{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/chaotic-conflicts/article_bee6256e-155c-5e49-abcd-bb3c77399fd3.html", "TITLE": " Chaotic conflicts ", "DATE": "Jun 30, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Chaos theory is about systems that may seemingly be stable but yet are highly sensitive to minor perturbations of any of the parameters that define them. A little push of any one may result in an entirely unpredictable outcome, hence the name \"chaos\". The most popular imagery, and I emphasise the word imagery, is of the connectivity of a butterfly flitting its wings in the depths of the Amazon rainforest leading to a devastating typhoon in the Pacific Ocean. It is largely a mathematical construct that may be projected into the real world. The remarkable thing about the construct is that any system arising from a tiny push while apparently chaotic may display its own highly ordered structure. Although well-intentioned the Integrity in Public Life Act became chaotic for two reasons the net of persons affected was much widened, and, the Commission, despite its many failings and self-inflicted wounds, it was never provided with the human and other resources to meet its responsibilities. And it may become even more chaotic as it reacts to external pressures such as a little push from Dr Rowley. Readers of this column may very well question the connection of abstract theory and the now rather thorny issue of conflicts of interest. Each of us will have a range of interests. Institutions, even churches, may also have ranges of interests. A conflict may arise where the individual or institution, in their normal activities, has an interest that, if pursued, may possibly influence their pursuit of another interest that might lead to some sort of impropriety or corruption. An insurance claims assessor, for example, does not evaluate claims for a relative's property, nor does an attorney represent both sides of a conflict between parties. The important point to note is that most people and institutions are able to recognise such conflicts and eliminate them in different ways before they metamorphose from possible to real conflict, and chaos. The ways in which conflicts of interest may be eliminated vary but the common approaches at the personal level may be either simple avoidance, or open disclosure of interest, or recusal from the particular conflict or third party resolution. At public and professional levels special codes of practice may be developed informing parties of what is expected of them. It is not uncommon in our Parliament for example for individuals to state an interest but contribute to a debate on the matter. As has been emphasised by both Martin Daly and Dana Seetahal, who addressed the broad issue as opposed to giving legal opinions, both clearly defined the boundaries of the envelope of the power of the Commission. Now that the Integrity Commission has created the precedent of commenting publicly on a matter \"actively in the public sphere\" it will be much challenged even if or when it considers the matter of the Lighthouse of the Lord Jesus Christ Church, a matter even more hyperactive in the public sphere. Religion is and has been a powerful, emotive, violent and often divisive influence in human affairs, historically much involved in conflicts of one kind or another, often exercising power over others, while having no monopoly on morality. And in this country, although in theory a secular state where religion plays mainly a ritual role in the affairs of the State, the Constitution does nevertheless guarantee freedom of conscience and religious belief and observance. Thus any investigation of any impropriety or corruption of any church, regardless of the size of its congregations or body of beliefs and rituals is bound to be contentious. Why should this be so Potential conflicts of interest! Anyone party to investigating the matter who happens to be seen to be in a leadership position of the same religious persuasion, or of the same family of beliefs, or for that matter a member of any religion, will see the immediate conflict. I would think also that there would be a similar conflict for any avowed atheist. The believers, especially those closest to that particular brand, might simply go overboard in softening the approach while the atheists might be rather heavy handed. Possibly only rational agnostics might be able to look into the matter objectively. The Commission is conducting and enquiry into the Guanapo church matter, hopefully in its own deliberate judgement and not on any directive from the executive and not on the basis of it being \"actively in the public sphere\". While the Commission has considerable powers of investigation it is procedurally bound by Section 34 at the end of which if it suspects an offence has been committed it can do no more than report to the Director of Public Prosecutions \"who may take such actions as he thinks appropriate\"! The Chairman with his admission of pastorship of a church must therefore now recuse himself from any involvement in the Guanapo chaos. Moreover the Chairman must avoid expressing personal opinions that may be misconstrued as being that of the Integrity Commission. Remember that a previous chairman stated that he had fun in his chairmanship. At least he was out of office. Together we achieve\".\"Let this celebration be a celebration of arrival - the arrival of our East Indian brothers and sisters and all other ethnic groups which have contributed to the creation of a unique nation, a diverse culture, and our melting pot of beauty,\"Samuel said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/judaism-christianity-and-islam/article_4ccd7b68-c861-5773-bd57-6c4425e60fca.html", "TITLE": " Judaism, Christianity and Islam ", "DATE": "Jan 26, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " Whereas there are billions who believe in a Creator (including, as I said many of the great scientists of the world), there is division amongst the believers as to what is the truth about Him. But most people inherit their religion from their parents and know very little about what other religions teach. For example, according to the Hebrew Old Testament, about 4,000 years ago a man named Abraham had an encounter with God. Brought up under a polytheist religion, he firmly established the tenet of monotheism, which made the Jews a people apart. Judaism is the religion of the Jewish people and it was the first great faith to hold that there is only one God. Christianity, on the other hand, was born about 2,000 years ago in Israel with the story of its founder Jesus of Nazareth, who, it is written, was crucified and willingly gave up his life for the redemption of humanity. But Christianity sprang from Judaism and it is said that he who encounters Jesus, encounters Judaism for according to his human nature, Jesus in his incarnation was a Jew. Islam is by far the youngest of the three religions. It originated in the 7th century AD, but its conceptual roots are in Judaism and Christianity. Muhammad was its founder. He is considered to be a prophet like Moses and the one who guided the Arabs towards monotheistic truth. When it began in the desert region of Arabia, it was initially considered an \"Arab religion for the Arabs,\" just as Judaism was the religion of the Jews many centuries before. All Christians firmly believe that Jesus is the Son of God. To Islam, however, Jesus is only \"a creature\" and Islam honours him as a true prophet and not as the Son of God. Muhammad, on the other hand, is said in the Qu'ran to be \"the Seal of the Prophets\" (Qu'ran 33:40), the last and greatest of the prophets, and the one who finally closes the series. However, the miracles which Jesus performed are interpreted as being manifestations of his divinity. But unlike Jesus, Muhammad had no miraculous powers, and when asked by his fellow citizens to show them a miracle, which would prove his right to claim that he was a prophet, he appealed to the Qu'ran. The miracle, he said, was the Qu'ran. Now, a crucial Christian belief, \"the mystery\" of the Trinity, holds that while God is fully one, there are three Persons in the one God and Jesus is the second Person of the Trinity. Judaism does not accept that Jesus is the Son of God and considers the doctrine of the Trinity to be polytheism and a contradiction to the strict monotheism of Judaism. As a consequence of this, the shared beliefs of Judaism and Christianity stop abruptly at the Old Testament. Islam rejects the Christian doctrine of the Trinity. For the Qu'ran there is only one unforgivable sin, namely, associating other beings with God and placing them on an equal with Him. According to Muslim tradition, the Qu'ran is the infallible word of God revealed by the Angel Gabriel to the Prophet Muhammad one night in Ramadan about the year 610 as he was asleep or in a trance. But the Christian Bible quotes the same Angel Gabriel as saying to Mary: \"And so, the child will be holy and be called Son of God\" (Luke 1:35). Which Gabriel is therefore telling the truth But Islam goes one step further and also professes that Jesus was never crucified. He was taken up into heaven by God after another who resembled him was killed in his place. The Christian Bible nonetheless quotes that person as saying: \"Father, forgive them for they know what they do\"! As for marriage, from early post-exile times, polygamy was generally accepted as the norm in Jewish society but in the year 1000 AD it was decreed that it was punishable by excommunication. Indeed, in his book The Bible and the Qu'ran, Jacques Jomier speculated that the polygamous law of the Qu'ran played a great part in the spread of Islam with the acceptability of divorce and the authorisation of having up to four simultaneous wives. Interestingly, it is documented that Muhammad himself had as many as ten wives. When he was 25 years old he married his first wife, a wealthy widow, Kadifah, aged 40, and his second wife and the youngest, Aisha, was six years old when he married her (Maxine Rodinson, Penguin Books, 1961). In addition, Jesus is quoted as saying that there is no marriage in heaven: \"At the resurrection men and women do not marry; they are like the angels in heaven\" (Matthew 22:30). However, the Qu'ran teaches otherwise: \"They (the righteous) shall recline in couches ranged in rows. To dark-eyed houris, We shall wed them\" (Qu'ran 52:20). All religions agree that God is Truth. But as Pilate once asked: \"What is truth\" Obviously, the world must not continually live a lie and I believe that it is destined that time will discover the truth and that one day soon we will all be one in that truth, whatever it may be! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/carmona-s-remarks-biased/article_2ce58834-c01d-5fda-9acd-e3eccaee2ada.html", "TITLE": " Carmona\u2019s remarks biased ", "DATE": "Sep 28, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "At a function organised by the Catholic Church on Republic Day, feature speaker President Anthony Thomas Aquinas Carmona took aim at the non-believing citizens of Trinidad and Tobago, telling his audience that \u201cwe must not in fact concede to those who are non-believers, to those who are agnostics, to those who are doubting Thomases, because you know what ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls We believe in the power of God, we believe that in fact there is a God that will bring miracles to this land of ours''. This is a direct encouragement to the population to rely on divine intervention rather than rationality, hard work, personal and community commitment to solve our many problems. It also encourages regression to tribal politics in a society that is struggling to move past the barriers of race and religion. While Mr Carmona is entitled to his religious beliefs in his private capacity, as President of the Republic he took an oath to serve all citizens of the nation. So when he singles out a group of persons defined by their non-religiosity, who may number anywhere between 26,000 and 90,000 persons depending on how census data is interpreted, he sends a message that such people are not entitled to all the rights enshrined in the Constitution. It also raises questions as to whether an individual who was agnostic or atheist or even non-Christian, would be fairly treated by him in respect of particular appointments and decisions which fall under the authority of the President. Ironically, mere hours later in his national address, President Carmona asserted that, \u201cEveryone is special and has a rightful place in this republic\u201d and \u201cThe common denominator of national dialogue must be compassion, empathy, understanding and tolerance''. This denominator he has signally failed to demonstrate in his dismissal and demonisation of non-believers. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/tha-sued-for-using-song-with-pork/article_54c083da-73f2-11e8-bdeb-a73ab072c5e7.html", "TITLE": " THA sued for using song with 'pork' ", "DATE": "Jun 19, 2018 ", "CONTENT": "Justice Frank Seepersad. Justice Frank Seepersad. A DECISION is expected next month in the case involving a composer who sued the Tobago Housing Assembly (THA) after it was alleged his song was used without permission in an advertisement. The ad included pork, which he does not consume because of his religious belief. Recording artiste and performer Sean Caruth cited copyright infringement over the use of his song \u201cThe Cook (Coal Pot)\u201d, which he created in 2001. The matter is being heard before Justice Frank Seepersad and was called yesterday at the Tobago High Court. Caruth said there were advertisements for the 2012 Tobago Blue Food Festival with his composition \u201cThe Cook (Coalpot)\u201d. He said it was used as the soundtrack along with a clip displaying images of various types of food, including pork. Caruth said he does not consume pork because of religion beliefs. He said had he been contacted, he would not have agreed to associate his song with such images. It was stated that his moral rights as author of the musical works were infringed as his name was not indicated in the advertisement ad as well as his right to object to his musical work being used in connection with images of pork \u201cwhich is contrary to (his) lifestyle and amount to derogatory action that is prejudicial to his honour and reputation.\u201d It was stated Caruth\u2019s performing rights were infringed upon as there was no authorization from him for his music to be included in the advertisement. Caruth\u2019s neighbouring rights were infringed, it was stated, by the reproducing of 39 seconds of the sound recording in television and radio advertisements that ran between September 20 and October 14 2012. The advertisement was aired on one radio station over 200 times, court documents stated. It was also later on YouTube. In 2012 the co-ordinator of the THA\u2019s event was informed the song had been used without permission and needed to be removed from television and radio advertisements. Caruth also launched a complaint with the Copyright Music Organization of Trinidad and Tobago with whom he had assigned the copyright for his musical works. The Copyright Music Organization of Trinidad and Tobago (COTT) advised the THA of the infringement and sought settlement. Caruth who said that up to March 2018 the ad was accessible on social media is seeking exemplary damages, interest and cost. The THA has submitted that it not a proper party to the proceedings and that it had no dealing with and is not liable to Caruth. It was also stated that Caruth was paid to perform at the 2013 Blue Food Festival, surrendering any claim regarding the 2012 use of the song. A decision in the matter is expected on July 23. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/lets-work-together-to-build-a-better-nation/article_44be9a88-f585-5d0c-89dc-0453913f7b19.html", "TITLE": " Lets work together to build a better nation ", "DATE": "Nov 2, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " One of the greatest privileges I have had in my lifetime is the opportunity to meet, work and live with people of various cultures, levels of wealth, religious beliefs and status. While people differ, one thing is common among all, they eat, drink, procreate and eventually die. Culture and religion lead different people in directions that may make one group to seem very different from another, but no matter what defines one group from another, none has been able to prevent diseases, sickness, accidents, disappointments and despair. Some people have learned over time that dancing, music, sharing with others, caring for each other and living in harmony with nature brings the human being the greatest joys. Almost every time I go to a funeral, it is the little things that one did to enhance the lives of another that is highlighted. I have never been to a funeral where family or loved ones boast about the accumulation of wealth or the amount of power one wielded. Its always to what extent we were able to positively impact the people we interacted with that determines our ultimate destiny or at the very least how people perceive our stay on earth. With this in mind I wish to challenge the citizens of Trinidad and Tobago to seek the greater good. What is wrong when as a nation we name our highest award after the Creator in Christian terms Other religions or people with different values should not be forced to accept the Trinity Cross, they can have the Order of T&T, but why eliminate our Christian history and values simply to be politically correct Why are we not insisting that our tax dollars are spent in ensuring that never again in our nations history we should be faced with a situation where our citizens are forced to sleep on chairs and on the floor in the corridors of our hospitals Why are we not opening up homes for the elderly where they can be treated with dignity Why are we not teaching our children to be tolerant of people of all cultures, races and beliefs and demonstrate the positives of loving each other Why are our aspirations evaluated by race, political party and culture rather than what is best for our nation Why is our politics divided in such a way that there are safe political seats anchored by ethnicity Trinidad and Tobago is blessed with natural resources, clean water, beautiful beaches, wonderful people and a location that protects our people from the ravages of natural disasters. In spite of these positives, however, there are people among us who are selfish, greedy, destructive, power hungry and wicked. It is because of these people that our cities and towns are dirty, our water courses are overgrown, our murder rate in among the highest per capita in the world, our system of justice has degenerated into one where street justice and revenge is replacing our courts and our children are living with a sense of hopelessness. It is up to us to face the challenges of tomorrow. We can put aside our sense of importance and silly pride and understand that we cannot stop our loved ones from getting sick or prevent our children from facing lifes hardships but we can do the best we can with the little we have. We can love God and one another and in so doing build better friendships, happier families, safer communities and ultimately a better nation. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-time-for-joy-and-vigilance/article_e4c4dbea-80b3-5f1d-960e-3f70527e9309.html", "TITLE": " A time for joy and vigilance ", "DATE": "Jul 4, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "We congratulate Muslims in the country who observed the holy month of Ramadan by fasting, praying and otherwise practicing the tenets of Islam, and we greet all adherents of the faith with \u201cEid Mubarak''. Like other religious occasions that are celebrated in our multi-cultural society, Eid-ul-Fitr, besides being a public holiday, is recognised by most citizens, if only by their enjoyment of the culinary delights that are associated with it. Such acceptance of each other's beliefs and practices, which goes beyond the tolerance that our national watchwords expect of us, bodes well for the future of this melting pot in which dividing lines are becoming increasingly blurred. Indeed, Islam is a religion which that has historically attracted people of all ethnicities. Generally, our Muslims have been good citizens who have made, and continue to make, important contributions to the development of the country. Although they were late entrants to the education system through the establishment of primary schools from the 1950s, they have risen to the top by insisting on high standards from both staff members and pupils. They have successfully engaged in other spheres of nation-building, from the public service to private enterprise and everything in between. They have thrived in a nation that embraces all religions, to the extent that most communities today have mosques, some of them landmark architectural structures, others simple buildings. Over the past three decades or more, Muslim women in particular who have chosen to dress in their traditional garments, more so the hijab, have been accepted in both the private and public sectors. Such freedoms must make celebrating Eid more joyous. Indeed, it is now commonplace for some Muslims to host the Eid prayers in open spaces such as the grounds of the University of the West Indies. As we join with them in marking the end of another Ramadan, we cannot help but note the deadly attack in one of Islam's holiest cities, Medina in Saudi Arabia. According to news reports last Monday, the suicide-bomb attack near the Prophet's Mosque was part of a series of Ramadan-related bombings that targeted Afghanistan, Iraq and Saudi Arabia, killing scores of Muslims. The Medina bombing was universally condemned across the Shia-Sunni divide. In fact, Iran's foreign minister Javad Zarif, who is not normally friendly with the Saudis, said, \u201cThere are no more red lines left for terrorists to cross. Sunnis, Shiites will both remain victims unless we stand united as one.\u201d With the self-styled \u201cIslamists\u201d indiscriminately attacking innocent people across the world, Trinidad and Tobago's Muslims should see it as their duty to expose any would-be terrorists who may pose threats to this country. If the Prophet's Mosque in Medina is not sacrosanct to such diabolical minds, then surely T&T is vulnerable. Eid is as auspicious an occasion as any for us to vow to unite against terrorism. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ahmed-rowley-extend-greetings-to-baptists/article_a218819a-45e2-50a1-989c-24e7c9590f97.html", "TITLE": " Ahmed, Rowley extend greetings to Baptists ", "DATE": "Mar 28, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley yesterday extended greetings to the Baptist community to mark the occasion of Shouter Baptist Liberation Day being celebrated today. In his message, Rowley noted that Spiritual and Shouter Baptists have overcome many challenges to be allowed the right to freely practise their religion. Imagine being forbidden to freely congregate for prayer and worship or being arrested for practising your religion. Picture being ridiculed, scorned and persecuted for your beliefs and having to flee to the hills, mountains and remote areas to escape the law, which prohibited your faith, Rowley said in a news release. That is what Spiritual/Shouter Baptists endured here in Trinidad and Tobago for decades. Rowley said, the religion, which is indigenous to T&T, has now spread to other islands and thousands of people are proud to call themselves Spiritual/Shouter Baptists. Far from the days when they were considered outlaws, the faith is now recognised for its positive contributions to our society, he said. However, Rowley said, steps must be taken to ensure the history of the Spiritual/Shouter Baptist is preserved as there is currently no repository of the history of the indigenous religion. The State must also partner with the church to help alleviate some of the social ills facing the society, he said. As we join our Spiritual Baptist brothers and sisters in celebrating Baptist Liberation Day, we use this opportunity to hold them up as an example of perseverance, persistence, strength and resilience. They have demonstrated that even the darkest hour of the night will eventually have to give way to the suns light. They understood, as we must now understand, that no challenge is insurmountable and we must always hold out hope for a better life and stay focused on working towards it, he said. Acting President Reziah Ahmed also extended greetings to the Baptist community in a news release yesterday. Today we join with our neighbours, our nations men and women and with our children to celebrate the historical occasion of the Repeal of an article of Lawthe Prohibition Ordinance of 1917, which, for many decades constituted oppression to our Shouter Baptist community, said Ahmed. It is a signal reminder of how men and women are the possessors of hearts and minds that have capacity for injustice, intolerance, and persecution of innocent people. Ahmed urged citizens to not take their freedoms for granted. Let us be grateful for our freedoms, and let us work to safeguard these freedoms, not only for ourselves, but let us leverage the communications platforms to extend our reach, beyond our shores, for the world is indeed a global village, she said. Indeed, as we celebrate this day of remembrance, let us uphold the great values of brotherhood and sisterhood and may we live in peace and harmony. Let us embrace our future with enthusiasm, hope and compassion and let us be forever reminded that it is in the capacity for love that man finds peace of mind. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-bad-argument/article_b55610d3-52f4-55a0-9af2-4f2dcdc62728.html", "TITLE": " A bad argument ", "DATE": "Feb 18, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "When making an argument, do you stick to the facts and adhere to the rules of logical discourse If so, you must lose all your arguments. You see, while there are places where facts and logic are essential to a good argument, Trinidad and Tobago isn't one of them. Instead, the individuals who get listened to in this place are usually those who present the most inane arguments as though they are gems of profound wisdom. Take medical doctor Courtenay Bartholomew, whom many people respect as a leading scientist. (Not me, eh, but people.) In his Express column of January 13, Bartholomew asserted that \"There can be no conflict between science and religion since both are supposed to deal with the truth, and it is written that God is truth.\" Now you may have encountered Christians who insist the Bible is true and, when you ask them how they know that, they answer, \"It say so in the Bible.\" You can't tell such people that they're committing a tautology, because they might report you to the police for using obscene language (and the police would believe them). Yet here we have a highly educated man also being totally tautological. (Do not attempt to say this three times fast.) Consider: if I told you that Prof Bartholomew was a zombie robot from the planet Karklebon, would you believe me just because I claimed I always speak the truth No, you'd want hard evidence, such as film footage of him eating somebody's brains while getting an oil change. This is the difference between the truths of religion and the truths of science. Science backs up its claims with experimental and observational data, tied together by logical explanations. Religion, on the other hand, proclaims truth on the basis of authority (\"God say so\"). And every religion has beliefs which are demonstrably wrong, in areas ranging from cosmology, biology, geography and history. In respect to this last discipline, another egregious example of false argument was provided on January 7 by Maha Sabha leader Sat Maharaj. In his ongoing quest to prove the perfection of ancient Indian society (the Hindu portion, that is), Maharaj asserted in a Trinidad Guardian column that pre-20th century India had no poverty, citing an 1835 address by Lord Macaulay to the British Parliament. \"Macaulay said he had travelled across the length and breadth of India and had not come across a person who is a beggar or who is a thief,\" wrote Maharaj. Now although Maharaj doesn't have a visible sense of humour, he clearly can't be serious. Anyone who genuinely wanted to argue whether 19th India was poor or not wouldn't rely on a selective account, especially when there are many other travellers who recorded quite different observations to Macaulay's. A better device is the Gross Domestic Product. According to figures compiled by the quantitative economist Angus Maddison, India's GDP per head in 1820 was $533, as compare to Britain's $1,243. But even that doesn't give a true picture since, thanks to the caste system, inequality was much greater in India than in Britain. However, the best measure of a country's poverty is a biological one: height. This is because better nutrition increases a population's average stature. Records show that in the 1840s, Indians recruited for indentured labour in Mauritius were 161-163 centimetres tall, as compared to English soldiers, who were 169 cms: and good statistics trumps anecdotes every time. January's dullest gem however, was provided on the 15th by economist Indera Sagewan-Alli, a former Opposition MP and regular guest commentator on TV talkshows. In an Express column headlined \"Power and political choices\", she wrote: \"According to a founding leader of the Caribbean Raja Yoga Movement, Sister Mohini, we each have the power to determine the perspective (positive or negative) we bring to the New Year and, indeed, to our lives.\" You'd think an economist would be more concerned with how resource allocation, incentives, and productivity impact on people's lives. But no. Instead, says Sagewan-Alli, \"If we choose success, immediately we assign power modules the task of defining actions that will facilitate success. All the forces of the universe then conspire with us to make success happen.\" And the proof of this amazing assertion Sagewan-Alli had set herself the goal of not finishing last in a 5K run. \"The sense of accomplishment, the surge of self-belief as I crossed the finishing line ahead of many was indescribable. But most important, it confirmed the theory that applying willpower to a task brings success.\" She didn't say, however, why the universe preferred everyone who had finished ahead of her. These are individuals whose opinions carry some weight in the society, with one of them sitting on the boards of several primary and secondary schools. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/honouring-a-good-baptist-leader/article_e6a46c69-da84-5fec-ba08-8356e4642a1d.html", "TITLE": " Honouring a good Baptist leader ", "DATE": "Mar 27, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "On the occasion of the celebration of Spiritual Shouter Baptist Liberation Day, I wish to pay special tribute to a deceased member of their flock, the late Pastor Lacaille of Maitagual, San Juan. I do so against the background of my being christened, confirmed and married in the Roman Catholic church, and, also a retired RC school principal. Pastor Lacaille always hailed out to my parents when passing our home on Lower Bushe Street and, almost invariably, came in to chat with them. Thus from the time I was a toddler to young adulthood, I was able to observe this gentleman at close quarters. This Baptist leader epitomised what being a Christian is all about. He was a very polite, soft-spoken individual who possessed the virtues of charity, humility and compassion for his fellow man, very slow to anger, with a passionate belief in his creator, never one to speak ill of another and ever willing to lend an ear and give sound advice. I consider it a great privilege and honour to have known this pious member of the Shouter Baptist following, who was persecuted and prosecuted for practising his religion but never wavered an iota from his convictions and beliefs. May God bless this good and faithful servant and may he rest in peace. Greetings to all members of the Shouter Baptist faith. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-message-to-the-contenders/article_776adb71-4b6e-5af0-b2a2-4c9f7a421a33.html", "TITLE": " A message to the contenders ", "DATE": "May 6, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Died in Crash: Richard Sutherland Wells Died in Crash: Richard Sutherland Wells At this stage in Trinidad and Tobago's history, politicians should be well aware of the dangers of using race and religion to win votes. Alas, many words to the wise have not been sufficient. People's National Movement (PNM) leader Prime Minister Patrick Manning in one evening managed to invoke both bogeys: first, byusing the term\"her own kind\" in reference to Kamla Persad-Bissessar; and then by warning Christians to be wary of United National Congress (UNC) coalitionmember Makandal Daaga because of the alleged desecration of the Roman Catholic cathedral 40 years ago. This latter allegation, for lacking validity,is likely only to backfire, andfor various reasons. First, although Mr Manning has been serving up \"political education\" in history on the PNM platform, his recounting of that 1970 episode entails a misstating of fairly well known events.For no suchdesecration occurred. The RC Church, whose cathedral demonstrators, including Mr Daaga, had entered, took no such offence.Indeed, the Catholic archbishop at the time, Anthony Pantin, had expressed sympathyfor the goals and grievances of the Black Power movementof whichMr Daaga was a leader. Fr Gerry Pantin founded the Catholic social-action organisation, Servol, as a direct result of the uprising. Mr Manning is strainingretroactively tomake an artificial mountain out of what is really a historical molehill. The PNM leaderis being more than a little disingenuous in calling for Mr Daaga to issue a \"letter of comfort\" to Catholics and Christians. More importantly, though, this blatant attempt to use religion can exacerbate divisions in the society, and indeed might be interpreted as a subtle degradation of religious mores as well. On their platform, some UNC coalition speakers have themselves beenusing religious belief to further their political fortunes,asserting that God is responsible for calling this election, that God wants Patrick Manning removed, and so on. A country which comprises several different religions and races can only become a nation when its various groups share common goals, values and aspirations. When politicians attempt to play different constituencies against one another, this process is hampered in ways which harm all citizens, even if some politicians gain short-term benefits from such divisions. Fortunately,more and morepeoplereceive racially coded language (\"her own kind'')and religious appeals with scepticism, even disdain. Addressing a World Press Freedom Day workshop last Monday, former media head Ken Gordon said, \"If we collectively condemn all who return to the old racial bogeys, and discard those who seek to keep us apart, they will get the message.\" We hope they do. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/peace-and-goodwill-to-all/article_f564d35d-8c52-5830-8d44-d348d3c14303.html", "TITLE": " Peace and goodwill to all ", "DATE": "Dec 24, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "WARMING UP: War Maker, with Nobel Abrego astride, being put through his paces yesterday at Santa Rosa Park, Arima, in preparation for today\u0092s 1,350-metre Republic Bank Online St James Stakes. \u0097Photo: ROBERT TAYLOR WARMING UP: War Maker, with Nobel Abrego astride, being put through his paces yesterday at Santa Rosa Park, Arima, in preparation for today\u0092s 1,350-metre Republic Bank Online St James Stakes. \u0097Photo: ROBERT TAYLOR Whatever one's beliefs, upbringing or culture, or whatever the rites and rituals recognised over the history of humanity, the historical fact resonates of the birth of Jesus of Nazareth, his teachings as recorded in the gospels, and the beginning of one of the world's great religions. Throughout a world of diversity and conflicts, in spite of its disasters and its challenges, and even in countries that have been much secularised and commercialised, today the world once again celebrates the birth of Christ. Some may dismiss the importance of the day, but surely the deep and lasting messages of the event must continue to offer some hope for humanity. What may these messages be Although many will already be aware of them, it is perhaps worth revisiting some. One is that common feeling of communion with others, that feeling of belonging to family, community and country. Another, certainly, is that upwelling of compassion for others, especially the lonely and the unfortunate. And, perhaps, it's all associated with that transition from the dying old year to the new. But surely the greatest message is simply one of hope, for without hope, and belief in the basic goodness of man, all would be lost and life would have little meaning. Let us not delude ourselves. There may be many seasonal distractions and considerable commercialisation, and some inevitable personal tragedies. But the core message of Christmas cannot be one of mindless merriment, but only one of hope and charity. This year, despite the negatives we have seen, citizens of all walks of life came together as one people to fulfill the hope of a mother, the hope for the chance of life for her seriously stricken child, Hanna Lendor. The gesture manifested the deep spirit of giving that is part of Christmas, exemplified in the story of the three wise men bearing gifts for the Christ child. Disorders of the wider world necessarily cause disquiet and alarm, not only for the victims of natural disasters but also for the innocent victims of civil strife, conflict and terror. What survives, however, is that deep belief and trust in the goodness of humanity that expresses a common hope, that always rises to the trials of lifepeace and goodwill to all. The Express and its staff at this time join in extending our best wishes to all readers and their families. May we also in some pause, and some reflection on the message of Christmas, embracing the prevailing spirit of peace and goodwill, in confident assurance that together we can build a future. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/puzzling-papal-view-on-key-issues/article_ded27bd5-c99a-5f65-9e91-50063d06a0e0.html", "TITLE": " Puzzling papal view on key issues ", "DATE": "Dec 27, 2008 ", "CONTENT": " We must admit considerable puzzlement at Pope Benedict's recent statement that saving humanity from homosexual or transsexual behaviour is equally as important as saving the rain forestspuzzlement in this season of peace and tolerance and goodwill to all men. Surely the pontiff and his advisers will have been aware of the reactions to the statement. And we are even more puzzled at the substance of the statement. Religions are generally conservative human associations with an accepted body of beliefs and rituals. What is notable about Christianity is that while it accepts both Old and New Testaments as the word of God, the testaments differ in their references to homosexuality. The Old Testament prescribes extremely barbaric punishments for the phenomenon while the New Testamentassuredly Christ's messagemakes little mention of it. Needless to say a not inconsiderable component of Christianity, the so-called gay and lesbian Christian community, publicly denounced the statement. And we suspect that many others will share their view. But what is also equally puzzling is that the Vatican, unlike many of the fundamentalist Christian churches, has progressively adopted a more liberal position on such burning issues as capital punishment and evolution. The science of animal behaviour has shown without doubt that homosexuality is relatively common especially among social birds and mammals, including the apes with which we share much of our DNA. Indeed, our closest cousin, the chimpanzeewith which we share 98.4 of our DNAdisplays the same general range of sexual relationships and activities as does the human species. So although science has not yet fully unravelled a genetic basis of human sexual orientation in humans, it seems highly probable that this will become known in time. The pontiff states that humanity needed to listen to the \"language of creation \" that supposedly defines the intended roles of man and woman, claiming that any union of two persons other than as a man and woman, husband and wife, presumably unified by a religious ceremony, was a \"destruction of God's work\". Anything else is self-destruction. The cynic might equally well argue that celibacy is contrary to natural law, preventing the natural flow of genes, the essence of life, from one generation to another. Today's world has changed radically from those days when the Church was part and parcel of the ruling classes and determined the norms of acceptable behaviour. In a functioning modern democracy religion has been guaranteed its specific place, in the same way that the individual man or woman is guaranteed basic human rights. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/hinduism-and-homosexuality/article_d191fe86-4032-58a6-814c-f8b943dce6f3.html", "TITLE": " Hinduism and homosexuality ", "DATE": "Jul 16, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "The Centre for Indic Studies is changing the way in which homosexuality is perceived in Hinduism. Its aim is to create a positive discourse on the Hindu view on a topic, by hosting a Queering Hinduism (the alternative Hindu discourse on alternative lifestyles seminar.The seminar, titled Queering Hinduism -the alternative Hindu discourse on alternative lifestyles was held last month at the National Council of Indian Culture (NCIC) Nagar in Chaguanas. It featured three speakers and their view of Hinduism regarding alternative or queer lifestyles. The conference focused on issues involving the LGBT (Lesbian/Gay/Bisexual/ Transgender) community.Founding director of CIS, lecturer at the University of the West Indies (UWI) and NCIC founding youth arm chair, Dr. Arvind Singh gave his presentation entitled, LGBTH (where the H stood for Hindu).Singh highlighted the Hindu shruti-smriti paradigm of knowledge in which spirituality in the quest for the supreme truth is not concerned in the least with gender and sexuality.Singh drew from scriptural sources to show that in Hinduism, sexuality was seen as fluid and natural in all its manifestations.He said, The continued denial of rights is categorically UN-HINDU and privileges, like the trinity cross perhaps, the beliefs of some religious communities over others, not to mention over the fundamental rights of people.Krystal Ghisyawan, whose current research is focused on loving lesbian women in Trinidad and their desire for safety within their families, country and religion, spoke about the real challenges same sex loving women face trying to reconcile their sexuality with their religion and family life. She explained that they (lesbian women) often turn to a more personal, individual, less institutional form of the faith.Ghisyawan presentation covered, \"the loved experience of same sex loving Hindu women (whom she interviewed for her PhD thesis.) She said: Most of them felt as though there was pressure in the Hindu community to be an ideal model of femininity - heterosexual and submissive. I also referenced the myths within the religion that they identified with to make sense of their sexual orientation, such as the Ardhanareeshwar (half woman God) which combined masculinity and femininity in one body. And other myths\".The final speaker was internationally recognised artist Shalini Seereeram who has had many of her works featured in MACO Caribbean Living magazine, Caribbean Belle and the Trinidad Express.Seereerams latest exhibition entitled, Intimate Moments focused on the intimacies between women.At the seminar, Seereeram spoke of the cultural propensity of Indians to bottle up, suppress and not speak of hurt, pain and violence. And how damaging this can be and that only through acceptance of that hurt and pain can one transcend which becomes a part of the creative process.She also shared her personal experience and struggles of being an openly gay woman and hopes that her work can touch the lives of others, so they feel less ashamed, less afraid, more secure in being themselves then she would consider the work a success. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/pastoring-plasticity/article_297de009-a481-525a-b9d3-baadb99cae25.html", "TITLE": " Pastoring plasticity ", "DATE": "Mar 21, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The English language is so full of words of multiple meanings. Take the word pastor, for example. In the language it may mean a priest, minister, elder or layperson, more often male, of one of the Christian faiths exercising some degree of spiritual or even social-behavioural influence over a group or congregation. Other cultures have different names for such leadership of different faiths, which we need not consider here, except that they exercise some degree of control over the group. The word may also mean a shepherd or one who herds or generally manages a flock of sheep for their wool and flesh, the words shepherd? and pastor often being used interchangeably, sharing a common theme of the individual herding/managing/controlling a group. The words plastic and plasticity? on the other hand have a wider range of meanings around a central theme of the property of being formless and amorphous and being moulded by diverse processes into distinct shapes or even functions. The word plastic is widely used in everyday life and one of its meanings is not unsurprisingly impressionable and easily influenced. Also, as we learn from biology and, incidentally, archaeology and history, that at birth a newborn human will have the potential to develop into an adult consistent partly with his or her genetic programming, and largely by the nurturing and conditioning of the immediate family, its social, cultural and political environment. Given the diversity of human cultures it is inevitable that the species must necessarily have a considerable degree of plasticity in contrast to many other animals that are prisoners of their genes. If one is born into one morph of a particular faith the odds are you will continue in it to some degree, although some may drift away or sever adherence. Although many animals, particularly mammals, have differing capabilities of learning, the human species with its large brain must obviously have unusual learning ability and consequently conditioning potential. While many mammals have genetically determined social structures involving herding behaviour, humans can hardly be described as a naturally herding species, being genetically somewhere between solitary and social, displaying extreme plasticity of social behaviour. This plasticity gives us language and writing, art and music, agriculture and food production, social, political and economic development, science in all its forms, clashes of cultures, histories of all its recent populations, and of course religion or religions. When we consider religion we tend to concentrate more on the body of beliefs about human life, ways and rituals, moral codes, religious laws, possibly also life about us, the nature of the planet and solar system, and the wider universe, and the cause or causes of material existence, possibly created by some sort of supernatural being or beings. We rarely consider origins or that religions might be mental states, properties of human minds and byproducts of their social conditioning. Perhaps, also, we often seem not to understand that religions in all their manifestations are closely interwoven with virtually all human activities or behaviour, language, war, commerce, politics, conquest, history, philosophy, the arts, disasters, disease, physical and economic development, environmental decay and slavery and even genocide. All too often, however, we seem to shy away from considering the origins of religions, mostly I imagine, in order to avoid offence. As I have suggested above, while we are not a naturally herding species our plasticity favours a considerable measure of herding behaviour, with all manner of pastors leading and controlling different groups, which in time achieve critical mass and a following. Put another way, it might be suggested that religion is more an expression of a human condition of a particular people at a particular time than an expression of ultimate reality, an expression that had some adaptive value, like speech and later writing, in binding primitive groups or super family groups of humans, favouring development of cultures, but which would later be a divisive force separating cultures. Writer Raymond Ramcharitar so aptly sees this condition as the malleability of human nature. In other words all religions could really be abstractions of the human mind randomly guided by cultural conditioning. Perhaps the best demonstration of religious plasticity is to be found in the United States, with its history of colonisation, conquest and enslavement. There are perhaps about 150 recognisable morphs of Christianity all sharing a small common core of beliefs, but with each grouping having a distinctive flavouring of binding rituals, from the rigid bureaucratic types, the mega churches, to the individual television performances, many competing for market share, with some seeking political power, and not a few offering healings on demand, gimmicks and prosperity. For survival they all rely on the financial contributions or tithes from their individual groupings, and their messages and promises. There are also other religions in that country; their numbers are much smaller but their basic methods may be comparable. Whether pastor or shepherd, the leadership, like political leadership, thrives insofar as it is able to herd its followers usually with props and promises. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/chaotic-conflicts/article_c40f6caf-a760-5513-9e8b-bd574a6ad282.html", "TITLE": " Chaotic conflicts ", "DATE": "Jun 21, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Chaos theory is about systems that may seemingly be stable but yet are highly sensitive to minor perturbations of any of the parameters that define them. A little push of any one may result in an entirely unpredictable outcome, hence the name \"chaos\". The most popular imagery, and I emphasise the word imagery, is of the connectivity of a butterfly flitting its wings in the depths of the Amazon rainforest leading to a devastating typhoon in the Pacific Ocean. It is largely a mathematical construct that may be projected into the real world. The remarkable thing about the construct is that any system arising from a tiny push while apparently chaotic may display its own highly ordered structure. Although well-intentioned the Integrity in Public Life Act became chaotic for two reasons the net of persons affected was much widened, and, the Commission, despite its many failings and self-inflicted wounds, it was never provided with the human and other resources to meet its responsibilities. And it may become even more chaotic as it reacts to external pressures such as a little push from Dr Rowley. Readers of this column may very well question the connection of abstract theory and the now rather thorny issue of conflicts of interest. Each of us will have a range of interests. Institutions, even churches, may also have ranges of interests. A conflict may arise where the individual or institution, in their normal activities, has an interest that, if pursued, may possibly influence their pursuit of another interest that might lead to some sort of impropriety or corruption. An insurance claims assessor, for example, does not evaluate claims for a relative's property, nor does an attorney represent both sides of a conflict between parties. The important point to note is that most people and institutions are able to recognise such conflicts and eliminate them in different ways before they metamorphose from possible to real conflict, and chaos. The ways in which conflicts of interest may be eliminated vary but the common approaches at the personal level may be either simple avoidance, or open disclosure of interest, or recusal from the particular conflict or third party resolution. At public and professional levels special codes of practice may be developed informing parties of what is expected of them. It is not uncommon in our Parliament for example for individuals to state an interest but contribute to a debate on the matter. As has been emphasised by both Martin Daly and Dana Seetahal, who addressed the broad issue as opposed to giving legal opinions, both clearly defined the boundaries of the envelope of the power of the Commission. Now that the Integrity Commission has created the precedent of commenting publicly on a matter \"actively in the public sphere\" it will be much challenged even if or when it considers the matter of the Lighthouse of the Lord Jesus Christ Church, a matter even more hyperactive in the public sphere. Religion is and has been a powerful, emotive, violent and often divisive influence in human affairs, historically much involved in conflicts of one kind or another, often exercising power over others, while having no monopoly on morality. And in this country, although in theory a secular state where religion plays mainly a ritual role in the affairs of the State, the Constitution does nevertheless guarantee freedom of conscience and religious belief and observance. Thus any investigation of any impropriety or corruption of any church, regardless of the size of its congregations or body of beliefs and rituals is bound to be contentious. Why should this be so Potential conflicts of interest! Anyone party to investigating the matter who happens to be seen to be in a leadership position of the same religious persuasion, or of the same family of beliefs, or for that matter a member of any religion, will see the immediate conflict. I would think also that there would be a similar conflict for any avowed atheist. The believers, especially those closest to that particular brand, might simply go overboard in softening the approach while the atheists might be rather heavy handed. Possibly only rational agnostics might be able to look into the matter objectively. The Commission is conducting and enquiry into the Guanapo church matter, hopefully in its own deliberate judgement and not on any directive from the executive and not on the basis of it being \"actively in the public sphere\". While the Commission has considerable powers of investigation it is procedurally bound by Section 34 at the end of which if it suspects an offence has been committed it can do no more than report to the Director of Public Prosecutions \"who may take such actions as he thinks appropriate\"! The Chairman with his admission of pastorship of a church must therefore now recuse himself from any involvement in the Guanapo chaos. Moreover the Chairman must avoid expressing personal opinions that may be misconstrued as being that of the Integrity Commission. Remember that a previous chairman stated that he had fun in his chairmanship. At least he was out of office. A woman and her lesbian lover were allegedly beaten by the woman\u2019s husband after she confessed to an extramarital affair last Saturday. The suspect, a 48 year old fisherman, flew into a rage after the confession and allegedly beat his wife at their home in Charlieville. Police said when the wife called her lover and told her of the attack, the lover went to the house and was allegedly battered by the suspect and his 19 year old son. The suspect and his son allegedly ganged up and beat the lover with their fists and a cutlass, police said. The two women \u2013the 43 year old Charlieville wife and her 47 year old lesbian lover - went to the Chaguanas police station that night and reported the incident to police. Officers took both women to the Chaguanas District Health Facility and they were transferred to the Eric Williams Medical Sciences Complex. The suspect\u2019s wife was treated for minor injuries and discharged. Police said that the lover was severely beaten on the head and face, and was warded at hospital. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-council-and-the-cross/article_1f01ca14-a092-5acc-8dbd-fc247da58486.html", "TITLE": " The Council and the Cross ", "DATE": "May 20, 2009 ", "CONTENT": " I have been writing and speaking about the national awards issue for nearly 15 years now. In my first article, which appeared in the Sunday Express of August 28, 1994, I urged among other things that \"the Trinity Cross award be dropped in favour of an award of truly national scope. The words 'Trinity' and 'Cross' carry obvious connotations of religion; they represent the very essence of Christianity. Even if 70 per cent of the population is Christian, ours is a secular society, where every creed is said to find an equal place. Therefore, logically, should any national award, and especially our highest award, convey any hint of emphasis on, or even leaning towards, this religion or that, or, indeed, carry any religious coloration at all Especially in a country as touchy as this one is on race and, to a lesser extent, religion, does this advance the cause of national unity\" I repeated this position in another Express article six years later, in August 2000. I added that I considered the whole national award system grievously defective, and that I would never accept any award under it. Nearly six years after that, in June 2006, I wrote this: \"For me, the most worrying aspect of the (Trinity Cross) debate has been the continuing subtext of religion, race and party politics in the comments of those favouring the preservation of the current top award. It is a dangerous cocktail. \"Where religion is concerned, you would think that many Christians' interpretation of Christianity is for them indisputably more important than anyone else's, and more valid than any commitment to constructing an equitable society within the framework of the country's Constitution and declared aspirations. \"Instead, it has largely been a question of asserting the primacy of Christianityin a secular state, mind youand a conviction that those 'devious' Hindus, led by Sat Maharaj, have in fact been carrying out their long-held plan to undermine the faith and eventually topple it. The heathens would then triumph, and a wrathful Christian God would, for our sins, unleash fire and brimstone and devastating floods upon our formerly peaceful, demon-free, Christian land (thus indiscriminately liquidating both Christian and heathen alike). \"But it isn't only Hinduism that threatens (Islam isn't spoken about too much, but that is perhaps because Muslims are fewer in number, and less voluble than Sat). Dem peoplethat is how, in a projected Vision 2020 world, many of us still see our fellow citizens: 'dem people', or worseare also 'Indians', and everyone knows you can't trust 'Indians'. \"They aren't going to stop at causing the cross to go; they will next move to change the country's name. That name (ask some of our 'historians') is 'Trinidad', and Trinidad is a country of which Tobagolike, say, Brasso Piedra or Rampanalgasis a part, and consequently without a separate identity in what we love to call, erroneously, our 'twin-island republic'. And, horrors, all dem 'Indians', even the Christian ones, are UNC. Never mind the current schisms in the party; they want to take over.\" I concluded: \"If over the years I have set my face like flint against an award with religious connotations, why do you think this is so Because I am anti-religious, or at least anti-Christian Because I prefer 'Indians' to black people Because I am a secret UNCite Because I am so gullible I've allowed myself to be led astray by 'dem people' Or is it because I wish to see us work towards a society in which every creed and race can one day genuinely find an equal place And in which much more energy is exerted on nation-building than on fevered exaltation of one's racial, ethnic, religious or political affiliations, beliefs and prejudices\" The Trinity Cross has now been replaced as the highest, or any, national award. Despite this, the Maha Sabha, the Islamic Relief Centre and others (\"the appellants\") approached the Privy Council (PC) on the constitutionality of the 1969 Letters Patent establishing the society of honour called the Order of Trinity, the highest rank of which was the Trinity Cross. In its judgment delivered last April 28, the PC said that the appellants were \"entitled to a declaration that creation of the Trinity Crossbreached their right to equality under section 4(b), their right to equality of treatment under section 4(d) and their right to freedom of conscience and belief under section 4(h) of the Constitution of Trinidad and Tobago 1976. Their Lordships will allow the appeal and make a declaration to that effect.\" I congratulate the appellants on their perseverance and eventual success (due in no small measure to the forensic skills of Sir Fenton Ramsahoye), but I am embarrassed that matters had to reach the point of having our highest courta foreign courtdeclare our former highest national award unconstitutional. We should all be embarrassed, and ashamed of the obstinacy that too many of us have displayed, and continue to display, in not recognising as equals a large proportion of our countrymen and women. At least I won't have to write anything on the subject in 2012. But the national award system as a whole, even with the departure of the Trinity Cross, is still defective. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/pm-t-t-a-mecca-for-shouter-baptists/article_151069ca-a32e-5840-963e-6af0f4bbda78.html", "TITLE": " PM: T&T a mecca for Shouter Baptists ", "DATE": "Mar 28, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar says Shouter Baptists have come a long way, from having their religion prohibited to now being a colourful and vibrant part of our countrys religious mosaic. Delivering greetings to the Baptist community in a news release yesterday, on the eve of Spiritual Shouter Baptist Day, Persad-Bissessar noted the significance of todays holiday, saying it was on March 30, 1951 that the Shouters Prohibition Ordinance of 1917 was repealed, allowing Spiritual/Shouter Baptists to worship and practise their faith openly without discrimination and repression. Like all others, this faith community enjoys protection under Trinidad and Tobagos 1976 Republican Constitution, which guarantees all citizens, freedom of conscience and religious belief and observance, said the Prime Minister. Persad-Bissessar said although the origins of the Spiritual/Shouter Baptist faith in Trinidad and Tobago can be traced to foreign countries, it has evolved over time to become a unique, indigenous religion. It has managed to fuse the spontaneity and rhythms of Africa with the restrained, traditional tenets of Christianity to produce a religion that is vibrant, expressive and dynamic. Today, the Spiritual Shouter Baptist Community constitutes a most colourful and vibrant part of our countrys religious mosaic. Indeed, many of ours sons and daughters of this faith are highly respected, not only among their own, but in the wider society. Many of them are professionals who hold substantive positions in both the public and private sectors. The Spiritual Shouter Baptist Community also plays a critical role in the education of our nations children by proudly managing their very own St Barbaras Spiritual Shouter Baptist Primary School in Maloney. Trinidad and Tobago can easily be described as the mecca for the Shouter Baptist movement in the Caribbean, she said. Persad-Bissessar said the Government will continue to give support to and partner with the Baptist community, and all other faiths, to build a better society. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/fudged-and-smudged/article_5fdb6517-c5ba-53bd-8a8f-3956ec3dcec5.html", "TITLE": " Fudged and smudged ", "DATE": "Oct 31, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "for one day: The Amadea docked in Scarborough, Tobago. for one day: The Amadea docked in Scarborough, Tobago. This is a dangerous time for us. Fundamental rights are under attack, as is the Judiciary, the primary arbiter of the extent of those rights. As my esteemed colleague, Selwyn Ryan, wrote in this newspaper two Sundays ago: \"What we are witnessing is an unconcealed attempt at comprehensive executive aggrandisement.\" I would add that the attempt is intended to acquire power to whatever extent is necessary in order to mow down anything and smear anyone interfering with the executive aggrandisement plan. The title of this column is inspired by something written by Maureen Dowd in the New York Times earlier this month, in which she wrote about how ideals \"collide with harsh reality\" and the dangers of excessive compromise of inspiring objectives. She was analysing the apparent wavering of Barack Obama, whose election to the office of President of the United States initially set the world on fire. The focus of Maureen Dowd's column to which I refer was concern that President Obama's charisma might be diluted by his constantly reaching for common ground. She quotes the former President of the Czech Republic who warned that, \"With minor compromises start the big and dangerous ones, the real problems.\" Ms Dowd comments that, one must be careful not to compromise so much that, \"ideals get blurred out of recognition\". You can \"get smudged if too much is fudged\". This Government has been in a constant state of denial that violent crime is a serious problem for Trinidad and Tobago. It has consistently fudged dealing with the problem, often not even acknowledging that there is one. Unfortunately for us the fudging has taken us way past merely being smudged. We are experiencing grief in abundance. The population is traumatised, in fear of opening our doors or going out on routine business or for pleasure. There is no place that cannot be reached with impunity by the violent criminal element whenever they feel like it. The fudging of the crime problem is backed up by a belief that the Christian God is on the side of the Government and will deliver its Ministers from evil and, perhaps, the rest of us ordinary mortals will receive the collateral benefit of our delivery from evil. There are obvious practical difficulties in mixing up politics and religion. It is plainly offensive in a plural society for any public official to lay claim to knowledge of who is the true God. The Constitution guarantees freedom of worship and we sing that there is an equal place for every creed and race. However, in view of the claim of this Government that it is \"drunk on God\", (a blasphemy if I ever heard one), the difficulty of mixing politics and religion that concerns me most at the moment is the effect which reliance on religious belief has on the mind of the politician. In a lecture given in 1932, Freud, the psycho-analyst, compared and contrasted the roles of philosophy, science and religion and said of the effect of religion on men and women that: \"It assures them of protection and final happiness amid the changing vicissitudes of life, and guides their thoughts and actions by means of precepts which are backed by the whole force of its authority.\" Put simply, a person armed with an assurance that everything will be all right does not need to embrace philosophy or science or to heed the views of others in an attempt to consider \"how to avoid certain dangers or to combat many sufferings\". Likewise it would seem to those politicians with God on their side that there is no need for meaningful democracy because the wishes of other people cannot trump the certainty of the religious revelation. Consequently, checks and balances on executive power are a nuisance and an impediment to implementation of the revelation. Living in the midst of the misuse of religious fervour to gloss over bad politics and bad governance compels me, by contrast to many of President Obama's critics, to view his attempts to find common ground with sympathetic relief. I am comforted that the most powerful democratically elected official should first seek as far as possible to reconcile conflicting views on healthcare and wars being fought abroad, like those in Iraq and Afghanistan, before attempting to impose his will on the population who elected him. The fact is we badly need a whole range of measures likely to bring peace and reconciliation in this small and divided nation of ours. We have fudged and smudged our path to a civilised quality of life. We have a huge amount of work to do to get ourselves off the road that is sign posted materialism only, and back on the road that is sign posted civilisation. The latter road is a broad and inclusive avenue, the former road is a dead-end, pun intended, in view of our disproportionate number of murdered dead. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/shakti-and-ash-in-modern-t-t/article_a3b15a20-a274-5606-8a48-fcdaba8a773d.html", "TITLE": " Shakti and Ash in modern T&T ", "DATE": "Apr 24, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "In a column last month I wrote about an interesting new book on the Ramayana tradition in Trinidad. Today I'll look at another recent study of religion in T&T, this one by an American anthropologist, Keith McNeal. It has the usual long, academic type of title: Trance and Modernity in the Southern Caribbean: African and Indian Popular Religions in Trinidad and Tobago. This book is a comparative study of the Orisha or Shango religion, and the Shakti Puja traditionthe worship of Kali and associated deities in modern Trinidadian Kali temples. It is historical ethnography: it combines historical research based on documentary evidence, with detailed descriptions of present-day practices based on actual observation and even participation (McNeal did most of this \"field work\" in 1999-2000). These two religious traditions are what McNeal calls \"subaltern\": both were historically despised and marginalised in colonial Trinidad, a situation which still prevails even today, though to a far lesser extent especially in the case of the Orisha faith. Derived from origins in West Africa and North and South India respectively, McNeal shows that they have evolved in remarkably similar ways, both adapting and changing in response to similar forces in colonial and post-colonial society. Because this is an academic book, there is a lot of theoretical discussion which is densely written and difficult; but the heart of the book for non-academic readers will probably be the chapters that present the \"ethnographical\" descriptions of the two religions, their ritual practices, their beliefs, their \"pantheons\" (deities). The fascinating material is enriched by striking photographs by the author of what he saw at Kali temples and Orisha yards (taken and published with permission, of course!) The core of McNeal's project is to show how similar the ritual practices and belief systems of the two religions are, though he never down-plays the obvious differences. Both are examples of what he calls \"ecstatic worship\": the central religious ritual involves persons falling into a trance (\"catching the power\") and \"manifesting\" a particular deity. During these manifestationsa term McNeal prefers to the more commonly used \"possession\"the \"medium\" counsels, rebukes, advises and (especially in the Kali temples) tries to heal those who have come to the service. Of course the manifesting deities are different: Kali and associated deities of mainly Indian derivation as against the Orisha pantheon of Yoruba origins. But the concepts behind the rituals of trance, manifestation and medium performance, McNeal shows, are strikingly similar. Each faith stresses a kind of mystical, cosmic energy which makes the trance and manifestation of the deities possible: Shakti in the Kali worship, which is often known as Shakti Puja, Ash in the Orisha. In addition, the ritual sacrifice to the deities of animals, goats and chickens, has historically been an essential part of worship services in both faiths, though not all Orisha \"feasts\" involve such sacrifices, and many modern Kali temples don't practice \"blood sacrifice\" at all. The similarity between the two faiths, therefore, is fundamental, having to do with core religious concepts and rituals. It's not just the fact that many African-Trinidadians attend Kali temples, and some Indo-Trinidadians are involved in the Orisha faith. It's not just that there are \"Indian\" deities who manifest in Orisha ritualsOsain is also known as \"Indian Man\", Ogun may manifest as Hanuman or Mahabil, Oshun has recently shown a link with Ganga Mata and Mother Lakshmi. The similarity has to do with deep spiritual conceptsoften called a \"cosmology\"and the ritual practices at the heart of both faiths. Shakti Puja or Kali worship, of course, is rooted in traditions of Hinduism originating in both North and South India which were brought here by the indentured immigrants in the 19th century. It was revived and transformed by influences brought from Guyana after national Independence, and the modern Kali temples were established from the late 1970s on. McNeal gives a detailed account of both the colonial practices which were \"precursors\" or fore-runners to the modern Kali worship, and the individuals, Guyanese and local, who pioneered the present-day movement. Although Shakti Puja is part of Hinduism, the modern movement has not been warmly received by mainstream, orthodox, \"Sanatanist\" Hinduism. It is generally frowned on as being a more \"primitive\", backward, \"low\" form of the faith. In this sense, the marginalisation endured by Kali worship in colonial times has continuedbut now it is the mainstream Hindu bodies, rather than the State, doing the marginalising. By contrast, as McNeal shows, the Orisha movement has been embraced warmly by many persons who are not the traditional, grassroots adherents of the faith, but who see in it a vitally \"African\" religion which can help redeem and recover their African identity. They have tended in recent times to lead a movement to \"purify\" the faith by eliminating the Christian (and Hindu) elements which have been part of it since the 19th century, and by emphasizing its Yoruba origins. No surprise that this effort has not been without its tensions and controversies. McNeal's richly detailed and always sympathetic study should help us to see how complex and fascinating our cultural and religious scene really is. Bridget Brereton isEmerita Professor of History at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine, and has studied and written about the history of Trinidad and Tobago, and the Caribbean, for many decades. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/multicultural-t-t-can-lead-the-world/article_c441c3a7-8041-58b9-9f12-41b6a5339d6a.html", "TITLE": " Multicultural T&T can lead the world ", "DATE": "Aug 25, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Whatever is good, beautiful, excellent, noble, elevating, inspiring, instructive of truth, equality, justice, peace, harmony, quality, integrity and greatness, in any culture, religion or philosophy, should be considered worthy of the heritage of mankind and this should be accepted as the foundation of multiculturalism. We are the people of a multicultural society, which we are by history, constitution and reality. Philosophies that divide mankind must be abandoned, especially those that proclaim partiality of a deity in the affairs of mankind, legitimise use of drugs, narcotics, violence against persons and discrimination with respect to gender, must be rejected. Blanket support for any creed must be curtailed in the light of reason, justice, science and intuition and experience. Openness and freedom of tranquil discussion must be employed. We, with our colonial past, have been forced and constrained to accept toxic religion, philosophies and practices that intrinsically divide mankind as chosen and not chosen, favoured or not favoured. We must individually and nationally adopt the good, beautiful, noble and excellent and discard the ignoble, unjust, unwholesome, anarchic and degrading, obnoxious. The law must protect the victims of such partiality and discrimination. We have overcome a lot, that which is obnoxious in other societies, and we increasingly accept diversity in music, dress, religion and views of the world.We must reject political leaders who selfishly utilise our differences to divide us. Religious leaders must reexamine ancient beliefs and not accept as blanket truth that which comes from some foreign authority or primitive document. We have the potential to lead the world with our success in multiculturalism. God bless this nation!
