{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/divali-greetings-from-parliament/article_f5f87ee0-f3e5-5dae-90e1-f15018e81559.html", "TITLE": " Divali greetings from Parliament ", "DATE": "Nov 6, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "VIEWING THE BODY: Crime scene officers view the body of an unidentified man who was found with gunshot wounds about his body at Roops Junction in Couva yesterday. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD VIEWING THE BODY: Crime scene officers view the body of an unidentified man who was found with gunshot wounds about his body at Roops Junction in Couva yesterday. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley said yesterday that he was reluctant accept the Speaker's invitation to give Divali greetings in the House of Representatives, lest his bestowing of such greetings should \"cause any member of this House to fly out the door\". The sarcasm behind the statement elicited general laughter but National Security Minister Jack Warner, to whom the remark was no doubt directed, wore a cheerless expression. Warner had stated in a letter to Surujdeo Mangaroo, Public Relations Officer of the National Council of Indian Culture (NCIC) , that he had stayed away from the opening of Divali Nagar because of the presence of Rowley. Rowley said in Parliament yesterday that the country was fortunate because it had different cultures. \"At times like these it is the coming together and sharing of what the communities have brought and made Trinidad and Tobago's own that should cause us to understand our place in the world. \"In the area of peaceful coexistence, multicultural, multireligious, multiethnic communities living together and sharing experiences, working together to build a nation, there is nowhere else in the world where a better example could be found than Trinidad and Tobago, notwithstanding the best efforts of some who may not fully appreciate what we have accomplished in the short life of our country,\" he stated. Rowley said the triumph of light over darkness was something accepted by all religions in the world and Divali represented that. He said in this country, there were celebrations, such as Christmas and Divali, which transcended the communities for which they came. Minister of Transport Chandresh Sharma said said he was happy that in this 50th anniversary of Independence, the country stood strong as a nation in its commitment to religious freedom and diversity. \"Each Member of Parliament here has in his or her heart the best for Trinidad and Tobago. It is in this vein that we sit here every week and conduct a respectful debate on the issues affecting Trinidad and Tobago. We may have differing opinions on how we reach the same goal but we do have one goala better Trinidad and Tobago for all of us for the next 50 years,\" he said to loud desk thumping on both sides. He said the observance of Divali was testimony to the diverse cultural traditions of the country. \"It makes all of us very proud to know the high regard which we hold and demonstrate for each other's beliefs and customs,\" he said. Sharma said each year, across communities all over this country without distinction of religion, the citizens come together to witness Ramleela performances. House Speaker Wade Mark also gave Divali greetings. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/foundation-work-starts-on-tobago-baptist-complex/article_49f3fc52-83ea-55a4-aaa9-b4d47cab9e53.html", "TITLE": " Foundation work starts on Tobago Baptist complex ", "DATE": "Mar 29, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "Despite 65 years of liberation, some sections of the Spiritual Shouter Baptist community in Tobago are of the belief that members of the faith continue to be treated like bastard children. Those were the words of Bishop Mural Dillon, as he spoke during Spiritual Shouter Baptist Liberation Day celebrations in Tobago yesterday. Dillon said Trinidad and Tobago gave birth to three children during slavery and, in the post-slavery era today, two of them are national treasures and the other is treated like a bastard. These \u201cchildren\u201d are the steelband, calypso and the Spiritual Shouter Baptist religion. \u201cThe world recognises steelband and calypso as natural treasures of Trinidad and Tobago...although the Spiritual Shouter Baptist religion has spread throughout the Caribbean and to some international countries, we are still treated like a bastard child in our own birthplace,\u201d Dillon said. However, one of the highlights of yesterday's celebrations was the fact that the foundation for the proposed building for the Spiritual Baptist Educational Complex has started, at a cost of $600,000. Since 2006, when the lands were handed over by the Tobago House of Assembly (THA) to members of the faith, THA Chief Secretary Orville London had long called for a structure to be built and, with the help of some Tobago businessmen, that mission has been accomplished. However, thieves recently stole 50 lengths of steel from the property. London toured the lands and observed the foundation works yesterday. \u201cI'm saying that the returns that Tobago demands is not the money, not in resources, not in even tangible returns. The returns are to be measured by the number of lives that you touch, the number of troubled persons that you comfort, the number of young people nurtured and prepared,\u201d said the Chief Secretary. And Assemblyman Handell Beckles stated that the future of the nation is in God's hands. \u201cAnd that is why I am comfortable that the future of the church is in God's hands and I am comfortable as a politician that the future of Tobago is in God's hands, and I'm comfortable that the future of our nation is in God's hands,\u201d Beckles said. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/saving-the-earth-the-hindu-way/article_766effd7-c68e-5e15-8967-31d946ec416f.html", "TITLE": " Saving the Earth the Hindu way ", "DATE": "Jul 8, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " Does any religion preach contempt for nature It doesn't seem so; it seems to be quite the opposite. In a previous column we looked at a Christian's duty to God as his stewards in actively engaging with the environmental crisis we currently face. The Bible is full of teachings that call upon Christians to fulfil their role and responsibility as caretakers or stewards to God, the rightful owner of the earth. Stewardship is a moral obligation and environmental destruction is the destruction of God's creation. Christian leaders worldwide have issued a clarion call to action, to hear God's call to protect and care for the earth. This week we will look briefly at what another major religion, Hinduism has to say about protecting the earth. In ecology, we often refer to the 'web of Life'. Interpreted broadly, in this view all of Earth's creatures are connected and our actions (direct or indirect) have consequences. This concept is captured beautifully by a Native American chief, Chief Seattle (1886) \"Whatever befalls the earth befalls the sons of the earth, all things are connected like the blood which unites one family. Man did not weave the web of life, he is merely a strand in it. Whatever he does to the web, he does to himself.\" This 'web of life' and the concept of interconnectedness is a foundational belief of Hinduism. Hindus believe that we are not separate from Nature. References to our interconnectedness and our relationship to Nature can be found in the Vedas, Upanishads, Gita, Puranas, the great epics such as the Ramayana and in the words of Hindu saints. Hindus believe that the Divine is everywhere. From this viewpoint, practising Hindus are true superheroes of the environment. Dr Pankaj Jain, Professor of South Asian Religions and Ecology says that though Hinduism is a diverse religion that has many manifestations at regional and local levels, there are several unifying themes. He explains that Hindus view the earth as the sacred Goddess Devi, who is worshipped and respected. Hindus believe in the concept of dharma or duty and karma. Karma is a central tenet in Hinduism that refers to consequences of our actions, both good and bad. These actions affect our future, including reincarnation. According to Jain, our duty includes our responsibility to care for the earth and our treatment of nature affects our karma. A morning prayer, eloquently expresses these concepts: Samudra Vasane Devi, Parvata Stana Mandale Vishnupatni Namastubhyam, Paada Sparsham Kshamasva me. Mother Earth, who has the ocean as clothes and mountains and forests on her body, Who is the wife of Lord Vishnu, I bow to you. Please forgive me for touching you with my feet. Another teaching that is fundamental to the Hindu religion is living a simple life. Scriptures speak about restraint from overconsumption and pursuit of material pleasures referred to as Sanyasa. Sanyasa can be thought of as a pathway to liberation or moksha. Dr. Jain points to simple living as a model for the development of sustainable economies where the earth is respected. As the great Mahatma Gandhi, who walked the pathway of simple living warned: \"Nature has enough for everyone's needs but not for everyone's greed.\" Hindus around the world have joined other religious bodies to engage with the global environmental crisis from a moral and spiritual perspective. As early as 1986, coming out of the Assisi Declarations on Nature, Hindu leaders joined in the call for action concerning the environment and espoused the role Hindus play in saving the environment. Presented in 2009 at the Parliament of the World's Religions, Melbourne, Australia, the \"Hindu Declaration on Climate Change,\" issued the following statements. \"The Hindu tradition understands that man is not separate from nature, that we are linked by spiritual, psychological and physical bonds with the elements around us. Knowing that the Divine is present everywhere and in all things, Hindus strive to do no harm. We hold a deep reverence for life and an awareness that the great forces of nature\u2014the earth, the water, the fire, the air and space\u2014as well as all the various orders of life, including plants and trees, forests and animals, are bound to each other within life's cosmic web. We cannot continue to destroy nature without also destroying ourselves. The dire problems besetting our world\u2014war, disease, poverty and hunger\u2014will all be magnified many fold by the predicted impacts of climate change.\" In Trinidad and Tobago, we are blessed with a rich Hindu heritage. How can Hindu's act as leaders, demonstrating a better way to live with each other and our natural world If you have an example of Hindus, individuals or groups, who are in touch with our natural world and are shining examples of environmental stewardship, please feel free to share your story with us. Dr Adana Mahase-Gibson is a project management professional and a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine. She works in the field of sustainable development with communities, government, businesses & NGOs in Trinidad and Tobago under the banner of Ecohealth. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/moonilal-diversity-is-our-strength/article_b65cd033-aa89-58bd-9cd6-4aee589544c5.html", "TITLE": " Moonilal: Diversity is our strength ", "DATE": "Oct 5, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "Minister of Housing and Urban Development Dr Roodal Moonilal says diversity goes beyond culture and it is not comprised of fences, including ideology and religion. He delivered the feature address at the First National Diversity Conference at Hyatt Regency Hotel, Wrightson Road, Port of Spain, on Friday. Moonilal was serving as acting Prime Minister while PM Kamla Persad-Bissessar was in Panama last week. The conference theme was Diversity is Inclusion...It is our common thread. The acting PM also thanked former minister of National Diversity Clifton De Couteau, who is now heading Gender, Youth and Child Development, for his contribution, and wished him a speedy recovery from a mild stroke he suffered recently. Among those present were Minister of National Diversity and Social Integration Rodger Samuel and Tertiary Education and Skills Training Minister Fazal Karim. Diversity presentations were made by University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) provost Fazal Ali, anthropologist Dr Dylan Kerrigan and Dr Fazadudin Hosein, vice-president for Spiritual Development, University of the Southern Caribbean (USC). Moonilal said the one-day conference was an opportunity for participants to stimulate the belief of Trinidad and Tobagos joint heritage and promote the objective that diversity must come alive and vibrant in schools, business places, communities and homes. Diversity must not be linked to our cultural diversity, it must go beyond. Diversity is genuine respect for all, a respect that must be borne out of education and understanding of who we are, what makes each of us different but unique, each of us with a role in building our nation, he said. Diversity is strength, strength in our collective difference. Diversity is opportunity, opportunities to discover the worlds that are literally around us, next to us and which, if we listen, could make each of us better citizens. Moonilal made reference to Prime Minister Persad-Bissessars comments at the United Nations General Assembly debate on Global Economic Development in New York on September 26, when she said: There are too many fences between us, fences of politics, ideology, religion, ethnicity and traditions. Such fences cannot be vaulted with respect for diversity. He also said the PM had sent her best wishes and requested the conference papers for future reading. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/vital-to-put-precious-t-t-first/article_b3ec5d07-79a7-59c8-bfc1-626d4dd5cbb4.html", "TITLE": " Vital to put precious T&T first ", "DATE": "Nov 9, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The big picture of Fazeer Mohammed's recent dismissal as host of First Up on CNMG is for me not about politics and power; it is about ignorance. We all know that there are many journalists who abuse their power and yet are quick to point out the State's abuse of power. This double-standard plagues our country and keeps us in a constant mire of Third World power plays where do so doh like so. I probably would not have bothered to comment had it been any of the many personalities passed off as talk-show hosts, but in the case of Mr Mohammed, whose intelligence and efficiency are obvious, I feel moved to speak up and show my understanding of the big picture. The clip that has been circulating shows not an interview nor a discussion but a battering of philosophies and principles. Religion and politics are kicked around like a football in a Soca Warriors game where no goals are scored and the only thing that happens is that the players come off muddy and tired. The danger here is the ignorance of the principles of Islam to which Mr Mohammed adheres. Mr Mohammed was put in the position of having to defend his philosophical beliefs and it may be interpreted that Mr Mohammed's Islamic beliefs were used as criteria to question his professional ethics and personal stance. There is nothing about this that can be deemed right. A man's religious and personal philosophies regarding how he makes sense of his life and his world are no other man's business to question. Equally important is the fact that in a country like ours it is so imperative to be mindful of how we treat with religious and cultural differences, especially when we have a public forum. Our misunderstanding of each other is based on ignorance; we simply do not know each other. When this ignorance is aired it is fuel for the radicals and the fanatics to build a bigger fire of hatred. We must all be responsible for ensuring that every creed and every race find an equal place here. This is the beauty of our island but it is also the bane if we do not understand it and know how to treat with it. Had the men in that clip understood the true importance of nation first, they could have used that opportunity to educate the public on the beauty of a country where differences in opinions and religious philosophies are lesser than the unification of a people. A Ministry of Multi-culturalism means nothing if we do not understand how to use multi-culturalism to forge patriotism. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/outrage-over-hindu-god-body-paint/article_1a7b4ed9-8b29-5c75-9e48-091a382e798c.html", "TITLE": " Outrage over Hindu God body paint ", "DATE": "Apr 19, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "An absolute outrage. This was the general view on social media by those who have viewed and shared images of a model with body paint depicting the Hindu incarnation of God known as Ganesha. What is this place coming too. Why didn't you put Jesus or Mary or Prophet Muhammad or Salassie just saying. No one God should be displayed on anyone skin especially for a season like carnival. It's disrespectful, sacrilegious and blasphemous. I feel strongly about this and I'm not even Hindu\u201d Another person wrote: \u201cI am not a Hindu but this is very disrespectful, inconsiderate and foolish. Respect each other religion\u201d. One person proudly spoke on the unity being spoken on the image where many of non-Hindu background expressed their concern of the Hindu image being presented for Carnival. There were those who questioned the reason for the outrage by others when Hindu religious symbols are tattooed onto the skin of many. One wrote: \u201cMany people have tattoos of the Om or whatever religious symbol you want to put in perspective, and have sex and what not. Why aren't they being penalized I agree it's degrading but there are others that do far worse\u201d. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/carmona-t-t-the-rainbow-nation-of-the-world/article_35fcce09-0830-53cc-864d-2c27d16e8fd6.html", "TITLE": " Carmona: T&T the rainbow nation of the world ", "DATE": "May 28, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "President Anthony Carmona has said the accomplishments and contributions to the national advancement of this Republic made by persons of Indian ancestry must neither be discounted nor understated but must be fully appreciated by us all. In his Indian Arrival Day message, Carmona said, From their humble beginnings as indentured labourers, trained to focus all industrial skills in the sugar industry, the East Indian population has taken those same industrial skills and have had them metamorphosed in the creation of an environment of defining competencies in the fields of medicine, law, engineering, entrepreneurial business, politics, culture, religion and sports. This has redounded to real benefits to our country, the Caribbean region and the world at large. Today, the Indian diaspora in Trinidad and Tobago and the Caribbean represents a vital and unrivalled thrust in world culture, education and politics. Against a background of extreme adversities, our Indian brothers and sisters have persevered and demonstrated that hard work, sacrifice and belief in God can trigger great rewards. The progressive response of the Trinidad and Tobago diaspora meshing other cultures with their art, music, cuisine and customs, have provided a fundamental platform for us being regarded as a rainbow nation. Throughout my life, I have always held a very close relationship with persons in my community and by extension the East Indian community. That relationship, very personal in many regards, has not swayed my fundamental belief in equality and just and fair treatment for all persons. In fact, I have been taught that fundamental and philosophy of life by many persons including gurus of Indian ancestry. As a United Nations prosecutor, I have had the unforgettable experience of being exposed to the horror that can result from intolerance and bigotry combined with ignorance and blinded aggression rooted in ethnic and religious differences both in the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda. Our forte as a nation is grounded in our harmonious and peaceful diversity and our racial and religious tolerance. We must therefore continue to guard this jealously. We must always be one with our Nation Anthem, Forged from the Love of Liberty and our national watchwords Discipline, Production and Tolerance, particularly Tolerance that speaks directly and positively to the harmony and appreciation of our religious and ethnical diversity. Today as we all unite to show appreciation and celebrate the arrival of our East Indian brothers and sisters, let us never forget that it is our ethnic, religious and cultural diversity that makes us the rainbow nation of the world. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/editorials/making-tolerance-real/article_d3ddf2b0-4111-11e8-9133-93a9c16ba6d8.html", "TITLE": " Making tolerance real ", "DATE": "Apr 15, 2018 ", "CONTENT": "For a country that has elevated the virtue of tolerance to the level of an official national watchword, the volume of intolerance since last week\u2019s verdict in the case of Jones vs the State is simply beyond comprehension. The cruel language and open ridicule of gay persons, combined with the reported evictions of homosexuals by families and landlords paint a reality far different from the tolerant, easy-going society which we proclaim ourselves to be to the world. This newspaper has been openly supportive of the judgment delivered by Justice Devindra Rampersad. It is consistent with our position that the State has no business legislating the sexual activity of consenting adults in the privacy of their various domains. While there is a place for the State in our lives, it is not inside the bedrooms of consenting adults. We recognise that our view is not shared by some religious persons and other individuals but respect their right to express their opinion and to practise the tenets of their faith. These are rights available to all, including gay persons, under the Constitution of Trinidad and Tobago. What is not acceptable is bigotry, zealotry and extremism from any quarter. Trinidad and Tobago is a secular state which guarantees not only the individual\u2019s freedom of \u201creligious belief and observance\u201d but \u201cfreedom of conscience\u201d, which may or may not involve religion. We claimed these rights in the aftermath of a brutal history of religious and political persecution of the vast majority of our people. More than most, Caribbean people know what it is to be deprived of rights, including the right to their humanity. Out of that past, we created new nation states that today stand on a bedrock of the very rights from which most people were once excluded. We are still far from perfect. The right of adults to love and to enjoy each other is not the only right that is still denied. The disabled suffer equally from the odious provisions of the Immigration Act which prohibit physically and mentally handicapped persons\u2013along with prostitutes and homosexuals\u2013from entering this country. As demonstrated in the case of the Child Marriage Act, the evolution of society requires ongoing review of attitudes and practices in the context of increasing respect and recognition of rights. Once upon a time, the right to kill the so-called infidel enjoyed sweeping religious sanction across a broad swathe of the planet. Today, such sanction is reviled, including by those who once upheld it. The challenge for secular states like Trinidad and Tobago which commit to freedom of religious belief and practice, is to balance the rights of the group with the rights of the individual. This is the delicate process that Justice Rampersad so carefully engaged in arriving at his judgment. As the Government prepares to pursue it to the end, we all have the right and responsibility to have our say. What we do not have is the right to abuse and humiliate another or to discriminate against them in attempting to impose our will. This is a moment to give real meaning to the national watchword of tolerance. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ramadharsingh-calls-for-baptist-museum/article_31318655-b4ae-5d21-9291-7cbf91640b2b.html", "TITLE": " Ramadharsingh calls for Baptist museum ", "DATE": "Mar 30, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "MINISTER of the People and Social Development Dr Glenn Ramadharsingh is encouraging members of the Spiritual Baptist community to support the establishment of a Baptist museum. The minister, who is also the Member of Parliament for Caroni Central, said because Spiritual Baptists struggled to get the right to express their religious beliefs, their history should be preserved. Ramadharsingh was speaking during Shouter Baptist Liberation Day celebrations at the Isaiah temple in Preysal last week. He said, \"Freedom comes with much struggle, preserve it for all eternity. Your struggle for freedom and recognition represents the epitome of human endurance and so you must now set about to document that struggle through the establishment of a Baptist Museum.\" In 1917, the Baptists were banned by law from practising their religion. Yet they continued practising their religion even if it meant hiding in the forests to do so. On March 30, 1951 the Legislative Council in this country passed a motion repealing the Act that had kept them in spiritual suppression. In the same year the Act was repealed and in subsequent years the Shouters held an annual celebration at Woodford Square, Port of Spain to mark the removal of the ban. Later they moved to the Jean Pierre Complex in the capital city. In 1996 former prime minster Basdeo Panday declared March 30 a public holiday and it was called Shouter Baptist Liberation Day. The Party may even be likened to a type of private 'Masonic Lodge, with all members being of equal status. The collective opposition parties operate like an antiquated system of castes. And there are 'castes' within the castes. These divisions are based on religion, complexion, financial security, self-importance and a host of other selfish personal considerations. These are all wrapped up in pride, envy and an inability to separate self from colonial type thinking. There is the rampant self-belief of Indo-Trinis that they are discriminated against, contrary to what is evident. Absolute evidence of great financial wealth and upward mobility in all spheres. Yet, there is a dangerous lack of self-confidence that should not exist. Why There is not supposed to be a \"Mother India\" or a \"Mother Africa\", but the ties to Mother India appear hardest from which to extricate oneself. Call it the ties that bind to a colonial past. The collective opposition, despite what they say, have no place in their caste system for the ordinary Trini man in the street. The popular vote remains with this voter whom you must convince that he is your equal and deserving of his vote.A shift in political power is not a likelihood for another twenty five years. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/reaffirm-the-role-of-spirituality/article_0d2233be-f291-5561-ad09-e5eb9fb692dd.html", "TITLE": " Reaffirm the role of spirituality ", "DATE": "Jan 13, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Despite his fundamentalist language, Government Minister and pastor Rodger Samuel has made an important contribution to the debate on crime. His literalist views on religion are not likely to win many adherents. However, his emphasis on God, God's law, and spirituality in general has direct relevance for our nation. It is precisely because we have become a secular society without all the institutions and values of a mature democratic society that we are in this mess today. We desperately need to re-invent a world view or common philosophy wherein we can all recognise our common humanity, civic duties, common needs and obligations to our nation. Most societies believe in some concept of God, some creation myth, some system of law and clear responsibilities to its people/citizens. Without a commitment to a religion, spirituality, legal system or philosophy, one's life is barren of meaning and one is adrift like straw in the wind. Those who condemn the idea of religion on the altar of a materialist science ignore the fact that science deals only with material entities and, thus, can neither prove nor disprove the existence of God, essentially a non-material entity. One cannot turn to science for love or compassion. What is vitally important to recognise is belief in a transcendent deity is a universal phenomenon. Whether you agree or not with such a belief is irrelevant. It is the effect of such a belief on the believer that is important. In its positive aspects, religious belief has given coherence and stability to society throughout the ages. It is at the basis of Western civilisation and western values, including democracy. Its negative aspect is reflected in earlier historical cruelties inflicted in the name of religion. Nevertheless, there is convincing empirical and anecdotal proof believers in all religions are generally happier, more serene, kinder, live longer and are more trustworthy than non-believers. Believers constitute the bedrock on which the structure of social norms, values and laws of their society is erected. That is why believers are less likely to be criminals than non-believers. Our criminals believe in nothing but greed, selfishness, cruelty, injustice and violence against their fellow citizens. They are rapidly destroying the moral fabric of our nation. They are like weeds grown in toxic soil without proper care or nutrition. Neuroscience tells us violent criminals usually possess a smaller and undeveloped neocortex\u2014the site of rationality, the only brain part that can restrain the violent impulses coming from another brain part, the amygdala. This latter responds to danger by the flight-or-fight syndrome. It has assisted the evolution of man by increasing his awareness to external danger. When we give way to anger and engage in fights or commit murder, we are being controlled by the amygdala. When we immediately withdraw into ourselves as a pattern of behaviour whenever faced with conflict, we are also being controlled. The appropriate response that would come from a functioning neocortex is to be reflective, objective, rational and moral in our behaviour. Neuroscience has pointed out violent criminals are generally brain damaged in some way. Brain damage, of course, cannot be used by criminals as a justification for their criminality. Pastor Samuel is correct to use the metaphors of Satan and satanic behaviour to describe their motivation, for their thoughts, values and actions all fall within the category of \"evil\". Simply put, murderers, especially gang killers, are evil and should be treated as such. We should not be tolerating the presence of gangs in our midst. We do not need them. They should be extirpated as quickly as possible. The Romans would have eliminated them immediately. The tragedy of T&T is that murder and acting out one's violent thoughts has become legitimate because our police forces are relatively inefficient because of educational deficits, poor training, lack of effective resources and inadequate leadership. It is comforting that a large section of our population is law abiding and kind, the consequence of believing in a God. We need to re-affirm the great importance of spirituality and religion for restoring and strengthening the moral fabric of our demoralised society and the lives of its citizens. It should begin in the home, addressed in the school, and emphasised by civic leaders. I refer to religion as any otherworldly view of life. I think of spirituality as a continuing search for ways to improve the moral quality of one's life. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/third-world-solution-to-first-world-problem/article_64c47487-abaf-5d1a-94cc-4a70bc8c6755.html", "TITLE": " Third World solution to First World problem ", "DATE": "Sep 21, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "I am writing this on September 11. Today marks 15 years since the attack on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon carried out by a group as close to evil and as far from the tenets of their religion as you could get. New York City shook and suffered the atrocities live on TV. Everyone in every country knew that the world would forever be changed. I have been to Ground Zero and it is both a nasty scar and a beautiful monument to the worst and the best of that dreadful day. Nine days later George W Bush addressed the nation in a speech that introduced the world to Al Qaeda. The president said, \u201cAl Qaeda is to terror what the mafia is to crime. But its goal is not making money; its goal is remaking the world\u2014and imposing its radical beliefs on people everywhere.\u201d While Bush tried to walk a tight line and not condemn all Muslims, collective emotions were understandably high and some very negative, xenophobic views of Islam were formed, and are sadly still held by many Americans today. Islam is seen by some as a primitive, stagnated and closed religion that calls for barbaric, deadly and disproportionate punishment such as the fatwa issued on Salman Rushdie for his book The Satanic Verses. The religion is viewed by many in the West as unrepentantly sexist and violent towards women, as well as supportive and protective of radical and violent acts done in its name. Countries where Sharia law is practised are viewed as alien theocracies that are actively adversarial to US interests. With those ill-conceived views about Islam flourishing in a post-9/11 world, it is easy to see how Islamophobia spread like a cancer across the US. It was present before 9/11, but after the twin towers collapsed many in the US were convinced war was a necessity to protect America's freedom from the terrors of Islam. In what would remain for me one of the greatest examples that there is always so much more right with America than there is wrong, a black man was elected president for two terms whose middle name was Hussein and whose father was Muslim. Nevertheless, 15 years later Islamophobia is so endemic and so almost mainstream that there is a presidential candidate who has made platform promises to impose a temporary ban on Muslims coming to the US\u2014as well as putting all American Muslims on a register, and he is supported by millions. Living in America over the past three years has been incredible; however, with the presidential election approaching, I've recognised fault lines I've never seen before. Every day, a perverted idea of Islam is highlighted in the media and there is a potential president who uses intimidation, xenophobia and Islamophobia to scare American voters. Usually the last place big countries look for answers regarding social justice, tolerance and integration issues is smaller countries like my Trinidad and Tobago. But the fact is we in T&T do social justice, tolerance and integration remarkably well. Trinis experienced a violent and bloody attack in the form of an attempted coup 26 years ago in which Parliament and then prime minister ANR Robinson and some of his MPs were held hostage. The hostilities and hostage stand-off ended after six days with the president giving amnesty to the leader of the Jamaat al Muslimeen and his armed insurgents. The body count was nowhere near that of 9/11 but the threat to our freedom and democracy was perhaps greater. The psychic damage done to the people of T&T was significant. People were angry and wanted justice, no different from post-9/11 America. It's easy to think that since this attack there would be permanent fault lines between Muslims and the rest of the country but I have come to the conclusion that Islamophobia simply doesn't exist in T&T. I can also say that when the media and other opinion shapers look back at the attempted coup the criticism and blame is confined to the leader and his followers, not their religion and the other nationals who practise it. How is it that tiny Trinidad and Tobago could provide an answer for an issue that has plagued some of the largest countries for decades T&T has more public holidays than the US and the majority are religious holidays. We celebrate Hindu, Muslim, Christian and Shouter Baptist holidays. We celebrate Indian Arrival Day as well as Emancipation Day. I grew up knowing about Eid-ul-Fitr and Christmas, Divali and Easter, celebrated freedom from slavery and the arrival of East Indian immigrants. The difference is we don't just celebrate different religions, we embrace them and all our Trini brothers and sisters who practise them. The fabric of Trinidadian society is a rich tapestry of values and traditions of so many different cultures and religions. The US has ten federal holidays a year. It might be hard for some to imagine states such as Arkansas, Alabama, Mississippi, Vermont or Texas learning much about Islam but I feel if Eid were a federal holiday the US would be closer to engaging Islam and ridding the US of Islamophobia. Exposure and education are the first steps taken towards tolerance and the US has yet to take baby steps to mainstream one of the world's great religions. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/our-journey-with-swami-vivekananda/article_792968df-8fd8-5e44-9ebb-2265b3fb9454.html", "TITLE": " Our journey with Swami Vivekananda ", "DATE": "Jan 26, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " Part 1 The journey referred to in the headline began on a much misunderstood and, may I say, maligned note. A general observation, made of all Hindu societies in the context of assessing the relevance of Swami Vivekananda and his Vedantic thoughts on the occasion of his 150th birth anniversary, was made light of. Since it all began with an Express reporter's inquisitiveness (January 5) as to what I meant exactly, let me clear the air by coming directly to the point. My reference to present-day Hinduism, a religion which, unlike any other, has surmounted the vicissitudes of time and come out stronger, must have had some strong points inherent in itself. That, in my view, is its philosophy which is universal, all-inclusive and embracing and that which appeals to and transcends all other religious beliefs. And that is Vedanta or Upanishads, the kernel of Hindu philosophy, for which India is known the world over and through the ages. My reference was also to a certain section of priests and pundits who, I feel, and in this I am joined by a good part of this country's intelligentsia and the younger generation, have led gullible masses with their superior knowledge in conducting rituals. I must make it clear that I have never decried rituals or belittled pundits. In fact my grandfather was a noted pundit (scholar) of his time and much of his scholarly inheritances have come down to me through my father, who was a pundit of no less renown. The fact that the organising committee of Swami Vivekananda's 150th birth anniversary celebrations was chaired by a pundit who is an extremely erudite, intelligent and articulate person of great merit, says it all. I have always believed, taking my inspiration from Swami Vivekananda, that every religion in the world has three essential components philosophy, mythology and rituals and each complements the others. It is therefore but logical that religion cannot neglect one for the others, otherwise the religion would risk decadence and decay. The same for Hinduism too, at the beginning of the 21st century, when it needs to be evaluated in the context of a rational and scientific environment and questions have to be answered instead of being swept under the carpet or the questioners being browbeaten under a cloak of arrogance and deceit. It is against this backdrop that Swami Vivekananda needs to be evaluated if we have to discuss the relevance of his message. And that we did, over six days of interaction with the Trinidad population through a diverse range of activities. Starting with an exhibition of books, pictures and posters and a pictorial depiction of Swamiji's life all resources brought from India we presented a cultural programme in the Bisram Gopie Auditorium of the Divali Nagar, sanctified by the presence of Swamiji himself with a serene bust of the master right at the entrance. It was a reminder of the celebrations at the same venue marking the centenary of the Swamji's address at the Chicago Parliament of Religions where, for the first time ever, the western world was exposed to the philosophy of Hinduism through the principles of Vedanta. And the Upanishads had found their greatest voice. Imbued with the teachings of his \"illiterate\" master, Sri Ramakrishna, a person seeped in the \"jnana\" (knowledge) of the ancient Shastras (spiritual texts), whom the great French savant Romain Rolland had described as the \"consummation of two thousand years of the spiritual life of three hundred million peoples\", the new message of the soul, the symphony of India, Swami Vivekananda had burst forth at the Chicago Parliament representing a universal religion, a religion with which each of the 3,000 delegates could identify. In all seven sessions that he addressed, Swamiji was the last to speak, lest people not walk out of the Parliament. Such was his arresting charm, his awesome personality. To him religion was a means to salvation through social service and serving the basic needs of the poorest, the \"Daridra Narayana\" (God's poor) and also to fill the spiritual vacuum of the material West with loftiest thoughts of the human mind. Here was a man who was admirably linking the East and the West through Hinduism, the mother of all religions, not through empty rituals. They had been shunned and relegated to the margins of a hackneyed ideology but the brilliance of Hinduism shone forth all over America and England by the time the Swami had finished his first pilgrimage to the West. His return to India was tumultuous as he addressed the multitudes in Colombo, Madras, Ramnad and countless other places in southern India with his stirring call, \"Arise, Awake and Stop not until the goal is reached\". This, then, was our motto the immortal verse of the Kathopanishad and artiste after artiste, young and old, sang, recited, danced and set to music the vibrations of those eternal words as the entire Bisram Gopie Auditorium at the Divali Nagar was moved to ecstasy. Two diferent people of different backgrounds... different religions. She a staunch Roman Catholic, a member of the media an event co-ordinator with the popular band TRIBE, very well known on the social circuit... and he a devout Muslim. But he was no ordnary Muslim; the son of Yasin Abu Bakr, the man who led for the 1990 coup. They began their courtship quietly, away from pryng eyes with only their closest associates, friends and family being privy to the knowledge that they had fallen in love. Some people chastised him for what he had done. To them he had chosen a worldly girl not of the Muslim faith. She also received her share of comdemnation for choosing to love the son of Abu Bakr. But both say they were having none of it. For all of those who feel love, the heart wants what it wants.... there is no denying it and so they said no to the naysayers and yes to love. They melded to each other solidyfying their union with their marital bond on October 17 before family and friends. The newlyweds appear to be happy, excited; but both agree that like all marriages they know their path would not be easy but it is a path they embarked on willingly and are prepared to walk together. Good luck to Kristy and Fuad on this new life-changing undertaking. It would be remiss of me if I didn't sincerely thank writer Lorraine Waldropt-Ferguson for the extra effort she put in while tracking this story. Thank you, Lorraine. Boodramsingh, a former champion apprentice congratulated Butcher on his achievement. Boodramsingh, last year\u0092s champion rider, is now two wins behind leader, Wilmer Galviz with the final raceday, the Boxing Day ten-race card, being the decider. \u0097Photo: DAVID WIGHT It was not the sort of scene that might appear on our prime time news channels. But the wonders of modern technology sometimes transmit the stark reality of the cruelty and barbarity of some contemporary human cultures. In one on-line English newspaper there was a brief video clip of a public daylight whipping of a woman by more than one policeman in Somalia. No details were ventured on the \"crime\" for which she was whipped. She was fully clothed in what I imagine to be an enforced dress code complete with head covering, ordered to sit on the ground surrounded by men, while two uniformed policemen took turns whipping her, not with canes but with long corded whip. The scene was interjected with her screams. As disgusting as the scene was the more abhorrent was the behaviour of the two policemen. When she defensively grabbed hold of the whip, another policeman emerged behind her with his whip and commenced whipping her across her back, both policemen cackling with laughter at her screams. The culture of the country, I suppose. The word \"culture\"it has so many meanings. The primary meaning however refers to the collective patterns of socially transmitted behaviour of human communities, including beliefs, languages, history, institutions, recreation, arts, science, commerce, laws and governance and so on. It must be noted, however, that cultures may differ markedly and often change. When one hears the word culture in the case of T&T it is more often understood to mean either entertainment of some form or folk and religious ways. But if we accept the primary meaning of the word we must accept that our culture must necessarily include many negatives. Compared with many T&T is supposedly highly corrupt, contemptuous of law, with disgusting road manners, cares little for the environment, littering and degrading, generating much noise and disorder, with most of our national institutions failing in their responsibilities to citizens. The one thing that continues to intrigue about our culture is the theme that Kevin Baldeosingh from time to time so patiently and clinically explains, the broad general correlation between religiosity and crime levels in different countries. For all the religiosity of T&T and the voluminous prayers that fly up to Heaven each day we continue to be a noisy, disordered, lawless, violent and crime-ridden society. We often continue to hear that we are a multicultural and multi-religious society, sometimes even with a sense of awe. On the other hand there is no doubt that cultures, including their subsets, can often bind peoples beneficially and support some measure of order, even as there may be strong divisions in that culture. At the same time there can hardly have any human culture where the process of binding does not involve some degree of coercion, in many cases extremely violent coercion. Religions may do it in different ways, some through the indoctrination from early childhood that may involve threats of one kind or another, or, through religious law that in some cases prescribes the death penalty for individual behaviours that would normally be ignored in other cultures. A Christian woman in Pakistan is sentenced to death for the \"crime\" of blasphemy the \"evidence\" being given by a group of Muslim women. Blasphemy is still on our law books as a criminal offence but is now ignored, whereas in Pakistan it may attract the death penalty as was recently reported. Perhaps some will note the irony of blasphemy being in some countries blasphemy against the dominant national religionin T&T against Christianity and in Pakistan against Islam. Perhaps some of the core values of the major religions may be shared, even by atheists and agnostics. These values however are few. It is when you get down to the broader customs, rituals and dictates of these that we see the divisive and exploitative methods of religions. It is not for a moment that I assume that religion or religions will disappear. But to survive in a more liberal world each religion or subset must use every possible device to maintain market share of the pool of available individuals, in some cases with promises and in others with repression. But can any Trinbagonian imagine living in a theocratic state and living under barbaric religious laws. T&T for all its faults is extremely lucky in that its governance has been in the traditions of the coloniser. We are what we are largely because of our history and culture that has been derived from western parliamentary systems that for the past few centuries have managed progressively to contain and diminish the powers of the Christian churches, with governments becoming progressively more secular. But even in some cultures as subsets continue to slaughter each other in the finest tradition of Christian religious violence of the past, now referred to as sectarian violence where Muslims slaughter Muslims, I imagine that some male Trinis might actually have enjoyed the public whipping of a woman. * Julian Kenny, chairman of the Environmental Management Authority, is a biologist and natural history author. He is a former UWI Professor of Zoology and Independent Senator. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/obeah-in-the-place/article_613d8cf9-fbde-5546-b5cd-9f02a8a414f9.html", "TITLE": " Obeah in the place ", "DATE": "Jan 19, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Breaking news this week was the arrest of a \"spiritual\" con man who was charged with a number of offences related to the scam he was running. These charlatans have always been around and prey on the insecurities of not only the most vulnerable in society, but also on the supposedly educated and worldly. The arrest brings to the forefront a deep mania in our populace and speaks to the culture and mindset of our country. Sometimes harmful, at others helpful, belief in the supernatural and all of the associated fetishes and rituals is ingrained in our culture and psyche. The very notion of what is obeah is problematic and reflects pervading norms of power. What is called obeah means different things to different groups and the dominant meaning of the word is assigned by the powerful in society. For instance, the rituals of the Spiritual Shouter Baptists who meld Indian, African and Christian culture were and, sadly, are still seen as obeah and evil by many in society. The same thing happens within groups. The practices of worshippers of the goddess Kali are sometimes called obeah and evil by other Hindus whose views are tainted by their own prejudices and the blindness of the leaders in their sects. At the risk of inviting controversy, I would ask: why is there a distinction drawn between obeah and religion Both seek to access supernatural power, both are practices by people professing to have some connection with or insight into the workings of the universe and forces outside the universe. Both lack any clear logic in their dogmas and both are rooted in tradition and rest on the faith of their adherents. To move away from the arrogant and dismissive way that obeah and the spiritual arts are written about by the self-professed educated, I offer instead a nuanced understanding of what is happening in our country. Lest we forget, the belief in the supernatural runs rampant in our society. Our last prime minister was rumoured to have consorted with a \"seer woman\" who just so happened not to have seen the landslide defeat at the polls for her patron. Numerous are the other reports of the political, educated and business classes consulting with obeah practitioners to achieve some aim. Why is there this strong belief in obeah and the supernatural, and what are the implications for our nation A cookie-cutter response would be our \"backwardness\" and the lack of education and learning in our country. This would be quite false. If it's one thing, we are not backward nor are we uneducated. Such an answer also fails to address the consulting of obeah people by the educated. One of the real reasons may be uncertainty. There is evidence in developmental scholarship that shattered expectations and uncertainty leads to a resurgence of, or increased fervour in religious convictions and beliefs. I offer this same reason for the pervading belief in obeah and magic in our society. We live in uncertain times. There is much fear and much anxiety in our country. Some may find solace in prayer and the rosary, while others may find comfort in knowing they spent $10,000 on a \"guard\" from the obeah man. Either way, these charms help to alleviate the anxiety of everyday living, especially in these turbulent times. More closely associated with our unique cultural history is the power of tradition and imagination. We may be speeding toward a tech-savvy condition where the youth are constantly chastised for losing values, but the stories told by nanny and grandpa still exist at the forefront of our minds. Legends and tales of la diablesse, lagahoo and soucoyant are part of all of our childhoods. Whispers of the girl ghost at Claxton Bay or the dealings with bucks by the business class have enriched our folklore for generations and are still around today. These stories form powerful parts of our national psyche and though we may embrace the way of logic, technology and science, we never completely rid ourselves of them. The problem arises, however, when these beliefs are abused and come to hinder good judgment. In the case of con men and professed healers, there is much more at stake than money. While it is terrible for people to be scammed out of their money, what is even more pressing is when they are led to do things that are detrimental to their well-being. The obvious and saddening case is the disgusting advice by these charlatans to people to stop taking medication and instead use herbs or trust in some sort of magic. There is great worry in Africa and in other places where \"bush doctors\" have stopped people from taking anti-retroviral drugs for HIV. This has lead to death and the spreading of the disease by many deluded believers. The same has occurred in Trinidad and Tobago and will continue to occur. In these instances, the culprits should be charged with manslaughter since they are directly responsible for deaths. Appropriate legislation should be drawn up to deal with such types. Belief in the supernatural may seem illogical, but the world would be a more boring place without it. Trinidad and Tobago has a unique culture and, instead of trying to suppress it, we should embrace it, but always understanding these are simply tales and stories that make the world much more interesting. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/question-and-challenge-authority/article_bf981097-05de-5a15-afa1-92f13913b649.html", "TITLE": " Question and challenge authority ", "DATE": "Jun 14, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "There is a disturbing culture of deference and servility towards authority religion, in particular in this country that needs to be addressed. There is a strong tendency to not offend or criticise religious institutions or beliefs and this constrains the public conversation on issues such as homosexuality and abortion. Individuals largely lack the conviction to abandon the tenets taught to them as children and the few dissenters that crop up are laughed off and told to \"Lighten up!\" or \"Calm down!\". I politely decline both offers. The ethos of mysticism and credulity in the populace has lead to a stunted Intelligentsia and has wormed its way into the Government. The disdain towards academia has led to mass scientific illiteracy and our culture is the poorer for it. I do not wish to express antagonism towards any devout or pious member of any faith. That would be impertinent and wrong of me. What concerns me, however, is the eagerness to \"be a part\" and the willingness to be indoctrinated. It is a culture of blind, unquestioning faith in what you're told in which scepticism is discouraged and dissent feared. In the recent public discussion on homosexuality (which I think could not have come up soon enough), the religious are quick to invoke the \"word\" of their supernatural authority as if it has any place in a civil rights conversation. They recycle facetious non-arguments and unscientific babble from decades ago, most if not all of it borrowed from the religious right in the US. They would be funny if only anyone was willing to laugh. So, what to do Here's my advice, for lack of a less condescending term, to those involved. To religious leaders: You are fully entitled to have your beliefs, to worship your deity/ies and to find salvation in whatever form you choose. But recognise that yours is not the only belief. Do not, for one second, presume to tell people how to live their lives. Recognise that your holy book(s) gives you absolutely no authority moral or otherwise over anyone, and especially over those who do not subscribe to your beliefs. Recognise that yours is a personal faith and as such, while it is your right to have it, it is to have no influence in government, scientific inquiry or human rights affairs. To the followers/congregations: Resist the urge to be a sheep. Take the risk of thinking for yourself. Do not allow what is screamed from the pulpit to sway your own morality and make you believe archaic, hateful nonsense. Learn to embrace the plurality and nuance of the world and let go of any conceptions of Utopia. You might say, \"But my beliefs give me hope, comfort,\" etc. Fine for you. But for the sake of all that is good, try to come out of your comfort zone. Teach yourself to be suspicious and critical of authority in whatever form it takes and stop following the crowds. To the politicians: Your job is to listen to the people all of them not to a higher power only you can see. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/columnists/consider-the-golden-rule/article_dbf92976-b71a-11e9-beb4-fb6b39bdd8f1.html", "TITLE": " Consider the golden rule ", "DATE": "Aug 4, 2019 ", "CONTENT": "LEADING THE WAY: Rev Charles Jason Gordon leads a procession yesterday into the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Port of Spain where he was installed as Archbishop. \u2013Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY LEADING THE WAY: Rev Charles Jason Gordon leads a procession yesterday into the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Port of Spain where he was installed as Archbishop. \u2013Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY I have asked that every Catholic participate in the 40 days of prayer for our nation hosted by Emmanuel Community. This prayer is respect for life in our nation. As you know, this is what I believe to be the fundamental root challenge that is facing us\u2014a culture of disrespect which is all-pervasive. The root of this challenge is spiritual. All the major religions observe the golden rule\u2014do unto others as you would have them do unto you. This golden thread runs through all the major religions, and binds humanity together in an interdependent ecosystem. My good is dependent upon the good of others. My growth is dependent on the growth of others. My flourishing is dependent upon the flourishing of others. This fundamental spiritual law is the basic foundation for humanity. Without this foundation, we cannot build a sustainable civilisation where people flourish. This is the deep challenge facing Trinidad and Tobago today. We want to flourish without ensuring all others flourish. It cannot happen! Rugged individualism with its exaggerated push for human freedom has taken us to the brink of the precipice. At this existential edge of human decency, we now have very difficult decisions to make. What type of civilisation do we want to build in Trinidad and Tobago? What type of people do we want to become? Looking at the golden rule it seems very simple\u2014do unto others as you would have them do unto you. It may even seem self-interested. At its heart, it is being other-focused. If you want a good life you need to limit your freedoms. You need to treat others as you want to be treated. You need to ensure others have what you dream for and aspire towards. You need to ensure all citizens in our nation have access to the dreams and aspirations that you have. You need to live exaggerated responsibility. It is from this understanding that we begin to understand the root of our interconnectedness. Here in the Catholic tradition we speak about the common good, the good that we must all seek and work for if we are all to flourish. The group 3Canal captured this in \u201cGood Morning, Neighbour\u201d. They say: \u201cI have a little remedy, a guaranteed philosophy to make this a better place, healing for the human race\u201d. Their remedy is for us to be neighbourly to each other, to acknowledge each other as human beings, and to engage each other and recognise the humanity and dignity of the other. In South Africa they say ubuntu. Generally, it means humanity. It is translated, \u201cI am because you are.\u201d This lays the foundation for building a civilisation. The building blocks are not pitch, oil or concrete and steel. It is the quality of relationships among citizens. It is the interdependence that we understand in our striving for excellence and growth. My existence and happiness are dependent upon yours. This is a different foundation from our current foundation in Trinidad and Tobago. There is a Yoruba proverb that says: \u201cOne who is going to take a pointed stick to pinch a baby bird should first try it on himself to feel how it hurts.\u201d Placed in the negative it puts forward the point very well. Your actions to others should be tested on yourself first. In Hinduism the text from the Taittiriya Upanishad, reads: \u201cThose acts that you consider good when done to you, do those to others, none else\u201d (Shikshavalli, Eleventh Anuvaka). We go after \u201cwhat we can get\u201d, or rather \u201cwhat\u2019s in it for me\u201d (WIIFM). We put the \u2018I\u2019 and the needs and desires of the self at centre. This putting self at centre is opposed to all religious traditions, and thus opposed to all ways of being in relationship with God. Trinidad and Tobago is a multi-ethnic, multi-religious community. Our largest traditions are Christianity, Hinduism and Islam. We have many other traditions also that make up this incredible place. We also have humanists and atheists in our land who do not believe in God but we all share a common humanity. We all occupy the 5,131 km2. We need to understand that my happiness is dependent upon your happiness. I want to ask every citizen to consider the golden rule. The fact that the golden rule transcends culture, religions and belief, suggests it is a moral code written into the fabric of who we are\u2014our DNA. By definition, prayer turns us outwards after leading us inward, away from our self towards the Other: the wholly Other, God! By this turn of mind and consciousness, we create a new foundation for our entire being. I am not the foundation of my being. I did not bring myself into being, I am not the origin, and I am not the end. There is one who is greater than me who brought everything into being. I am surrendering to this One. I seek communion with this One. I want to know, love and serve this One. By turning from self, we change the basic proposition of our national consciousness. It is no longer about \u2018me\u2019. It is about God! This is the first step in our religious conversion. ", "DATE": "Apr 1, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "HAPPY BIRTHDAY!: Keshorn Walcott prepares to unleash one of his big throws in the Falcon Games men's javelin event, at the Hasely Crawford Stadium in Port of Spain, yesterday. Walcott, who turns 19 today, won with a 77.53 metres effort--a new Central American and Caribbean (CAC) junior (under-20) record. Photo courtesy PAUL VOISIN HAPPY BIRTHDAY!: Keshorn Walcott prepares to unleash one of his big throws in the Falcon Games men's javelin event, at the Hasely Crawford Stadium in Port of Spain, yesterday. Walcott, who turns 19 today, won with a 77.53 metres effort--a new Central American and Caribbean (CAC) junior (under-20) record. Photo courtesy PAUL VOISIN At the outset, allow me to congratulate the members of the Spiritual Baptist community on the celebration of the 60th Anniversary of the Proscription of the Shouters Prohibition Ordinance and the 15th Anniversary of the national celebration. You have done well over these years, to keep alive the triumph of the pioneers who struggled to see the enactment of an Act which would give substance to the words of our National Anthem which declare that \"every creed and race find an equal place\". Until then, a substantial number of citizens, being members of your faith, were debarred from exercising the right of freedom of worship which is enshrined in our Constitution. So the repeal of the Ordinance on 30th March 1951was indeed a landmark ruling, giving substance, as it does, to that aspect of our Constitution. It is a matter of record, both oral and written, that Shouter Baptist women played a significant role in the battle for equality of treatment, in relation to other religions. This should come as no surprise, as in secular matters, women have made their presence felt. Even during the infamous World Wars, women quickly took their places in the war effort, if not at the front, in factories and in the care of the wounded. Earlier this month, Trinidad and Tobago participated in the worldwide celebration of International Women's Day and so it is timely and fitting that the theme of the National Evangelical Spiritual Baptists celebration is \"Women in the Shouter Baptist faith\". The world is increasingly paying attention to the condition of women - at one end, our hopes, accomplishments, exploits and at the other, our subordination, situations of exploitation based on gender, as well as the deliberate disadvantage at which some of us are placed, as a direct result of traditions and customs which dictate the pace. But with respect to the latter, one has to be very cautious about disturbing what may be regarded as the natural order, given the societies in which those traditions and customs are in place. Wisdom must prevail in the strategies that are in place or contemplated. Apart from the general context of man/woman relationship as evolved in Trinidad and Tobago, there have been, in religious circles, certain parameters that have tended to define the role and place of women. But this is changing to some extent and women are becoming more visible in positions of leadership in traditional religions as the ordination of women to the priesthood has increased. In the Spiritual Baptist faith, you have taken the lead, a clear lead, in that, for many years, you have been ordaining women to the rank of Bishop and Archbishop, a position yet to be adopted in some of the older religious denominations. But it is a place that the women of your faith have earned, if such a word is appropriate. It is a place which is not based solely on manifest spiritual growth. I would think that your women's role in the struggle for emancipation of the faith had a secular dimension in that, like Lydia, Chloe, Damaris, who clung to her faith in spite of ridicule and Priscilla in the early Christian Church, who all ministered to the temporal needs of the members, so that the message could be spread, Spiritual Baptist women did the same. And then there was Deborah, the warrior prophetess, agitator and judge who defended her nation against the enemy of the day, much as the women in St Vincent did battle for their beliefs and were arrested and imprisoned. It is also recorded that, in Trinidad and Tobago, Caroline French opened her home to the 14 protesters, 12 of them women, who resisted the Shouters Prohibition Ordinance and were arrested on 17th December, 1917. I am quite certain that these are only two of many stories that can be told regarding the campaign of women in the Shouter Baptist faith. Instances such as these give historical validity to the places of honour that have been given to women of the faith and should be a guidepost for succeeding generations, in pursuit of their own places in the hierarchical order of things. In all of the strivings, though, one must bear in mind and keep always at the forefront of one's thinking, that there are two dimensions to be considered - the spiritual and the secular. Recognising that there remain certain traditional attitudes towards women, which some of us are reluctant to face, one must guard against bringing into an environment shaped by religion in this case, the Shouter Baptist religion an over-zealous feminist thrust. Lest I be misunderstood, let me assure you that I am well aware of some of the obstacles that women face, simply on the grounds of gender. Nevertheless, I believe that while we have all been created equal, there is some validity in the view held by quite a number of persons, that there are some roles that are specific to men and others to women. We must be careful, therefore, that in securing the understanding among women as among men, that we have equal value, we do not overturn the responsibilities as suggested in the beginning, that is to say, in creation history, to such a degree, that chaos takes the place of order. Sometimes, there is a fine line between what is acceptable and what is not. What is important is that, as we evolve and take our places, truly side by side, this does not result in loss of dignity and of mutual respect, for anyone. I have confidence in our women, to continue to assume leadership roles in religion as in areas of secular activities. I have confidence also that, within the Shouter Baptist faith, you are capable of securing accommodations among yourselves that will enable you to continue to assume leadership roles with sensitivity and with proper focus... (NAPS) \u201cDeep Conviction: True Stories of Ordinary Americans Fighting for the Freedom to Live Their Beliefs\u201d has been called a fascinating and thought-provoking new book. (NAPS) (NAPSI)\u2014What would you do if your most strongly held beliefs were challenged by the government, placing your livelihood, your way of life and even your freedom at risk? You may find inspiration for your answer in a new book about four Americans\u2014a priest, an atheist, a Native American and a baker\u2014who put it all on the line for their creeds. The Book \u201cDeep Conviction: True Stories of Ordinary Americans Fighting for the Freedom to Live Their Beliefs\u201d (Shadow Mountain) is by professor and lawyer Steven T. Collis. An advocate and a scholar, he believes religious freedom is \u201ca fundamental liberty protecting all individuals living in this country, allowing us to exist in relative peace with one another.\u201d This peace, he adds, is unique in history and exceptional even in the world today. Collis notes, \u201cReligion is not what leads us to battle, it\u2019s the lack of religious liberty.\u201d The book offers insights into religious liberty through the stories of four ordinary Americans who risked their reputations to preserve and live their personal beliefs. Although vastly different in many ways, they share such qualities as conviction and determination. The Courageous Four \u2022 In 1813, a Catholic priest in New York City faced prison after a grand jury subpoenaed him for refusing to divulge the identity of a jewelry thief who admitted to the crime during the sacrament of confession. \u2022 In 1959, an atheist in Maryland was forced to stand up for his beliefs when the state required him to sign an oath that said he believed in God before he could work as a notary public. The United States Supreme Court would decide his fate. \u2022 In 1989, a Klamath Indian man walked into the highest court of the nation to fight for the right to practice the central sacrament of the Native American Church after the state of Oregon had declared it illegal. \u2022 And, finally, in 2017, a Christian baker and a gay couple took their cases to the United States Supreme Court after the baker declined to create a custom wedding cake to celebrate the couple\u2019s same-sex marriage, fearing it would violate his duty to God. Written with the pace of a novel, Collis\u2019 book brings these stories to life in a way that reflects their universality and the broad principles they represent. He stresses how the notion of religious freedom for all, truly cherished, allows justice and protection for everyone, religious or not. Learn More For further facts and to get the book, visit www.ShadowMountain.com. \u201c\u201cDeep Conviction: True Stories of Ordinary Americans Fighting for the Freedom to Live Their Beliefs\u201d (Shadow Mountain) by Steven T. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/hajj-pilgrims-getting-a-raw-deal/article_96b08e2c-bebb-557f-8b13-f75a5c4ba4f9.html", "TITLE": " Hajj pilgrims getting a raw deal ", "DATE": "May 29, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " THE promise of religion is sure we will all one day die, leave this world and then be accountable to Almighty God (Muslims and Arabic tongues say Allah), and we as Muslims and most of the wider society do believe in this promise, don't we Hajj is sacred and is a major part of the Islamic faith. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-are-not-a-theocracy/article_8c45951d-68f8-5e1a-8d21-d65a4e6b6639.html", "TITLE": " We are not a theocracy ", "DATE": "Nov 9, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "In the interest of the people of Trinidad and Tobago, the zealous fervour of the religious movement opposing basic human rights and changes to outdated laws has to be counteracted. For some reason, the so-called religious leaders of our nation have taken it upon themselves to paint their followers as a band of dogmatic robots who are incapable of thinking. The so-called leaders of the major religions are nothing more than overdone caricatures and trilobites who do not represent their constituents and are doing more harm than good. Most of the people who belong to a religion are quite happy to live and let live, are apathetic to many issues that seem to set their leaders on fire and are in favour of progressive legislation and modernity. These leaders and, sadly, a few other vociferous minorities need to keep in mind that the state of Trinidad and Tobago is a secular republic with a strong constitution guarding the separation of church and state. Far be it for me or for anyone else to deny any person or group the right to belief and practice of religion. The right to religious freedom is enshrined in our constitution and I believe this is a positive thing, as it shows that we, as a nation, are able to respect others and co-exist despite our religious differences. The place of religion, however, is in the church/ temple/mosque, etc. Religion and religious leaders need to take care of the moral and spiritual souls of their flock and leave the business of public policy to the State. The laws of the secular Republic of Trinidad and Tobago need to be formulated, debated and passed by the legislature for the benefit of the nation. During formal public consultations, religious groups as well as other stakeholders have the right to make their positions known. It will be up to the State to balance the interests of all stakeholders and do what is best for the nation. At the end of the day, however, the religious need to respect the secular composition of our nation. It is under these guiding principles that our multifaceted nation can continue to flourish and function in peace. No religious group should have the ability to influence the State as this will undoubtedly lead to anarchy. It would be myopic and naive of me to believe that there is no religion in law. The basis of our constitution is Judeo-Christian and most of it is still based on these world views, with a few local tweaks here and there. The problem with this, however, is that Judeo-Christian and secular thought have progressed tremendously since 1962 and yet, as the world marches on, our constitution is stuck in the past. The few attempts that have been made to write the wrongs of these archaic laws have been fiercely resisted by the leaders of the religious organisations. They argue that the changes are a secular attack on the religious, but I challenge these fig leaves and postulate that they are defending the status quo where they are in positions of power and where they are free to discriminate at their fancy. They are like the clergy of the Dark Ages who rejected the Enlightenment and, in last-ditch efforts to stave off the march of progress, cried of doom and destruction. The predictions of the \"Dark Agers\" never came to pass and man began to flourish even more and so too will the hollow refrains of the ridiculous religious fall to nothing. Too often during debates on issues such as gay rights, the right to abortions and for contraception, we have people use the Bible, Hindu scriptures or the Qur'an as some form of basis for not granting these rights. It is necessary to point out that it is legal to hold these views, but these books and their postulations are not acceptable as legal justification for any law. Quite frankly, it is ludicrous that people will rage against any issue by using religion since there is no proof for religious dogma, as it is based completely on faith. It is also curious that those who seek to pressure policy to be based on religious doctrine have never thought out how dangerous this is for their own movement. A simple case will illustrate this; if law and policy were to be written on religious grounds, then should one religion gain prominence, say Hinduism Then if laws are written based on their tenets, the Muslims and Christians can bid goodbye to beef and Halal. It is then in the interest of all religions to be governed by a secular state. The rise of radical Islam in Iran and the subsequent brutal suppression of other religions, such as Christians, Sufi Islam and the Baha'i, show just how dangerous it is to live under a theocracy. I hope by now my point is becoming clear; this is not an attack on religion nor is it the ranting of a militant secularist. Instead, it is an appeal to some religious movements to allow the State to do its job, to allow the State to seek the interest of the people and the minorities who may not fall into the fold of the religious movement. There is a place for everyone in a secular state, a place for the religious, for the agnostics/atheists, for the GLBT movement, for the charities and for open discussion. Within the secular state, all can thrive and be protected and have rights; the protection and rights of one group does not erase or infringe on another. The world has changed and humanity has progressed; we are simply all one people of different ideals and ideologies but, at the end of the day, we are all human. The reign of religion and theology is over, the secular state is the vehicle of our progression and all are welcome. Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal in 2006 for business/modern studies.
