{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-tragedy-of-blind-faithreligion-and-politics/article_b09ba719-dd3e-5943-8ac5-598f2aa5f6f0.html", "TITLE": " The tragedy of blind faithreligion and politics ", "DATE": "Jun 6, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " Faith is belief without evidence, or trust without logic. Far from being the sole domain of religion, blind faith is spreading in Trinidad and Tobago at a worrying pace. People are choosing to place their utter and absolute faith in politicians, religion, norms and education without thinking for themselves. Blind faith threatens to undermine our entire development project as it retards the development of the mind. Without freedom from mental slavery and blind belief, all of our money, resources and infrastructure will not deliver to us the future we hope for. It may seem odd to some that in this day of open technology, easily accessible information and more aware citizenry that I am writing about blind faith. We have to look just below the surface to see that beyond this facade of modernity, our society is festering with blind faith. Citizens who appear to be worldly or wise are, in fact, zombies without critical logic or minds of their own. We are facing an epidemic like no other, an epidemic which has swept though places like Saudi Arabia, Nigeria and even the USA, to some degree. When I speak of blind faith, I am referring to the inability of our people to think critically and to question. In the face of glaring logical evidence, facts and figures, our citizens choose to turn a blind eye and continue to believe the falsehoods they have always clung to. Logical enquiry and empirics are only one part of thinking critically, the other is questioning, understanding and rejecting or accepting. For instance, all three major religions have customs and rituals that are followed on special occasions or as everyday routines. There are thousands of citizens who observe these rituals without knowing what they are doing or why they are doing it. Very few will question their religious leaders, and most times, even the so-called \"religious elite\" have no idea what they are doing. They will allude to custom and tradition, but custom and tradition also included slavery and human sacrifice, which we have rejected, so that is definitely not a good reason. Religion, it seems, is an easy target for those who would seek to highlight blind faith; in some ways, it is too easy and not the institutions that we should be concentrating on most, though it warrants investigation. Instead, I am seeking, in addition to religion, to focus on politics, education and norms. The ability to question, to think, to analyse and to reject is not an academic project that is only to be taught in school. It is a cultural ethic that stems from history, family and society. Our country has gone from a period of heightened awareness in the 1970s and early 1980s to a completely myopic and blind nation in the current age. Political awareness has sunk to new lows, and engagement in political affairs is continuing to decline. Far from only young people being unaware of politics, which has been observed across the world, the general population of T&T is not aware of what is going on. Lack of political awareness however pales in comparison to the blind faith that party supporters put in their leaders and their party. In Trinidad and Tobago, over the past 15 years, there has not been an election on issues such as economics, environment, freedom, trade, etc. It has always been about scandal, fete and, recently, crime. Citizens couldn't care less about issues, instead, they vote for their ethnic party or party of tradition. Despite the glaringly obvious pitiful state of parties, candidates or leaders, people continue to trust and support them. Laventille East and Caroni Central have been utterly neglected by their respective parties, but come election time, these two seats remain very safe by wide margins. This is just one example of how people are trapped when they place blind faith in parties. The harm and hurt affects only the people and not the political class. The neglect of these two seats and others will continue across the country as long as people trust blindly and do not demand better and ensure they get better. This may not be that they need to switch allegiances but rather they should seek to transform their parties of choice to properly represent their interest. The other sad state of blind faith is to be found in religion. Not faith as the belief in a supreme being or \"god\" but rather faith in doctrines and customs to the detriment of their own selves or our country. I begrudge no one belief in religion; I support religious freedom, tolerance and defend people's right to believe as they so see fit. What I cannot condone, however, is the blind faith that people put not in their religion or texts but in their leaders and man-written doctrines. Many believers in religion have not read their own religious texts; this is an accepted statement backed by proper research. Instead, the faithful rely on religious leaders to distill texts and \"educate\" them. Often, these same leaders have no idea what they are talking about and engage in behaviours their own religion finds deplorable. \"Judge not lest ye be judged,\" is a resounding theme across our three major religions, yet one has to only pick up a newspaper, look at television or listen to radio to hear an avalanche of judgment on all sorts of issues. Humility, love and kindness are also recurring themes, yet many religious leaders live in mansions while their congregations dwell in shacks, but once again, people accept and do not question. Let me make clear again; I have no problem with religion, what I have an issue with is religious hypocrisy and, more so, the blind thrust of the masses in these charlatans. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/breaking-dress-codes/article_da6d909b-714a-5f6c-bcd1-b75072193b75.html", "TITLE": " Breaking dress codes ", "DATE": "Aug 7, 2009 ", "CONTENT": " HUMANS are not particularly well adapted to the wide range of temperatures on earth and as a result of the spreading out from our origins in eastern Africa many hundreds of thousands of years ago, we have had to adopt body coverings of some kind for protection, certainly against the elements and against physical damage to parts of the body. Today most organised societies have developed kinds or modes of clothing, employing a wide range of materials of natural and, more recently, synthetic origin. But while clothes have also in their evolution assumed deep cultural significance, norms of dress in many societies have changed over time. Yet many dress rules and traditions have been retained as they relate to a wide range of human activities including religion and the professions. Some societies such as ours often adopt the modes of dress of other cultures to give some sort of solemnity to special occasions. When our Parliament convenes for the first time the House Speaker and the Senate President are formally robed and bewigged, a ritual going back a few centuries in the United Kingdom. When we attend our places of worship everyone seems to know what is expected. When pre-school infants \"graduate\" they are usually dressed in colourful approximations of the mortar board and gown that date back to medieval times in Europe. Our culture seems to accept slowly changing norms as to what is appropriate attire and behaviour for the time, event or place but many would be shocked to read that a 40-year-old professional woman is being tried for wearing \"indecent clothing\"trousersat a coffee shop in Khartoum, the capital of Sudan. She faces the prospect of 40 strokes if convicted! Had she walked the streets of Port of Spain she would hardly have been noticed amongst the great diversity of styles to be seen. Yes, it is true that there is a broad spectrum of what might be said to be Muslim dress to be seen in many parts of the world today. But at the same time there is no doubt that many members of that faith do not necessarily feel absolutely bound by dictates or conventions. Indeed, one can see across the entire Islamic world great diversity of dress, from places as far apart as Turkey and Indonesia. Religions have been an integral part of the evolution of societies and a powerful binding force, much of this through their core beliefs. But religions also reflect customs and laws of peoples, customs and laws that may have been appropriate for other, older times. In this unstable world of competing interests, conservatism continues as a force in all societieseven oursand extreme elements or groups often violently intervene in the hope of imposing their values, hence the upsurge in diverse societies such as Nigeria, Sudan and Iran. Liberalism and secularism can be a potent force. But even in highly secular societies laws and customs change, with ensuing tensions and collisions. How these are to be resolved is the ongoing question. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/comparative-religion/article_8fc57085-0a8c-5804-ba6a-f8efd33a5473.html", "TITLE": " Comparative Religion ", "DATE": "Sep 28, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " In one of my earliest articles in the Express (May 29, 2002) I wrote on the need for the teaching of Comparative Religion in our schools. I argued that as Trinidad and Tobago is a multicultural and multi-religious society in order for there to be harmony among our diverse peoples, it is necessary that we understand the philosophies and mores of each other, for ignorance breeds fear and mistrust. However, while we treat with some of the cultural differences in the curriculum in our schools, no fundamental instruction in each other's religious beliefs is given. Many of our young people do not appreciate the moral values held by our diverse faiths. I returned to this subject two years later in a series on reform of the education system (Express, December 2, 2004) and I then wrote: \"I will quote from a communication I received from a teacher of this subject in a secondary school in the United Kingdom. \"There are two possible pitfalls in a multicultural society: the one is to take the liberal view that 'all religions are fundamentally from the same source'. This denies integrity to members of a number of religions for whom commitment means a rejection of this notion. The other is to believe that there is no possible benefit from communication between human beings whose world views are fundamentally incompatible. This is clearly a recipe for social discord. For me the classroom is a microcosm of society, and in RE (Religious Education) lessons we try to establish a 'community of enquiry' into a number of world views, particularly religious ones, in order to test truth claims and give pupils the skills needed either to affirm already held beliefs or to search for themselves. It works because in such a community they are taught that relationships are more important than winning arguments, and being reasonable therefore means more than being rational. Sometimes people just have to agree to disagree, but can still show respect. This is not the same as accepting things which are against your belief, but it is acknowledging another person's right to choose, and your own responsibility to live in peace wherever possible.\" Religious Education and Civics (Citizenship) are compulsory subjects in the UK. How many of us in this country have good knowledge of each other's religious beliefs or a good knowledge of governance It was therefore with great interest that I learned of an initiative by the Trinidad and Tobago National Commission for UNESCO to mount a symposium and a workshop on Comparative Religion. The proposal for this initiative states in part that it is informed by a concern that, given the multicultural context of Trinidad and Tobago, and the apparent disintegration of peace and tolerance in the society, formal and non-formal education must facilitate not only an appreciation of cultural diversity but also of the diversity of religious beliefs. Further, such education must also foster recognition of the moral values held by our diverse faiths. It must engage our young people in the contemplation of a deeper meaning of life, in an understanding of the varied religious perspectives and it must support their spiritual development. The proposal further states that the Government envisages a society in which the diversity and creativity of all its people are valued and nurtured. The introduction of Comparative Religion in the school system offers one means of achieving this goal. This will require development of curricula and training of teachers. The objectives of the proposed introduction of Comparative Religion are to: 1.Develop respect for other religions, while remaining strong in one's own belief systems (which include atheism and agnosticism); 2.Expose students to different competing religious philosophies so as to foster tolerance and peaceful co-existence; 3.Promote a better appreciation of the tenets of other religious faiths and facilitate an understanding of the similarities among religions, for example similarity of moral issues; 4.Gather data and build consensus. A workshop will be held next week (October 5 and 6) for teachers and representatives of religious bodies at the Rudranath Capildeo Learning Resource Centre, Couva. The theme of the Workshop is: \"Harmony in diversity: Towards best practice for teaching World Religions\". On the first day the Keynote address will be given by Professor Anantanand Rambachan on the topic: \"International trends/current practices in teaching Comparative Religion: Impact and effectiveness of this teaching\". This will be followed by a Group discussion on the topic: Perspectives on approaching Comparative Religion in schools in Trinidad and Tobago. On the second day the Keynote address will be by Mrs. Grace Peart, Curriculum Officer, Jamaica on the topic : Curriculum Development and Implementation for Comparative Religion in Jamaica: A case study. TThis will be followed by an Open Forum on Curriculum Development and implementation for Comparative Religion. A Panel of Resource Persons will lead the discussion. Panelists: Grace Peart, Prof Anantanand Rambachan, Dr. Nasser Mustapha and Dr. Rev. Hazel Ann Gibbs De Peza. It is my expectation that the output from this Workshop will make a significant contribution to curriculum reform in our education system. Further information on the workshop may be obtained from the Secretariat of the Trinidad and Tobago National Commission for UNESCO, telephone number: 622 0939. John Spence is Professor Emeritus, UWI. He also served as an Independent Senator. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/features/islams-impact-on-womens-lives-and-how-they-respond-to/article_548985cf-ce8b-5f08-a236-9459117adbd2.html", "TITLE": " Islams Impact on Womens Lives and How They Respond to World Events ", "DATE": "Aug 8, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Unfortunately, the Muslim faith came to the forefront globally due to the actions of a small number of individuals in 2001, after the attack on the World Trade Center. Since then, it seems that Muslims worldwide have had to defend themselves verbally and yes, even physically.What some fail to see is that the actions of one group does not or should not cast a shadow on an entire community. Persons who follow Islam can be just as mindful, respectful, law-abiding and constructive as individuals of any other faith.In a world where it seems that morality and general self-respect are being seen as the new bad, just like others, Muslims too are striving to maintain order in their homes and guiding their children on the right path. Generally, women of all religions and cultures embrace similar ideals within their marital households. However, two local Muslim women, Amirah Bholai and Hanisha Karim, expressed their perspectives on what they saw as their responsibility as a woman of Islamic faith. I was curious about what aspect of Ramadan they looked forward to during the period of fasting; what Islamic lessons they sougt to teach their children; and what they considered to be a womans greatest role within her marital relationship.Bholai, is of African descent and is originally from Trinidad but migrated to and has spent most of her adult years in the United States. Twenty-three years ago, she converted to Islam and married a practising Muslim 16 years ago. As a Muslim woman, I ask Allah for forgiveness and strength to do better after Ramadan and in a way that is the same as we do during Ramadan. I teach my kids that in your time of need pray only to Allah for help.Being Muslim we should not go to a monk, priest, the obeah man or anyone else. I tell them make sure to pray five times a day. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/spiritual-shouter-baptists-free-to-worship/article_a91f8d9d-b2ce-55a3-b576-327864a12c52.html", "TITLE": " Spiritual Shouter Baptists free to worship ", "DATE": "Mar 28, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "When on January 26, 1996, then Prime Minister Basdeo Panday declared March 30 Spiritual Baptist Shouter Liberation Day, it was a triumph for the still misunderstood group of believers. There are still many who will cross the street when they see them in prayer. For Archbishop Episcopus Barbara Gray-Burke, the painful memories remain, but the triumph of the freedom to worship is much sweeter. \"Every year we give God thanks for a new dawn.\" she says. \"At one time certain banks would not allow me to park [on their compound] even though I was a minister of religion,\" she recalled. \"I had members who could not go to work with their heads tied. At one stage your passport couldn't have you with your head tied. Nuns could have their picture taken with their heads tied, but we couldn't. I could go on and on. Now you could have your own marriage officers today.\" Burke added: \"We are glad for the freedom to worship God. [Our ancestors] went to prison only for worshpping God. Our plans for the future are to have a Baptist school to educate the young ones in our faith. We are looking forward to a primary school, secondary school and university.\" This year she celebrates in Maloney with a Thanksgiving service. It includes giving out awards including book presentations. Burke says she has given copies of the book to the National Library and the University of the West Indies so that young people will be able to understand the faith's relationship with God. She said: \"The rumours spread that we were obeah people. We are a faith and believe in the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. We are not obeah people. We are trying to correct all those myths and misconceptions.\" She describes the religion as being about service. Burke says she was elated upon hearing that March 30 was declared Spiritual Baptist Liberation Day and describes the day as one of reflection. \"It means a lot to [Baptists]. It means they have to reflect on the past, present and future, knowing that their ancestors preserved the faith for themfor all of usand now they are free to worship. Preservation of the faith, that is what is important to us.\" Although the attire may be different to other religions, Burke said members pray to God just like any other conformist church. \"We sing, we pray, we read the Bible, we clap, we shout. We are indigenous. There are goups all over the world.\" Burke quoted Psalm 100:1 of the King James Bible which states \"Make a joyful noise unto the Lord, all ye lands.\" She continued: \"We believe too that men and brethren shout and bring down the walls of Jericho.\" From the years 1917 to 1951 the Spiritual and Shouter Baptist faith was officially banned in Trinidad by the colonial government of the day. The legislation to enact this ban, the Shouters Prohibition Ordinance, was passed on November 16, 1917. The reason given for the ordinance was that the Shouters made too much noise with their loud singing and bell ringing and disturbed the peace. Witnesses reported that during worship, participants danced, shouted, shook and fell to the ground in convulsions. Such behaviour was deemed unseemly by the more traditional and conservative elements in the society. Also, the established churches regarded such behaviour as heathen and barbaric. The police, who had been persecuting the Baptists for several years, also wanted them silenced. Worshipers were arrested, beaten and jailed if they were caught practising their religion. Like criminals, they had to flee to the hills and forests to practise their religion. Even then, the police still pursued and brutalised them. Nevertheless the Spiritual and Shouter Baptists survived. During the 1920s and 1930s, the Baptists fought many court battles and tried to counteract the negative perceptions of their faith. It was only when Tubal Uriah 'Buzz' Butler emerged as a labour leader that attitudes towards the Baptists gradually began to change. Butler himself was a devoted Baptist and controversial figure. His public meetings were reminiscent of a Baptist prayer meeting. His prominence gave the religion some legitimacy although he too was jailed for his political and religious beliefs. During the 1940s Grenadian-born Elton George Griffith campaigned to have the Prohibition Ordinance repealed. Under his leadership the numerous Independent Baptist churches formed the West Indian Evangelical Spiritual Baptist Faith. In 1940, as a united body, they presented a petition to the Legislative Council asking for the ordinance to be repealed. It was not granted but a few years later Albert Gomes asked the council to appoint a committee to look into a repeal of the 1917 ordinance. A committee was formed but it took several years before it released its findings. Meanwhile Griffith and his followers continued to lobby members of the Legislative Council to support the repeal. Finally, after much lobbying, the bill to repeal the ordinance was passed on March 30, 1951. The Spiritual and Shouter Baptists were free to practise their religion. The hidden agenda is to impose immorality on a nation that rejects immorality and has strong religious foundations. We must continue to listen to our religious leaders and all those in authority. We should never stop listening to the truth to believe in the many lies and deceptions currently being proposed. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/going-beyond-prayer-to-save-our-environment/article_6bc6d8ac-a5dc-5135-89db-17a6d4e8db1f.html", "TITLE": " Going beyond prayer to save our environment ", "DATE": "Feb 11, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "During the recently concluded National Week of Prayer, one day was assigned to pray for the environment. With the Beetham landfill fires belching inescapable toxic fumes, oil spills polluting our coasts and smothering our wildlife, and devastating floods and landslides at the slightest rain, it is obvious that our islands are increasingly unable to sustain us. It is good that religious bodies and the Government recognise that Trinidad and Tobagos environment needs a miracle, but now that the prayers have been said, whats next T&Ts major religious denominations (Christianity, Hinduism and Islam) all call on believers to take responsibility for the earth and its creatures. The Bible is full of teachings that call upon Christians to fulfil their role and responsibility as caretakers or stewards to God, the rightful owner of the earth. Stewardship is a moral obligation and environmental destruction is the destruction of Gods creation. Hindus believe that the Divine is everywhere and we are not separate from nature. The Muslim holy book, the Quran, contains many verses that speak to environmental protection. The Islamic approach to the environment involves Tawhid, the unity principle; Fitra, the principle of the natural state; Mizan, the balance principle; and Khalifa, the responsibility principle. Internationally, many religious groups have issued a call to act on such environmental principles. The Alliance of Religions and Conservation (ARC) is an international organisation bridging religion and the environment. Based in the UK, it was founded by His Royal Highness Prince Philip in 1995. ARCs aim, according to their website, is to assist the major religions of the world to develop environmental programmes based on their own core teachings, beliefs and practices. ARC works to help faiths turn their ecological teachings into action. Working with representatives of the worlds major faiths, they focus on developing long-term commitments for a living planet. These are faith-based commitments to environmental action to address pressing global environmental issues such as climate change. ARC has worked on projects that include transformation of a municipal rubbish dump to an urban green space, a green guide to Hajj, sacred sanctuaries for wildlife, reduction of soil erosion in the Sahara, Africa, and organic agriculture initiatives. Another inspirational organisation is GreenFaith, one of the most widely recognised religious, environmental organisations in the US. They have been hard at work since the 1990s, implementing programmes to address environmental issues. According to GreenFaith, for the religious community to make a difference to the environment, religious institutions and individuals must live out stewardship in everyday action. They provide congregations from multiple faiths with approaches to religious-environmental engagement. GreenFaiths programmes include energy conservation and the use of renewable energy in religious institutions, environmental health and justice programmes, and religious-environmental training programmes for clergy and layleaders. These international organisations demonstrate that faith-based action can help us achieve a cleaner, healthier environment. In T&T, many citizens are moved by a profound faith, but given the path we are on, prayer can only take us part of the way. The question remains: how do we turn our faith into a cleaner, greener, safer T&T It requires more than just a sermon here and there, a yearly tree-planting exercise or changing a few light bulbs. Our environmental problems are not easy fixes. They are ongoing, so the solutions have to be ongoing as well. If prayer alone can solve our problems, then prayers should include an urgent request for an improved human respiratory system that can breathe toxic fumes, a tough integumentary (skin) system to safely swim in waters that are about as clean as a toilet bowl and an improved human stomach that can digest toxins and plastics. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-plan-beyond-belief/article_05eda98e-70a6-57b7-b23d-e1e06f38e18c.html", "TITLE": " A plan beyond belief ", "DATE": "Apr 8, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "With all due respect to the Education Minister, Dr Tim Gopeesingh, there seems to be an agenda to convert our primary and secondary schools, designed for academic development of our children and citizens, into churches, mandirs or mosques. Can schools take the place of religious training institutions, and should school teachers take the place of religious experts Has the minister considered the mammoth and confusing task, coupled with the impracticability involved in such an undertaking Moreover, he seems to be assuming the \"strange\" role of high priest, imam, pundit or archbishop to mandate that his subordinates teach all religions to their children. Where are we heading as a nation with this approach Aren't we enjoying religious harmony already in this country In his address to the Hindu Students' Council of Trinidad and Tobago, the minister referred to \"a revised curriculum in religious education that mirrors the virtues and values of all the religious groups in our country.\" Whose brain-child is this Is there a hidden religious agenda here This is essentially syncretism (the combining of different religions, cultures and ways of thinking); so that this whole effort seems nothing more than the imposition of \"another religion\" on the nation, starting with our vulnerable and unsuspecting children. The wonderful \"pluralism\" of T&T implied in the minister's speech is likely to be seriously eroded as the classroom turns into a religious war-zone through the implementation of the proposed curriculum. That which is beautiful now at the cultural, social and academic levels could quickly turn into outright religious war in the classroom. The minister should be aware that religious sensitivities become more acute when one is forced to teach or listen to that which one does not believe in or find insulting to one's convictions. Worse, when a government provides an official platform for comparisons and contrasts of the nation's religions, what can be more divisive Everybody knows how deep religious sentiments run among any people, whether multicultural, multi-religious or not! What is the ontological basis of the so-called \"moral values held by our diverse faiths\" referred to by Prof John Spence How else can these moral values be sound except rooted in objective truth, that which is established by one Creator God Are they merely ideologies coming out of humanistic considerations or is there a standardised moral code from which they are drawn Which set of moral values should teachers persuade our children to embrace Which ones are right and which ones are wrong Prof Spence (one of my former UWI lecturers) is certainly not an expert in religion; I am surprised he is advocating this, if only partly on the basis of the information from a UK \"teacher on that subject\". I would have expected much more in-depth and insightful judgment on his part. He should note that a \"multicultural society\" is not the same as a religiously syncretic society, more like the agenda being pushed by the Minister of Education. This is where serious problems are likely to developwhere a kind of religious melting pot is imposed on the citizenry. Some serious questions have to be asked. How many religions will be covered in this \"revised curriculum\" What about denominational branches In Christianity, there are the Roman Catholics, the Episcopalian (Anglican), Moravian, Spiritual or Shouter Baptists, Pentecostals, Seventh Day Adventists, Presbyterians and others. What about branches of Hinduism or Islam This comparative religion business is certainly not a matter for primary and secondary schools. This should be left to religious bodies. It will only create an extra burden on our pupils and unwarrantedly hamper their overall development. By the way, did the minister ban extra-curricular activities in schools to accommodate this \"religious\" agenda The type of religious education proposed, fraught with such dangers, could never be more beneficial to our children's education than extra-curricular activities. The issue is not one of \"ignorance\" as Dr Spence implies; it is about people's deep-seated religious convictions that cannot be dictated and mandated against. Then where is the integrity of our national anthem: \"Here every creed and race find an equal place\" Here is where the Prime Minister needs to overrule. \"Who is qualified to teach what\" Would a Christian teacher teach on Hinduism What would be the content of that teaching What would be the source of informationthe Gita or the Holy Bible Would teachers be guilty of offending pupils and their parents What about bias, disrespect and perceived or deliberate insults that could be hurled at other people's religions What about the workability of a belief or its unrealistic nature What about metaphysics and the question of ontology, causality, the philosophy of time, space or space time as conceptualised by different religions Will teachers teach on the \"nature of evidence\" and the \"critical experiment\" of a religious view that either verifies or falsifies a hypothesis or theory What a huge, confused and impractical curriculum this is likely to be, if it has to make sense or justify the paper and the time utilised for doing same! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/tests-of-gods/article_9a383677-9d0e-5cda-b474-dcb6e148da65.html", "TITLE": " Tests of Gods ", "DATE": "Oct 13, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "impressed: Suhas Gopinath impressed: Suhas Gopinath Most children grow up fooled by one religion, but the Government now plans to ensure that the nation's youth are fooled by several. According to an official document from a workshop held last week for teaching Comparative Religion, a key objective is to \"Develop respect for other religions, while remaining strong in one's own belief systems (which include atheism and agnosticism).\" In other words, teachers would have to lie about religion, and a lack of religion. However, for the few conscientious teachers who might teach this subject honestly, I have written a booklet comparing Trinidad's three main religions. Here's a short extract, complete with test questions: Comparing women: All religions agree that women must obey men, but differ in how to make this happen. The Bible says that if a woman is found not to be a virgin on her wedding night, \"the men of the city shall stone her with stones that she die\" (Deuteronomy 22:20-21). The Qur'an tells men that they're in charge of women and instructs \"from those whom you fear defiance, warn them and send them to a separate bed and whip them\" (surah 4, verse 34). And the Manusamhita decrees that \"In childhood a woman should be under her father's control, in youth under her husband's and, when her husband is dead, under her son's.\" Question What causes men to fear disobedience from a woman (a) beauty; (b) intelligence; (c) small penis. Crime comparisons: All religions are against crime, unless you're killing, robbing, or raping a believer of another religion. Then it's hunky-dory. So although the sixth commandment in the Bible says, \"Thou shalt not murder\", in Numbers 31:17-18 Yahweh tells Moses to order his followers to attack the Midianites and \"kill every male among the little ones, and kill every woman that hath known man by lying with him.\" Muslims, in their turn, value possessions more than limbs, so the Qur'an says, \"As for the thief, both male and female, cut off their hands\" (5:38). In Hinduism, sitting can be a serious offence, and the Manusamhita states that \"If a man of inferior caste tries to sit in the same seat as man of superior caste, he should...have his buttocks cut off.\" Questions (a) Don't all women lie (b) Do only bisexual thieves get their hands chopped off (c) Can this punishment really be applied to flat-bottomed Indians Comparative peace: Apologists for all three religions claim they promote peace, which is why they never cite the following scriptures: in the Bible, \"Thou shalt smite them and utterly destroy them; thou shalt make no covenant with them, nor show mercy unto them (Deut. 7:2).\" In the Qur'an, \"Warfare is ordained for you, though it is hateful onto you: but it may happen that you hate a thing which is good for you, and love a thing which is bad for you\" (2:216). And in the Bhagavadgita, \"One who is not driven by pride, whose mind is clear, though he kills men in this world, does not kill.\" Questions (a) If you smite someone, don't they get smitten (b) Is war like cheesecake (c) What is the psychological term for individuals who kill but believe they don't Comparatively sinful: All religions agree that some actions are absolutely wrong, though none mentions adding ketchup to eggs. For Muslims, the greatest sin is not to be Muslim, because \"Who does a greater evil than he who invents a lie against Allah and denies His revelations\" (6:21).The Bible takes a similar tack, with Leviticus 24:16 decreeing \"And he that blasphemeth the name of the Lord, he shall surely be put to death.\" Hinduism, however, doesn't mind non-believers, once their noses aren't bigger than a Brahmin's. Question Is it a sin to eat devilled eggs Compare the facts: The facts taught to young people from religious texts would not often match the facts taught in other subjects. The Bible, for example, says that the human race started with two persons: Adam, who was created from dust (Genesis 2:7); and Eve, who was created from Adam's rib (Gen. 2: 21-22). The evidence from palaeontology, biochemistry, and genetics says that modern human beings evolved in Africa about 100,000 years ago. Another religious fact from the Qur'an is that mountains prevent earthquakes (16:15, 21:31), whereas geologists know that mountains are formed from tectonic, volcanic, and sedimentary forces. And, although biologists talk about larvae, the Manusamhita says that \"Mosquitoes and gnats, lice, flies, and maggots, and other species of this sort which originate from heat are born of sweat.\" Questions Should students believe God's word or man's science If the former, will they get extra marks, if the latter will they go to Hell If they go to Hell, will the heat make them sweat If it does, will their sweat breed mosquitoes, gnats, lice, flies, maggots, etc kbaldeosingh@hotmail.com TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/it-is-the-church-to-blame/article_dc90d29e-7b30-5454-ba63-0a04c5fa36c3.html", "TITLE": " It is the \u2018Church\u2019 to blame ", "DATE": "Feb 13, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "It is reported that the leaders of the Pentecostal Church, the Maha Sabha and ASJA, have all come out in support of the misogynic statements surrounding the murder of Japanese pannist Asami Nagakiya. It is unfortunate that religious leaders can only promote religion through condemnation of women since the time of Eve (May the peace and blessings of Allah be upon her). Condemnation is the methodology of appearing to be religious and women are easy targets because of Eve. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-plan-beyond-belief/article_88965901-e07a-5fa4-9f78-14f276ac0106.html", "TITLE": " A plan beyond belief ", "DATE": "Apr 8, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "With all due respect to the Education Minister, Dr Tim Gopeesingh, there seems to be an agenda to convert our primary and secondary schools, designed for academic development of our children and citizens, into churches, mandirs or mosques. Can schools take the place of religious training institutions, and should school teachers take the place of religious experts Has the minister considered the mammoth and confusing task, coupled with the impracticability involved in such an undertaking Moreover, he seems to be assuming the strange role of high priest, imam, pundit or archbishop to mandate that his subordinates teach all religions to their children. Where are we heading as a nation with this approach Arent we enjoying religious harmony already in this country In his address to the Hindu Students Council of Trinidad and Tobago, the minister referred to a revised curriculum in religious education that mirrors the virtues and values of all the religious groups in our country. Whose brain-child is this Is there a hidden religious agenda here This is essentially syncretism (the combining of different religions, cultures and ways of thinking); so that this whole effort seems nothing more than the imposition of another religion on the nation, starting with our vulnerable and unsuspecting children. The wonderful pluralism of T&T implied in the ministers speech is likely to be seriously eroded as the classroom turns into a religious war-zone through the implementation of the proposed curriculum. That which is beautiful now at the cultural, social and academic levels could quickly turn into outright religious war in the classroom. The minister should be aware that religious sensitivities become more acute when one is forced to teach or listen to that which one does not believe in or find insulting to ones convictions. Worse, when a government provides an official platform for comparisons and contrasts of the nations religions, what can be more divisive Everybody knows how deep religious sentiments run among any people, whether multicultural, multi-religious or not! What is the ontological basis of the so-called moral values held by our diverse faiths referred to by Prof John Spence How else can these moral values be sound except rooted in objective truth, that which is established by one Creator God Are they merely ideologies coming out of humanistic considerations or is there a standardised moral code from which they are drawn Which set of moral values should teachers persuade our children to embrace Which ones are right and which ones are wrong Prof Spence (one of my former UWI lecturers) is certainly not an expert in religion; I am surprised he is advocating this, if only partly on the basis of the information from a UK teacher on that subject. I would have expected much more in-depth and insightful judgment on his part. He should note that a multicultural society is not the same as a religiously syncretic society, more like the agenda being pushed by the Minister of Education. This is where serious problems are likely to developwhere a kind of religious melting pot is imposed on the citizenry. Some serious questions have to be asked. How many religions will be covered in this revised curriculum What about denominational branches In Christianity, there are the Roman Catholics, the Episcopalian (Anglican), Moravian, Spiritual or Shouter Baptists, Pentecostals, Seventh Day Adventists, Presbyterians and others. What about branches of Hinduism or Islam This comparative religion business is certainly not a matter for primary and secondary schools. This should be left to religious bodies. It will only create an extra burden on our pupils and unwarrantedly hamper their overall development. By the way, did the minister ban extra-curricular activities in schools to accommodate this religious agenda The type of religious education proposed, fraught with such dangers, could never be more beneficial to our childrens education than extra-curricular activities. The issue is not one of ignorance as Dr Spence implies; it is about peoples deep-seated religious convictions that cannot be dictated and mandated against. Then where is the integrity of our national anthem: Here every creed and race find an equal place Here is where the Prime Minister needs to overrule. Who is qualified to teach what Would a Christian teacher teach on Hinduism What would be the content of that teaching What would be the source of informationthe Gita or the Holy Bible Would teachers be guilty of offending pupils and their parents What about bias, disrespect and perceived or deliberate insults that could be hurled at other peoples religions What about the workability of a belief or its unrealistic nature What about metaphysics and the question of ontology, causality, the philosophy of time, space or space time as conceptualised by different religions Will teachers teach on the nature of evidence and the critical experiment of a religious view that either verifies or falsifies a hypothesis or theory What a huge, confused and impractical curriculum this is likely to be, if it has to make sense or justify the paper and the time utilised for doing same! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-teaching-of-religions/article_47a5794f-65a4-521a-ba5c-9f65b987d3eb.html", "TITLE": " The teaching of religions ", "DATE": "Apr 15, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " Part 2 It is not my intention to address the comments that have been made on my last article, except to say that I admit to not being an expert on religion as one commentator has remarked. Indeed it is in part that lack of knowledge of religions other than the one to which I adhere, knowledge which in my view should be acquired at school, that I support the teaching of religions in our schools. As promised in my last article I shall once again present some comments that I have made in previous articles and the views of a teacher of Religious Education (RE) in the United Kingdom where by law it is a compulsory subject. It seems appropriate to do so at this time when attention is focused on this issue. This teacher is from Trinidad and Tobago and has taught RE in the UK for over 20 years. He keeps in touch with this country by periodic visits. I quote: \"There are two possible pitfalls in a multicultural society: the one is to take the liberal view that 'all religions are fundamentally from the same source'. This denies integrity to members of a number of religions for whom commitment means a rejection of this notion. The other is to believe that there is no possible benefit from communication between human beings whose world views are fundamentally incompatible. This is clearly a recipe for social discord. For me the classroom is a microcosm of society, and in RE lessons we try to establish a 'community of enquiry' into a number of world views, particularly religious ones, in order to test truth claims and give pupils the skills needed either to affirm already held beliefs or to search for themselves. It works because in such a community they are taught that relationships are more important than winning arguments, and being reasonable therefore means more than being rational. Sometimes people just have to agree to disagree, but can still show respect. This is not the same as accepting things which are against your belief, but it is acknowledging another person's right to choose, and your own responsibility to live in peace wherever possible. We try and allow authentic representatives of different world views to have their say in a carefully constructed context, to avoid the accusation of indoctrination. (e.g. a Buddhist monk is asked to comment on the suffering of the holocaust, followed by a survivor of the holocaust and then by a Christian). The pupils devise the questions to be asked, and in the end give their own conclusions as to why there is suffering in the world. They are being asked to develop an approach to deal with whatever life throws at them, after hearing how others have overcome suffering. In the classroom I encourage a robust integrity and reasonable conflict based on relationships that can 'take the load'; this is better in the long run for society, rather than ignoring differences. A curriculum which denies a genuine spiritual search is in itself a form of indoctrination into agnosticism. Although agnosticism should be a legitimate world view, it should not be at the expense of true faith, and discussing faith should not be avoided because of potential trouble. This simply stores up more trouble than social relationships can cope with, leading to the breakdown of a multicultural society into warring factions\". \"The UK syllabus in Religious Education provides for spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of the students. The sections on spiritual development help students to consider the meaning and purpose of life and values in human society. In the sections on moral development students use their understanding of religious and ethical teaching to consider areas of morality. In studies of social development students are assisted to develop a sense of identity and to be prepared for life as citizens in a multicultural, multi-religious society. In cultural development studies, issues within and between faiths are considered in order to develop an understanding of the cultural contexts in which they live. The students' awareness and understanding of a range of beliefs, practices and values in their own society and in the world are enhanced. This syllabus also promotes pupils personal, social and health education and citizenship. It deals with religious and moral beliefs and values that lead to beneficial social policies and practices (e.g. crime and punishment), and beneficial patterns of health (e.g. preventing the use of drugs). It looks at voluntary and charitable activities of individuals and organisations that help to make up a healthy democratic society. It contributes to social and political awareness (e.g. rights and responsibilities) and helps pupils to understand and respect people of different beliefs, races and cultures. RE provides opportunities for pupils to work together sharing ideas, discussing beliefs, values and practices and learning from each other. They may study particular topics such as Conservation of the Environment and discuss how each Faith addresses this issue\". Teaching RE can have a beneficial effect on the school population outside of the RE classes. Here are the comments on the teaching of RE at a school in the UK made by a review team that has done a detailed review of all facets of that school for the Office for Standards in Education (OFSTED): \" Pupils are engaged in the lessons, express opinions and think for themselves. They are helped to analyse their opinions and those of others. The subject is made relevant to life today and pupils are engaged in big moral, social and philosophical questions such as justice, faith, love, care, trust and why we are here. Further, links have been made \"with a wide range of people from the faith communities including Christians, Jews, Muslims and Hindus to give a broad perspective on faith. People from these groups come into the school to add to the teachers' input in lessons. The subject (RE) makes a very good contribution to pupils' spiritual, moral, social and cultural development\". It is my hope that the views expressed above will be of some use in the discussions on the introduction of RE into schools in this country\". John Spence is Professor Emeritus, UWI. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/that-s-your-morality-not-mine/article_dd838cb8-f5a3-56ca-bafa-dd80f4c006bf.html", "TITLE": " That\u2019s your morality, not mine ", "DATE": "Feb 18, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "I REFER to a letter in the Express of Thursday, February 18, written by Rev Robert Dash, who expressed support for former mayor Raymond Tim Kee, concerning the apparent immorality of Carnival masqueraders. First of all, I wish to deal with the concept of morality as defined by the Cambridge English dictionary. Morality is defined as \u201ca set of personal or social standards for good or bad behaviour\u201d. It is important to recognise as indicated in that definition that there is personal morality and social morality. Personal morality is the moral belief system you hold yourself to as an individual while social morality stems from the general belief system embraced collectively as a community/nation. This difference in morality arises from the simple fact that in most coun\u00adtries, their citizens come from different religious persuasions, diffe\u00adrent ethnicities, different political views and different social classes. The religious aspect can be further dissected as there are people who do not subscribe to any religion, some subscribe to agnostic beliefs while others are atheist and humanist. The morality you hold for yourself, in essence, comes from and is influenced by your religious persuasion/non-religious persuasion, political views and your social standing. The social morality we espouse is mostly dictated by our political system, that is, the fact that we live in a democracy. However, the personal morality, which is the most prominent, is mostly influenced by what religious views our parents imparted to us as children. Our personal morality is then further shaped by our decisions as adults, that is, whether we choose to embrace a religion diffe\u00adrent from our parents or whether we choose no religion and instead embrace agnosticism, atheism or humanist ideology. I say this all to highlight the obvi\u00adous\u2014that no two persons in a multireligious, multi-ethnic demo\u00adcracy such as Trinidad and Tobago will have the exact same personal moral code. Rev Dash then went on to make this most interesting statement: \u201cThe culture of a people should not be allowed to take them away from the true, living God.\u201d I found that statement to be quite astounding for seve\u00adral reasons. In a multireligious society such as ours, which of the religions ascribe to the true, living God Is it the Muslims Hindus Catholics Pentecostals Secondly, Rev Dash cannot compel any\u00adone living in democra\u00adtic Tri\u00adni\u00addad and Tobago to subscribe to a religion. Just as he has the right to practise his religion freely without fear of persecution, it is the right of the agnostic or the atheist to not subscribe to any religion. I believe this entire fiasco with the former mayor could have been avoided if people understood this very basic concept. Trinidad and Tobago is a democracy, and a republic at that. It is the right of any citizen to frown upon and avoid anything that he/she perceives to be contradictory to their personal morality. No one, and that includes a mayor, pastor, pundit, imam, Christian, Hindu, Muslim, agnostic or atheist, has the right to impose their concept of mora\u00adlity on another citizen. They also do not have the right to try to prevent any citizen from doing anything that they are comfortable doing and which they feel does not conflict with their own moral code. Some religious people have gone so far as to complain that people who participate in Carnival shut down Port of Spain for two days. Interestingly enough, they make no mention of the seven or so religious holidays which shut down the country throughout the year and inconveniences non-religious people or people who are not of their religious persuasion. Such is the nature of democracy, and it cannot be any other way. Any time we start going down the road of dictating to anyone what they can and cannot do based on our religious concept of morality, is to lead the way to dictating to people what religion they ought to be in or dictating that they ought to have a religion in the first place, notwithstanding any reservations to such. History is replete with examples of the disastrous consequences of such attempts, such as the long, bloody Catholic/Protestant conflict in Northern Ireland. I, for one, have no intention of surrendering my personal morality to the whims and fancy of a zealot, especially since I am one of those who abandoned the religion of my parents and opted for the ideology of the agnostic. But that is my constitutional right as is granted in the democratic republic of Trinidad and Tobago. Freedom of religion is an enshrined constitutional right and an extremely sensitive issue to many. We have found a unique and exemplary way to live among our fellow citizens of different faiths. In most other countries, a population as diverse in race, culture and religion like ours would have been extremely difficult if not impossible to govern. We have achieved something that is admired the world over and we have achieved it without anyone from the Education Ministry ever mandating to schools that they must teach about other religions. A Hindu teacher teaching Hindu children in a Hindu school about Hinduism is quite different from a Pentecostal teacher teaching Christian children in a Christian school about Hinduism. Naturally, the Hindu teacher teaching Christian doctrines would be biased and stymied by his own personal convictions, and vice versa. One of the Christian and Islamic beliefs and teachings about Hinduism is that it is pagan, demonic, polytheistic and evil. The Minister should leave that hornets' nest alone! What is the mischief in society that needs to be corrected What void and lack exists in the intellectual development of our schoolchildren because they are not being taught about other religions We are living in an Internet age and any child who so desires can learn about other religions by simply \"Googling\" them! This mandate has the potential to introduce to pupils not just the teachings about other religions, but the biases and prejudices that exist between them. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/clumsy-handling-of-a-touchy-subject/article_93a53ef7-1fc4-5e6f-b85f-a8a3e64e9c10.html", "TITLE": " Clumsy handling of a touchy subject ", "DATE": "Apr 4, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " Education Minister Tim Gopeesingh should by now have got the message that religion probably runs a close second to race as a touchy subject in Trinidad and Tobago. The public reaction to his plan to mandate \"religious education'' in all schools, ranging from fear to concern to plain bigotry, threatens to blight in advance the prospects of the policy's implementation. Dr Gopeesingh created a perhaps unnecessary furore by the vague and off-the-cuff manner in which he announced, in advance of the consultation on curriculum due to have started yesterday, that religious education would be made mandatory in all schools. \"In the reviewed curriculum, all schools, whether they are government, government-assisted, which are denominational or private, will be mandated to teach about religious education as part of their timetable,\" said the Education Minister at a Hindu students' conference last Sunday, emphasising, \"So we want to teach about religious education, and not religious education there is a difference.\" He should have explained that difference. Dr Gopeesingh could not have actually meant \"teach about religious education\", since this means teaching about how religion is taught. What he presumably meant was teaching about the philosophy, tenets and history of religion, as distinct from the present practice of religious indoctrination. The Minister should also have clarified why private schools are being forced by the State to include this on their timetable. While it is true that the Education Ministry regulates private educational institutions, this is only to the extent of ensuring that certain pedagogical standards are met, such as having qualified teachers. The inclusion of private schools in this mandate implies that the Government considers learning about religion to be as indispensable for education as, say, English Language, Mathematics and Science. The proposed imposition on denominational schools, founded specifically to foster their own religions, will also very likely lead to conflict. At present, these schools do not directly impose their beliefs on students who don't belong to their faith, but this does not mean the schools would want their core students being taught about other religions, although a Catholic spokesperson yesterday appeared to welcome the teaching of comparative religion. On its website, the Ministry states that the curriculum for Comparative Religion \"must be based on an understanding of the norms and values of our society and grounded in the lives of our communities.\" This begs the question as to whether different religions have different norms and values, and also assumes that such values can undergird, rather than undermine, the quest to build a nation out of diverse traditions. It may be that all these issues will be addressed in the stakeholders conference which ends today. But the controversy will almost certainly continue, largely because of Dr Gopeesingh's hopeless inarticulation and clumsy public relations on this question. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/religion-and-porn/article_d59c01c3-bb9f-50d4-90f7-eeb927e5cca4.html", "TITLE": " Religion and porn ", "DATE": "Dec 22, 2008 ", "CONTENT": "CHRISTMAS GIFT: Member of Parliament for Laventille East/Morvant Donna Cox receives a gift from little Tariq Sanchez during a Christmas treat for children of her constituency held at the House of Angostura, Laventille yesterday. \u2013Photo JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK CHRISTMAS GIFT: Member of Parliament for Laventille East/Morvant Donna Cox receives a gift from little Tariq Sanchez during a Christmas treat for children of her constituency held at the House of Angostura, Laventille yesterday. \u2013Photo JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK In this the final of a three-part series on porn addiction, a behaviour change specialist tells Nazma Muller that Trinidad and Tobago's secret sexual habits are a result of too much preaching, and not enough teaching \"I don't collect, I just borrow, watch it and give it back.\" So Kelly-Ann wouldn't say she's addicted to porn; but she likes to watch it. The 40-year-old professional has a boyfriend, who doesn't know about her secret habit. \"I'm not into girl-on-girl action, that's boring. I'm into hetero stufftwo guys and a girl. That's a fantasy of mine.\" The ex-Convent girl said she started out reading Playboy and Penthouse as a teen, and had seen some of the older movies, including classics like Deep Throat. \"I was always curious about sex. And back then I wasn't doing anything (sex-wise), just fooling around. That's how I would learn about it, reading articles in magazines. It was research, this was something I planned to do and I wanted to get it right.\" At Convent Kelly-Ann didn't talk to the other girls about sex. \"That was not the kind of conversation we would have,\" she shrugged. Then she went to UWI, and started having sex, \"so I would watch porn and learn tricks to put into practice\". She still enjoys reading erotica, mostly written by women for women because \"it comes at sex from a whole different angle\". Most porn videos are made by men, she pointed out. \"Porn is mainstream now anyway,\" Kelly-Ann insisted. Well, in the US and Europe anyway, with rappers making music videos that are basically softcore porn; and a few even doing hardcore versions. However, she had to admit, her liking for porn was \"not something I would disclose to everybody\". \"We are a society that is uncomfortable with the idea of discussing sex,\" says Salorn McDonald of Population Services International (PSI), an organisation that is trying to change the high-risk sexual behaviour that many Trinbagonians engage in. As the regional behaviour change communications manager for PSI, McDonald has seen and heard a lot in his research. \"You have old men bragging about contracting STIs (sexually transmitted infections) back in their heyday,\" he exclaimed. \"Back then it was a source of pride to get 'runnings'. They show you their old, beat-up, green clinic card, as if getting it made them a man. They don't tell you about the burning sensation when you pee and not being able to walk properly after a shot of penicillin. \"We have to remove the mystique and mystery from sex. This is what creates that appetite to explore. We need to make this a normal part of our upbringing, then it becomes a healthy understanding of life and ourselves.\" Where does this publicly prudish attitude (except at Carnival) come from Is it because we were a British colony \"It goes deeper than that,\" McDonald contends. Many people tend to use a faith-based approach to raising children, he said, be it Christianity, Islam, Hinduism or Rastafarianism. And this means sex is portrayed as something that should not be talked about. \"We ingrain this into our children and that creates a situation where there is no exploration of sexual appetite, and discussing sex is immoral. The idea of having young people discuss sex is not to be done.\" Worse, it does not equip our children for a world inhabited by sexual predators. Young girls with no knowledge of sex or feelings are fooled into having sex with the first person who tells them \"I love you\". All of this could be avoided if, God forbid, children were exposed to information about sex and sexuality at an early age, says McDonald. He has visited countries such as Switzerland, Sweden and Holland, where there is clear evidence that education about the birds and the bees has helped to reduce teenage pregnancy and the incidence of \"VD\" (venereal disease). Even in England, sex education is to be taught in schools. In October, Schools Minister Jim Knight announced that sex education would be added to the national curriculum including kindergartens. The English have had no choice but to confront distressing figures such as 39,000 girls between ages 15 and 17 becoming pregnant in 2006, plus another 7,200 girls between the ages of 13 and 14. \"It's vital that this information doesn't come from playground rumour or the mixed messages from the media about sex,\" Knight said. Currently, English schools are only required to teach basic lessons on reproduction as part of the science curriculum. Now they will have to provide lessons on relationships and contraception, with the lessons becoming more sophisticated as the children get older. Elementary schools can offer lessons in naming body parts, preparing for puberty and relationship feelings, Knight said. At the very earliest, sex education will mainly be about self-awareness, he said. \"We are not talking about five-year-old kids being taught sex. What we're talking about is children knowing about themselves, their differences, their friendships and how to manage their feelings.\" In Trinidad and Tobago we still teach a vague introduction to public health and hygiene in school that dates way back, McDonald said with exasperation. The absence of proper sex education in schools is not serving children in any way. \"It's not helping young people to understand themselves and what happens to their bodies,\" he said. And burying our heads in the sand is not going to make resulting problems, like porn addiction, go away. To be a fine, upstanding member of this society, says McDonald, one does not discuss matters like sex. And this belief is especially strong among the elders. \"They say what seems to be the correct thing,\" he noted, \"rather than saying or doing the important thingwhat is necessary.\" Do you think sex education is the answer to addressing problems like porn addiction Tell us with you think. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-atheist-buses/article_5e31a8aa-dc56-5896-8250-f4afcca2f193.html", "TITLE": " The atheist buses ", "DATE": "Feb 10, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "Jamaludin Khan, Petrotrin\u0092s vice president of exploration and production, speaking at the Energy Conference at Hyatt Regency, Wrightson Road, Port of Spain last Tuesday. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SLANDY Jamaludin Khan, Petrotrin\u0092s vice president of exploration and production, speaking at the Energy Conference at Hyatt Regency, Wrightson Road, Port of Spain last Tuesday. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SLANDY If the objective was to undermine people's belief in God, then turning the atheist buses loose in Britain was largely a waste of time, because most British people don't believe in God anyway. The atheist buses are all over London and some other big British cities by now, with a large ad running down the sides saying: \"There is probably no God. Now stop worrying and enjoy your life.'' But you have to ask: if the sponsors of the ad, the British Humanist Society, felt strongly enough about it to spend 35,000 (US$50,000) to put the signs on all those buses, why did they only say \"probably no God'' It's not their fault. Tim Bleakley, managing director for sales and marketing at CBS Outdoor in London, which handles advertising for the bus system, explained that advertisements saying flatly that there is no God \"would have been misleading'' for religious people. \"So as not to fall foul of the code, you have to acknowledge that there is a gray area.'' When the complaints rolled in anyway, alleging that the ad was offensive to Christians and that the \"no God'' claim could not be substantiated, the Advertising Standards Authority ruled that the ads were \"an expression of the advertiser's opinion and that the claims in it were not capable of objective substantiation.\" For a non-theological organisation, the ASA is pretty sharp. Never mind all that. The real question is: what did the British Humanist Society think it would achieve with its ad campaign It's not as though non-believers in Britain were an oppressed minority. In fact, they're not a minority at all. They are the majority, although you have to read the statistics carefully to realise that. According to the 2001 census, only seven million people in Britain said they had no religion, while 37 million said they were Christian. 1.5 million were Muslim, half a million were Hindu, 390,000 were Jedi Knights (there was a conspiracy among younger Britons to mock the process by claiming allegiance to the religion of Star Wars), 329,000 were Sikhs and 260,000 were Jewish. Those numbers suggest that Britain is an overwhelmingly Christian country, with under 20 per cent of the population non-believers. Yet three-quarters of the people in Britain do not go to church even once a year. On an average Sunday only six per cent of the population is in church, and that figure has been dropping at two per cent per decade since the 1970s. Something doesn't add up here. When the International Social Survey Programme conducted a more in-depth study of religious belief almost 20 years ago (1991 and 1993), it asked people if they agreed or disagreed with the statement \"I know God exists and I have no doubts about it.'' In Britain, only 23.8 per cent of people said they agreed. That's a normal number for Europe. In that ISSP poll, most European countries only registered between 20 and 30 per cent for confident belief in God, although Italy struggled up to 51 per cent, Ireland reached 58 per cent and Poland got the prize with 66 per cent believers. What is happening is that people in Britain and many other countries are answering the census question about religion in terms of their cultural heritage (which is, in most cases, Christian), not of their actual beliefs. It all depends on how you phrase the question, but the official figures are misleading. Actual levels of religious belief in Europe are very low. Moreover, the collapse in belief is continuing, with the youngest least likely to identify with a religion. A MORI poll commissioned by the British Library in 2007 found that nearly half of teenagers in Britain were atheists. This fits in better with what you actually observe from day to day in most European countries. People are no less moral than they ever were, but religion is simply absent in daily life in Europe, at least compared to the United States, where it seems omnipresent. Yet here's a strange thing: the very first place those bus ads came out was the United States. The idea started in Britain, but the American Humanists moved faster. Their ads appeared on buses in Washington, DC, in November, saying \"Why believe in a god Just be good for goodness' sake''and there was little public outcry. Maybe the United States is not that different after all. The United States, we are constantly told, has a level of religious belief almost as high as Iran's, and every Gallup poll since 1944 has reported that at least 94 per cent of Americans \"believe in God or a universal spirit.'' But look at that question. If you had any lingering guilt at all about having abandoned your ancestral religion, you'd say yes to that, wouldn't you When the ISSP asked its much more rigorous question, only 66 per cent of Americans agreed with the statement, \"I know God exists and I have no doubts about it.'' That was almost 20 years ago, and it's very likely that the level of belief has fallen since. The United States is not the same as Europe, but it is not invulnerable to the same trends. Which may be why President Obama, while rhyming off the roll-call of America's religions in the time-honoured fashion in his election-night acceptance speech, for the first time added \"and non-believers.'' {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/bigotry-has-no-place-in-education/article_a765dc62-a941-5b70-966d-27f9028026a4.html", "TITLE": " Bigotry has no place in education ", "DATE": "Mar 19, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "Although the parents of the pupil in the Naparima College controversy have denied being atheists, it is apparent that the teacher felt secure in making threatening remarks about homosexuals and non-believers because this kind of bigotry is considered acceptable by many people in the school and the wider society. Disparaging the sixth-form pupil to a class, the teacher reportedly stated that: \u201cThe beginning of the story is he has two parents who should not be parents, they are screw-ups, they are atheists, they do not believe in God. You see me, give me a gun and I will fix all the problems in the world. I will shoot both of them first and then their offspring.\u201d That the teacher thinks atheists and homosexuals deserve to be killed reveals the kind of fanaticism religious beliefs can engender in otherwise normal persons, which has been acted out most prominently by jihadists around the world and, in 1990, right here in Trinidad and Tobago. As an organisation which has a high proportion of atheists and agnostics, we must note that the teacher's view that persons who do not believe in God are unfit to be parents is not borne out by the research. While there are no data for T&T, surveys in other societies show that atheist parents, far more than religious ones, typically impart to their children at least one of the virtues listed in the national motto: tolerance. Indeed, whereas religious parents invariably indoctrinate their children into their beliefs, atheist parents mostly leave it up to their children to choose their own paths and often actively expose them to different belief systems. Although their children usually end up non-religious, that is probably because atheist parents tend to teach their children to think for themselves and to be ethical in their choices. That makes it less likely that they will adhere to religious beliefs or religion-based morality. As for outcomes, it is worth noting that, in T&T's jails all religions are over-represented or on par with the general populace, except Hindus and Presbyterians who are under-represented. Non-conformists, as the prison authorities label inmates who profess no religion, make up seven per cent of the inmates.
