{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-are-not-a-religious-people/article_482de43e-7612-50c1-8c6f-bf1e4d6d16d8.html", "TITLE": " We are not a religious people ", "DATE": "Feb 2, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "IT is undeniable that in Trinidad and Tobago the majority of people will call themselves religious and say they belong to a religion. What is interesting, however, is that people in T&T tend to be culturally religious and not religious at all. This may sound confusing but I will explain what I mean. Religion, defined as a set of principles and beliefs, has governed human existence for a number of years. With religion there is usually a divine being or beings, that is God or gods. Within religion a number of rules and norms have been established that come to define what is acceptable behaviour, how the world is to be seen and how one in general should perceive things. The great or major religions are Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, Judaism and Buddhism, but the teachings of these religions are much more than how to pray and who to believe in. They are ways of life and behaviour. Queue Trinidad and Tobago, the land of multiculturalism, many religions, peoples, traditions and backgrounds. The melting pot of the Caribbean, where thankfully at the moment there exists little or no religious strife. In our beautiful country, though, when most people align themselves with a religion, they do so in a very narrow sense. They have adhered to some of the ritual actions and belief systems of their respective religions but for the most part they have abandoned the moral, social and mental aspects of their faith. A case in point is our wonderful Carnival season where our people revel in the things of the world and its \"vices\". For the average person this is not a scandal or anything to be afraid of; it is Carnival and Carnival is in our blood as a people. It would be interesting to know that the major religions condemn to no end and religious societies forbid the behaviour and very idea of Carnival. The same people who are chipping down the street on Carnival day three-quarter naked will not think twice of praying before they go to bed and in most cases going to church. We as a society see nothing wrong with this. Another great example in our unique country is where different religions cross and intermingle. Muslims go to Hindu prayer services, Catholics to Muslim functions and all the like. One would recall when the Honourable Mr Jack Warner took part in a Hindu prayer service the Archbishop gave an opinion that condemned it and cited some obscure teaching that calls for no religious mixing. What the Archbishop did not know is that in our country those rules forbidding mixing and cross-religious participation have been thrown out the window. What has resulted from this is a religiously tolerant society, unlike places like India where Hindus and Muslims kill each other or Lebanon where Muslim and Christian militias would gladly kill each other over religion. I am hoping that my point about being culturally religious is coming across now. It is no more greatly demonstrated than in the Hindu population who have adhered to Indian/Hindu culture but abandoned many of the teachings of the Hindu religion. The caste system has been thrown out the window but the saris and kurtas still remain. The temples and Divali still remain but many of the rules governing male/female interaction, many Hindu teachings about eating meat and consuming alcohol have been tossed out and family and culture have come to replace the teachings of Hinduism. The same goes for my Muslim brethren who have demonstrated great faith to their religious values in terms of beliefs but have thrown the behaviour and societal controls involving male/female interaction etc out the window. This is not to say that people do not \"read their bible and pray every day\". I am not denying that. What I am advocating, however, is that people skip over the part dealing with not eating a cloven-footed animal (that is pork) as they love their pork too much, and the part calling for the honouring of the Sabbath, that is, no work on a Sunday, is thrown out the window also. These things may seem minute and \"normal\" but they are in fact betrayals of what a religion entails. In countries where religion actually holds sway these things are honoured to a tee. In our blessed country, politics has not been tainted by religion that much. When compared to a place like the US, believe it or not, we are a highly developed non-religious democracy. The religious and moral beliefs of a candidate or a party mean nothing to us as we are not religious like the Christian right wing in the US. We are indeed much closer to Western Europe who have thrown religion out the window a very long time ago. What is also interesting about Western Europe is that in the majority of countries the majority of the population do not identify with a religion and are either atheist (do not believe in God) or agnostic (God cannot be proved or disproved so they are sceptical of religion and have none). Is Trinidad and Tobago heading towards a fully secular non-religious society One cannot be sure. It may be hard now to imagine our country devoid of religious people but this is actually where we are trending. A large swath of the younger generation has thrown religion completely out the window. Some are atheists and agnostics and some still say they are religious, but in name only. This does not mean that we have no morals and values. All it means is that we will do good not to go to heaven but because we wish to do it and help our fellow human beings. The world is becoming more secular as religion declines. Trinidad and Tobago is already ahead of its time. Let us hope it will continue. Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal for business studies/modern studies in 2006. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/muslim-cries-discrimination-because-of-her-religion/article_cdc634bc-df8b-5dc1-b17b-4416fcfd7e4f.html", "TITLE": " Muslim cries discrimination because of her religion ", "DATE": "Aug 5, 2015 ", "CONTENT": "Crystal Lewis, of Scarborough, Tobago, is claiming religious victimisation and discrimination. A follower of the Muslim faith, Lewis has been told to remove her religious garments or she will not be paid. The Tobago House of Assembly (THA) has launched an immediate investigation into her allegations. Lewis claims a senior THA official at the Division of Agriculture is causing some concern. Almost brought to tears, Lewis told the Express yesterday she has been treated like a criminal since she decided to practise the Muslim faith. She claims the official attached to the Division of Agriculture is paying no regard to her religious beliefs. \u201cUpon entering a senior official's office, I was told to take off my hijab, and if I did not do so, then I'm not allowed in the office,\u201d Lewis said. As a checker attached to the Mt St George work crew, she is responsible for at least 30 workers and for Wednesday's visit to the senior official, time sheets were to be signed for payment of salaries. Lewis said when she refused to remove her hijab she was verbally abused and the salaries of at least 30 workers are now in jeopardy. \u201cWell, my response to that senior officer was I was not going to remove my hijab, and his response was, well, I need to get out of his office,\u201d she said. Lewis said she was told her clothing was intimidating. \u201cHe then came out and said it and said that he was intimidated, and I could have a weapon under my hijab. So I looked at him with disbelief. I know this is a government building and this should not be happening in a multi-cultural, multi-racial society as Trinidad and Tobago.\u201d She said she did not expect to be handed such treatment. \u201cAnyone has the right to practise what religion they choose to and my supervisor made me feel like I was a terrorist.\u201d Contacted for a comment on the matter, THA Agriculture Secretary, Godwin Adams, said the division does not condone that type of behaviour. He classified the persecution as unacceptable and an immediate investigation has been launched into the matter. Lewis said she has informed Mulsimeen leader Imam Abu Bakr of the matter. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/is-religion-education-good/article_2db67fd5-51f2-5b96-b9a8-1668e0f53257.html", "TITLE": " Is Religion Education good ", "DATE": "Apr 15, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The Religious Education that the Government will be making compulsory in all schools is supposed to foster tolerance among young people. But, according to psychological studies, this will be achieved only if the students become less religious. And, if RE makes more people more religious, crime and corruption in Trinidad and Tobago may get worse. This is not the view of the country's present Prime Minister, however. When she was Minister of Education in the UNC administration 15 years ago, Kamla Persad-Bissessar told the audience at an ASJA fund-raising function: \"There is a fair amount of empirical evidence that points to the contribution that religion makes to healthy human development, especially in the development of the young.\" But in their book Atheists, North American psychologists Bruce Hunsberger and Bob Altemeyer cite their research which found that, the more religious people were, the more narrow-minded they became. \"As religiosity ranges from 0 to 100, so will dogmatism, zealotry, authoritarianism, and prejudice generally increase,\" they write. Their studies encompassed Canadians and Americans who went to church regularly and those who went only occasionally. Non-believers scored lowest on this list of undesirable traits. However, psychologist David G Myers, whose psychology textbooks are widely used in American universities, says the opposite in his book A Friendly Letter to Skeptics and Atheists. \"In nearly every one of more than two dozen studies, faithful church attenders exhibited less prejudice than irregular attenders,\" Myers writes. \"...it seems that, among the churched, the devout exhibit less prejudice and deeper feelings of human kinship that the nominally religious, who are somewhat more likely to rationalise prejudice with the aid of religion.\" In Trinidad and Tobago, religion is also seen as a key to academic success. Religious leaders continually claim that it is the religious character of the denominational schools which account for them producing most of the top 100 SEA students and taking the lion's share of CSEC scholarships. Maha Sabha head Sat Maharaj, for example, in a 2007 article in the Trinidad Guardian wrote: \"A successful education system must, therefore, provide for the cultural and religious needs of the children. Lack of State subventions for priests, pundits, and imams to teach religious values must impact negatively, especially at the state schools.\" However, at the formal opening of a national consultation on the primary school curriculum on April 5, Education Minister Tim Gopeesingh noted, \"The denomination boards cream the top and put them into their so-called prestige schools, so they must get better results at CSEC, CXC. So you only get good results at CXC and CSEC because you have the best students coming to your school.\" Other factors may be more pertinent to the academic performance of these schools. Criminologist Ramesh Deosaran has done research showing that the majority of students in the \"prestige schools\" come from two-parent families which are mostly upper- and middle-class. (See Table 1.) Studies show that these factors are more relevant than a religious upbringing to doing well in school and avoiding serious juvenile delinquency. Moreover, studies in other countries have consistently shown a negative correlation between IQ or education and religiosityi.e. the higher people's IQ or educational attainments, the less likely they are to be religious. For example, a 1996 study by psychologists EJ Larson and L Witham showed that over two-thirds of the most eminent American scientists do not believe in God or an afterlife, as compared to a mere ten per cent of the general American populace who also rejected such beliefs. Table 2 shows the religious affiliations of UWI students at the St Augustine campus, compared to their respective proportions in the wider population. The percentage of students who did not state their religion is twice that of the general populace (or seven times that of the national census who put \"None\"). All denominations are under-represented, except Presbyterians and Pentecostals. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/religious-tolerance-and-racial-harmony/article_a23eda48-dda1-5a4c-96ad-ae01b7a6ee87.html", "TITLE": " Religious tolerance and racial harmony ", "DATE": "Mar 30, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "WORLD CHAMP: Jehue Gordon WORLD CHAMP: Jehue Gordon One of the primary facets of a free country is the guarantee of religious freedom and religious tolerance by the State. That is why many people of different religious persuasions recognise the need for a secular state to ensure that the state does not promote one religion over another or discriminate against any particular creed. Many of us like to think that in Trinidad and Tobago every creed and race has an equal place and were quite surprised to hear the Prime Minister declare that born-again Christians were being persecuted in modern T&T. It is reasonable to expect the major religions of our country to work together to promote religious tolerance and racial harmony. The four largest religions in the world (Christianity, Islam, Hinduism and Judaism) are all monotheist. That is to say they all believe in one God. In Hinduism God may have many manifestations and in Catholicism there may be three persons in one God, but they all believe there is only one God. I am most certainly not an expert in religion but I am willing to accept that this one God is one and the same for all religions. For that reason I believe it is important to respect the beliefs of others and not denigrate or discriminate against other religions. Unfortunately although religion is supposed to be a force for good it has been used over the centuries to provoke differences, justify wars and promote atrocities. Nobody needs to be an expert in religion or history to be aware of the very numerous acts of persecution in the name of religion and the massacres that have been perpetrated in the name of the true God. The Crusades and the Inquisition are but two examples of violence in the name of religion. And of course views change over time so Joan of Arc can be burnt as a heretic and later canonised as a saint. It is unfortunately true that many leaders, for their own misguided reasons, have played on the fears of the ignorant to divide people against each other. Many acts of religious violence are committed within a broad faith e.g. Catholics against Protestants, Shi'ites against Sunnis and so you can see tolerance as a goal is not something universally achieved. My platitude that every religion believes in the same God, is about as hopeful as wishing for racial harmony because all races are human. Trinidad and Tobago has had its share of religious discrimination and persecution. The colonial powers of Spain, France and England that populated Trinidad were largely Christian and the State was not secular. It took a long time for other religions to be tolerated and in acknowledgement of that a public holiday was declared to recognise the struggle of Shouter Baptists. That holiday (yesterday) should have been a good time for us all to reflect on the need for tolerance and respect for all religions including Full Gospel born-again Christians. I am not calling for a public holiday for them, however, because we have far too many already and also I do not believe there is one iota of evidence of religious persecution against any groups in T&T today. Quite honestly we need to reduce the number of holidays and having holidays for Christians, Hindus, Muslims and Baptists is not necessary in the name of religious tolerance and may be detrimental to productivity. Even if there is no evidence of persecution against any religion in T&T today we must remain vigilant to ensure it stays that way. Persecution is not far behind discrimination and intolerance and it would be an exaggeration to say that Trinidad is a tolerant society in which there is no religious discrimination. It is very much up to our religious leaders to teach their followers the virtues of tolerance and to ensure the state does not enforce religious customs on the population. We must also be vigilant to ensure that religion is able to preserve its independence from politics. Politicians are not beyond using religious differences to seek their own ends. The creation of public holidays and the granting of land or other favours to religious groups in the expectation of political support is not far from overt corruption. It is reasonable to seek to support politicians and parties that show strong moral values and integrity. But ask yourself this. Does it matter what religious beliefs any Prime Minister has in this plural society Does it matter to you if he is Hindu, Catholic, Anglican, Presbyterian, Muslim, Southern Baptist, Shouter Baptist or even agnostic or atheist If it does, ask yourself why. Should it not be enough that our leaders have strong moral values and principles, leaving religion entirely separate It is very important to the future harmony of our multi-cultural, multi-racial and multi-religious society that we remain tolerant and the State remains secular. We must not allow our differences to be used against us as we work for a better T&T. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/keep-religion-out-of-schools/article_82278671-f435-58af-a39c-76fff0100e8a.html", "TITLE": " Keep religion out of schools ", "DATE": "Apr 13, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Part 1 Singapore, Switzerland, Denmark, Japan, Hong Kong, Norway and the Netherlands countries with the lowest crime rates in the world, less than 30 per cent of the people are religious. Colombia, Jamaica, Venezuela, Mexico, South Africa countries with the highest crime rates in the world, more than 80 per cent of the people are religious. LAST week, when I read there was some lunacy being floated around that religion was going to be taught in schools, I almost blew a gasket. I started to write my column only to realise it was being driven by disbelief and anger and not by logic, facts, figures and academic proof which are what I base my columns on. I cooled off, decided to read the arguments of the proponents and then respond rationally. Examine the above data from the United Nations Criminal Justice Information Network, the CIA World Factbook and various national statistical agencies. Look closely at the countries that have the lowest crime rates and what does one notice Then look at those with the worst crime rates. What does one notice Yes, you are right the most religious countries are the worst in terms of crime, whilst the lowest crime rates exist in countries that have large numbers of non-religious people atheists and agnostics. I read an interesting argument that T&T is experiencing a high murder rate because of moral and social decay and in some odd way this is connected to lack of religious education! Is anyone as confused as I am To tell me that teaching religious studies in school is going to lessen crime is the equivalent of saying prayer will heal cancer and HIV. Well it has not and it is not going to. Schools are supposed to be bastions of wisdom, places where facts, figures, science, history and truth reign supreme. Not places for children to learn about stories from books that have been proven wrong so many times one wonders why revised editions have not been put out. Do not get me wrong. Religious tolerance is a worthy trait and should be instilled. But this should be done through the teaching of the social sciences, history and philosophy; through theological studies that dissect and analyse and many cases disprove religious theories. Not through forcing children to listen to people yap for hours about things that have no factual basis. Religious tolerance needs to be fostered though everyday interaction, cultural shows, exhibitions in school libraries etc, Not by forcing kids to zone out and they will zone out for an hour or so a week. If anything, kids will get more dismissive; if it is one thing that all people but more so children hate, it is to be forced to do anything. What about the non-believers, the atheists and the agnostics What will happen to them I know as a humanist/agnostic myself, if someone had tried to teach me religion in secondary school I would have been thrown out of class more times than I was, because I would argue endlessly. But what about the other students not like me who will sit there in discomfort for hours, being told stories that belief in some form or another of God(s) is the way to heaven One may ask, how many non-believers are there in secondary school Well, I interact with secondary school pupils online a lot. Any sample would show that while many are nominal members of some religion, most could not care less and believe even less. If you do not believe me ask a teenager if they really believe in what their religion says, the stories and myths. Be prepared for a surprise. They may say they are Hindu/Muslim/Christian, but only in name; they do not adhere to or believe most of what those religions teach. What exactly is going to be taught Is it a cursory review of the major religions Is it their principles, because the principles of two of the largest Abrahamic religions (Islam and Christianity) in our country are fundamentally incompatible with the Kumbaya notion being peddled in the articles I read. Those religions state that there is only one God their God, there is only one way their way and others will be cast to hell and fire and brimstone and so on. Is this what 14-year-olds are going to be told Which religions are going to be taught There are many minorities in T&T including some Kabir Panth, Baha'i, Baptists and Jews. Are their faiths going to be taught What of some of the lovely passages from those good books Are the homophobic ones going to be mentioned How will the gay/bisexual and lesbian youngsters feel The passages that call for the stoning of disobedient children, the ones that call people infidels, the one that says kill the Jew under the rock, the one that says fire will come to burn those who do not believe We would like some answers. School is for advancement, not fairy tales. It has been proven time and time again that as education increases, religion decreases, development increases and crime decreases. The teaching of religion is best left to the home and to the society that must demonstrate the values they preach. It makes no sense to have children learn about religion and then the imams, pastors and pundits go lambasting other faiths and either calling for them to repent, convert or be prepared for hell. What should be thought in school is knowledge grounded in facts and reality. With this knowledge comes power and this power crushes the illusion of religion. From this only good things come forth. Next week Religion a failed experiment. Rajiv Gopie won the President's Medal for business studies/modern studies in 2006. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/how-to-value-religion/article_6cbd2dcd-2387-5412-a7f0-1d891d56fffb.html", "TITLE": " How to value religion ", "DATE": "Apr 6, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "GOOD RUN: Michelle-Lee Ahye GOOD RUN: Michelle-Lee Ahye I wasn't invited to the Education Ministry's stakeholders consultation on the teaching of religion. Maybe the organisers find that I stake religious beliefs too often in my writing. Nonetheless, since I know more about religion than religious leaders in Trinidad and Tobago, I feel I have an intellectual obligation to put in my two cents' worth. And, after hearing Education Minister Tim Gopeesingh's rationale for this new policy, I figure that figure is just about right. According to Dr Gopeesingh, the Ministry wants \"a revised curriculum that mirrors the virtues and values of all the religious groups in the country\". But if religion were taught like a proper subject, such as Science, then it wouldn't be a mirror of virtues. Physics teachers don't tell students they should believe Maxwell's laws of electromagnetism because James Maxwell was a teetotaller, and Biology teachers don't argue that evolution is a fact because Charles Darwin never horned his wife. Teaching Religion as it is actually practised here would mean teaching young people how to take money under false pretences such as healing the sick, preventing crime, and stopping hurricanes. (Many students already know how to fornicate while saying \"Oh God\".) So if Religion is to be a subject which reflects virtue, then English Language teachers would first be required to teach their students a new meaning of the word \"virtue\". After all, if nine-year-old school girls are told the age of the Prophet Muhammad's fourth wife, Aisha, they would probably go \"Ewww!\", indicating that their idea of virtue is different from Muslim scholars', who explain that it was a great honour for Aisha to be chosen by the 53-year-old Muhammad. Now all schools, and not just Muslim ones, will be teaching girls to be ambitious from small, since even a nine-year-old can cook, sweep, and marry their grandfather's friend. This value of women is also backed up in Christianity and Hinduism, since Corinthians 11:9 says \"Neither was the man created for the woman but the woman for the man\" while the Bhagavadgita says that women are of \"lower birth\". Teachers could explain that this doesn't mean women were made to serve man, as a common sense interpretation of these words would suggest, but only that men need someone to wash their clothes. The virtue provided here by Yahweh is the formula to prevent domestic violence in Colossians 3:18-19, which says, \"Wives, be subject to your husbands, as fitting in the Lord.\" It would be rather more difficult to explain the virtues of the Bhagavadgita, especially to teenage boys from Laventille, since Bhagavan says: \"One who is not motivated by ego, whose intelligence is not entangled, though he kills men in this world, does not kill nor is he bound by his actions.\" Schoolboys may interpret this to mean that, since they aren't doing well in class, they could kill and not go to jail. The teacher should explain that this rule only allows Hindus to kill, and even then only if they're brahmins or ksatriyas. The virtue here is that this would lead to less stigmatisation of little black boys. On the other hand, teaching Religion could lead to more stigmatisation of little gay boys. Leviticus 20:13 says, \"If a man lies with a male as with a woman, both of them have committed an abomination; they shall be put to death\". But if this law was followed, would anyone be left to put on plays at Queen's Hall Would it have to be renamed Kings Hall However, teachers can take their cue from Seventh-Day Adventist pastor Clive Dottin, who says this is a moral law and not a ceremonial law, which I assume means that you needn't execute homosexuals nowadays but they're all still going to Hell. Where teachers will have the most problems, though, would be in reconciling religious facts with actual facts. In Mathematics class, students are told that pi is an infinite sequence of numbers of which the first six numbers are 3.14159: but, in 1Kings 7:23, the value of pi is calculated as 3. The fractions in the Quran also contradict what students are taught in Math, since Sura 4:11-12 and 4:176 state that when a man dies, leaving only his mother, his wife and two sisters, then they respectively receive , , and inheritance: which adds up to 15/12 of the man's property. Maybe in the first instance, teachers can say that everybody rounds up figures, including Yahweh, and in the second instance claim that this is proof that Allah performs even better miracles than Jesus feeding the multitudes with two fishes and five loaves. So, given that religion would still be taught as propaganda in T&T's schools, such a class would mainly impart ignorance and intolerance to the students. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/opinion/cudjoe-distorting-the-nature-of-hinduism/article_8ac59279-e779-5e66-ae23-295c6079b2e0.html", "TITLE": " Cudjoe distorting the nature of Hinduism ", "DATE": "Dec 28, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "Selwyn Cudjoe's description of Hinduism in his column headlined \u201cRace and tribal consciousness\u201d (Sunday Express, December 18) is a great distortion of the world's oldest religion. Prof Cudjoe stated: \u201cHinduism, a feudal religion of many strands, demands allegiance of its followers. That does not make its followers tribal, it makes them narrowly myopic.\u201d If Hinduism is \u201ca polytheistic religion\u201d then one may draw the conclusion that the idea of the Divine is not exclusive but broad and inclusive. This is certainly not being \u201cmyopic\u201d like other religions which are exclusive, with the idea of God as one, with one scripture and one mediator between the one God and his followers. American David Frawley wrote in his book Hinduism The Eternal Tradition that \u201cthere is one religion which has always formulated itself as a universal tradition. Hinduism does not rest itself upon any singular formation or belief system but has remained open to all approaches to truth through a great variety of spiritual teachings and practices apart from any organised dogma\u201d. He continued: \u201cThe beauty of Hinduism is that it is a religion which is open to the universal and not closed in an exclusive belief system. Hinduism is not centred on any single belief system. Hinduism not centred on any figure like Christ, Mohammed or Buddha. It has no standard creed or practice. It is an open tradition of spiritual searching that accepts all true human aspiration regardless of its name and form.\u201d To write that, \u201cHinduism demands allegiance of its followers\u201d similar to the fanaticism of some exclusive religions is disparaging to Hinduism. This is not true. Hinduism in Trinidad reflects the pluralism of the ancient tradition, with many organisations and schools of thought. There is no Hindu political agenda in Trinidad. Over the years Hindus have supported both the PNM and parties opposed to the PNM. From 1956 the Arya Samajists, for example, have supported the PNM, together with other Hindu leaders. Even pundits have stood on PNM platforms. Jack Warner, in 2013, won the Chaguanas East bye-election with Hindu support. In 2015 the UNC recaptured the constituency with mainly Hindu/Indian support. In 1971 even Bhadase Sagan Maraj was rejected by the electorate. It is an error to suggest that Hindus support the UNC and formerly the ULF and DLP because of Hinduism. Just as faulty is the analysis that the ULF and UNC had their political base in the sugar belt and Rienzi Complex. A combination of factors can best explain Hindu political behaviour and not only religion. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-do-not-need-a-holy-war-in-t-t/article_d797b891-8b8a-5f83-9071-1da2d5033368.html", "TITLE": " We do not need a holy war in T&T ", "DATE": "May 30, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "One can only hope that the child marriage debate does not escalate into a \u201creligious war\u201d. T&T is a diverse society with various religions and cultures, and at times, politics and religion sometimes collide. But in spite of our differences, we are by and large a tolerant people. Nonetheless, people's religious beliefs are sacred, and perceived inflammatory remarks against their religion will ultimately be met with commensurate responses. As such, tolerance must not be taken for granted and differences must be managed with sensitivity. One expects religious leaders to be more diplomatic and politically correct in their utterances than ordinary citizens. After all, their remarks are seen as representative of their respective organisations. For example, it was all well and good for a priest to lead a political demonstration around the Red House. That's his democratic right. But publicly chastising other religious leaders for their decision to steer clear of politics is tantamount to provoking religious strife. My personal view is, Archbishop Harris' response to the child marriage debate, labelling it \u201crape\u201d, was a tad excessive. After all, his organisation is hardly blameless regarding violations against children. If we are to move forward, we must appreciate that child marriage was an acceptable undertaking among certain cultures and religions. Now that society has evolved, child marriage is seen as old-fashioned and disadvantageous. That said, secretary general of the Sanatan Dharma Maha Sabha, Sat Maharaj, should also tone down his rhetoric. I cite his response to Archbishop Harris. After all, religion is rooted in high principles. Without mutual tolerance, respect, and forgiveness, religion will be relegated to nothing more than cheap politics. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/professing-nonsense/article_34f59bd0-e768-5cdb-b702-198c2a772bc4.html", "TITLE": " Professing nonsense ", "DATE": "Feb 2, 2009 ", "CONTENT": " From time to time letters appear in the newspapers, often including the academic title of the writer professor this or professor that, some even acknowledging a particular field of specialisation. Occasionally some are sensitive enough not to give their titles. But the title \"professor'' as used in the British tradition is essentially an academic ranking, usually in a particular discipline. In the past, again in the British tradition, a professor headed a department and was intellectual leader in a discipline. The fact that one is titled \"professor'' does not necessarily confer on one any special competence in other disciplines, although there have been spectacular exceptions, such as Prof Joseph Needham, a noted embryologist/biochemist and internationally acclaimed Chinese scholar. In most cases one professor may be highly qualified in a particular discipline but know no more than a KFC cashier about Sumerian archaeology, or for that matter the orchids of Trinidad and Tobago. Most understand their limitations. About 15 years ago one UWI science professor responded to some letter writer in one of the newspapers who argued that the Hindu religion was the oldest religion in the world and in essence that its age conferred on it something of special significance in knowledge of ultimate reality. His response was essentially that Hinduism was a lot of silly superstition and mythology while Christianity and Islam were real living religions, the implication being that Hinduism was dead. And my guess is that, that particular professor in the following days may have lectured to a class that may have included Hindusthey really are tolerant. At the time I was somewhat intrigued at his notion of living and dead religions and wondered about his knowledge, good Christian that he was, of the history of the living ones and their murderous ways, and of diversification of Christianity from the original over the past two millennia. Exactly what makes a religion \"living\" and another \"dead\" To some, all religions must be \"living\" in that they actually have some sort of corpus of beliefs, worship or practice folk religious rites. In the monotheistic ones there are several subdivisions and sects, and some even believe that theirs is the true religion. To others all religions may be dead, irrelevant and no more than conditioning based on folk myths, a sort of displacement activity reaction, to explain the unexplainableand thus gain power over others. A recent letter coming from another UWI professor with no demonstrated published record in evolutionary science dismisses evolution as \"baseless speculations\". Scientific theories are based on scientific knowledge. The bases of the fact of evolution by natural selection include geology, palaeontology, biogeography, embryology, comparative anatomy, morphology, physiology, biochemistry, genetics and other branches of science, and indeed animal and plant breeding by the human species. To argue that evolution is founded on baseless speculation is to argue that many branches of science simply do not exist. This is utter nonsense. I wonder therefore what the letter writer might make of a suggestion by, say, Kevin Baldeosingh who might equally well argue that all religion is merely an uncritical acceptance of folk mythology, or, by, say, BC as mere manifestations of genetic expression of relatively few genes that had some benefit in binding small communities at one time, but which as populations dispersed contributed to the excessive intraspecific competition and violence. It is in no way unusual that evolution comes under attack from religions. This dates back to Darwin's times, although, sound scientist that he was, he took no part in the discourse. The opposition came from a church, the Church of England into which he was born and conditioned and whose Holy Orders he once considered joining. Darwin of course became agnostic in his later years. But the attacks continue using the \"flat earthist\" approach. They simply cannot grasp a simple fact that organic evolution is not about the question of origin/s of life, but about the facts of the processes of formation of species from pre-existing species, or, that there are several hypotheses about the origin or origins of life, some originating from science and many from folk mythology. You can accept or reject the fact of evolution if you wish. Religious beliefs however remain centred about a few unprovable notions and continue to be divisive of humanity. Religion and religious zeal are undoubtedly a force in human society, in some respects beneficial to binding groups together with common beliefs, myths and mores. In other respects the force may be exploitative, tyrannical and often murderous. Yet religions are hardly consistent in their \"beliefs\". In Christianity, the main stem which once burnt \"heretics,\" now fully supports abolition of capital punishment and accepts the fact of evolution of species, while some fundamentalist morphs offer instant miracles, deny evolution, believe the planet is 6,000 years old, praise George Bush and damn Barack Obamaand want to hang the criminals. In another monotheistic one, women are occasionally stoned to deathfor performing a natural biological function! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-teaching-of-religions/article_272f0775-ccac-5129-a024-91964f98e35e.html", "TITLE": " The teaching of religions ", "DATE": "Apr 5, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " Part I I am particularly heartened by the report (Express, April 4) that the Minister of Education has announced that the teaching of religions will be introduced into the curriculum of all schools. I congratulate the Minister and the People's Partnership Government in taking a bold step for which they will no doubt receive criticism from many quarters. On the Internet edition of the Express at time of writing (Monday 4th) there have been already 168 comments on the news report of the Minister's announcement on the teaching of religions! There may be objections, from individuals many of whom may not be knowledgeable of the moral values that are at the heart of all religions and which are so sadly lacking in our society today. There has already been discussion of this subject by stakeholders. Under the initiative of the National Commission for UNESCO a one-day symposium was held in 2008 and two workshops in 2010 on the teaching of religions. The feature speaker at the last workshop was a very distinguished son of the soil Prof Anantanand Rambachan. He is Prof of Religion, Philosophy and Asian Studies at St Olaf College, Minnesota, USA. St Olaf is a college in the Lutheran (Christian) tradition. He has a great deal of experience at the international level in religious education. There will be opportunity for further discussion at the Ministry of Education's Consultation on Curriculum that is being held this week. I have written articles in the Express on this subject in 2002, 2004 and 2010. I quote below extracts from those articles: Trinidad and Tobago is a multicultural and multi-religious society. In order that there be harmony among our diverse peoples, it is necessary that we understand the philosophies and mores of each other, for ignorance breeds fear and mistrust. However, while we treat with some of the cultural differences in the curriculum in our schools, no fundamental instruction in each other's beliefs is given. Thus many of our young people do not appreciate the moral values held by our diverse faiths. The breakdown of the family structure; the emergence of more and more single-parent families; the pressure on both parents to be away from the home for long periods each day in an effort to ensure economic stability in the home, all mitigate against the instilling of ethical values in our children. While it is recognised that the home is the best place for such instruction, it is proposed here, indeed strongly advocated, that Religious Education (RE) (teaching of religions) be made a compulsory subject at primary and secondary schools in Trinidad and Tobago. Such a programme would also help to address our materialism and selfishness. At the moment religion is taught on a voluntary basis as individual faiths to members of the respective faith (religious instruction). At government schools one hour a week is allocated for this purpose and it is not proposed that the teaching of religions (comparative religion) would in any way interfere with that existing programme. In the United Kingdom, which has become a multicultural society, Religious Education is now enshrined by law as a compulsory element of the national curriculum up to the age of 16, along with a daily act of collective worship. However, this subject is taught as the History and Philosophy of Religion, Comparative Religion and Ethical values. In Trinidad and Tobago, by contrast, if religion is included in the timetable (as stated earlier) it is left to individual religious leaders to give children of their faith instructions in the particular beliefs and many children have a free period if a representative of their faith is not present. The Dearing report, which was the last major review of the national curriculum in the UK, states that a search for a deeper meaning in life is essential to education, as is an understanding of the religious perspectives and spiritual development. It is necessary to distinguish religious instruction in particular faiths (as is provided for in our schools at present) from Religious Education or Comparative Religion which is the teaching about all religions. In the UK both Religious Education and Civics (Citizenship) are compulsory subjects. How many of us (in Trinidad and Tobago) have good knowledge of each other's religious beliefs And it is this ignorance which breeds animosity and in most instances culture is related to religion, and civics includes how we organise society in a relationship which accepts religious and cultural differences (and these in many instances are also related to ethnic and racial differences). In order to introduce RE (teaching of religions) into schools in Trinidad and Tobago a syllabus would have to be developed and teachers would have to be trained. To do this a Unit of Religious Education should be established at the University of the West Indies in the School of Education and Scholarships awarded to do the B.Ed. or the postgraduate Diploma in Education with RE as the main focus. In a subsequent article I shall once again present comments on the value of Religious Education in the UK sent to me by a teacher of that subject. John Spence is Professor Emeritus, UWI. At the same time, a high level of education is strongly correlated with less religiosity. There is no contradiction here. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/richards-all-should-respect-the-occasion/article_75a393c6-f2a3-5287-b0cf-a0741b5975a3.html", "TITLE": " Richards: All should respect the occasion ", "DATE": "Mar 28, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " President George Maxwell Richards, in his message to mark Spiritual Shouter Baptist Liberation Day, called on citizens not celebrating the occasion to respect the sanctity of the day. In his message, Richards said while the day should be one of deep reflection for religious followers, non-religious people should also respect the sanctity of the day. \"Regardless of religious beliefs or even in the absence of religious beliefs, I say this because the fundamental theme that undergirds this celebration is freedom, in this case the freedom of religion,\" he said. He said freedom of conscience, religious belief and observance is also a right protected by the Republican Constitution. He said from 1917 until 1951, the Spiritual/Shouter Baptist community had no legal protection. \"They were on the wrong side of the law and had to depend largely on their own resolve, in order to survive the largely brutal containment of their religious practices,\" he said. The President added that the \"real problem\" and reason for antagonism was because the religious practices were of African origin. \"A large part of the population did not want to be reminded of the shame and degradation associated with things African, particularly slavery,\" he said. \"Religion and culture being closely intertwined as they are, whatever the merits or lack thereof of the above mentioned view, this should give pause for thought and strengthen our determination, as a country of diverse streams, not to be influenced by any considerations that do violence to entitlement to human rights, in the decision-making process, throughout our systems,\" he said. \"On behalf of the national community, I extend best wishes to the Spiritual Baptists at home and in the diaspora, on this day of celebration,\" he said. Richards also recalled the persecution of the Shouter Baptists before the repeal of the Shouter Prohibition Ordinance in 1951 during his annual greeting to the community for today's Shouter Baptist Day holiday. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/sat-is-so-right/article_97515419-45df-520e-8195-9c71000ad0e8.html", "TITLE": " Sat is so right ", "DATE": "Nov 10, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "In reportedly denying entrance to non-Hindu students and staff at the Tunupuna Hindu Primary School, Sat Maharaj is simply expressing his right to the freedom of religion. Am I the only one who has taken note of the fact that the school in question is a \"Hindu\" primary school I have no doubt that it is so called because it was established to teach and further Hindu values. In fact, Mr Maharaj himself, has suggested that his reason for not wanting non-Hindu students and staff at the school is because allowing non-Hindus at the school may result in the contravention of Hindu beliefs and practices. His concern is only natural, for if one sees one's religious beliefs as right, then naturally, one would not want anyone or anything to erode or dilute those beliefs. As a Christian, I understand the fears of Maharaj, for I too, if I headed a Christian primary school, would not want anyone or anything contravening Christian beliefs and I would seek to enforce Christian beliefs in the same way that Maharaj is merely seeking to enforce Hindu beliefs. Thus, there is no reason for the PNM MP Patricia McIntosh to make an issue of Maharaj's refusal to allow non-Hindu students at the school. With regard to the fact that the school is a public school, the fact remains that the Maha Sabha, by virtue of owning the buildings that house the school, has some say in how the school is run. And though the Government financially assists the school, it must respect Maharaj's right (and in doing so, the right of others) to freedom of religion. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/more-than-three-religions-in-t-t/article_cd6a662f-16cf-5dae-b771-e95627d168f5.html", "TITLE": " More than three religions in T&T ", "DATE": "Apr 8, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "So now we going and teach all religions in all schools; and with the same swipe of the pen, or should I say whip, we are removing all extra-curricular activities. I have heard this Government say that we are a multi-religious, multi-ethnic society, yet the Education Minister has mentioned only three religions which are to be taught in schools. Well so much for the multi-religious concept. The 'Christian' religion or faith, is subdivided into many distinct groupings which are in some cases totally different from each other; so your intention is to now lump Catholic, Anglican, Seventh-Day Adventist, Protestant, Southern Baptist (different from Trinidad Baptist), Presbyterian, Born-again and Orthodox into one heap. Sir, that sort of thinking shows a lack of consideration and gross ignorance of these religious groupings, on your part. We also have the Yorb religion which subdivides into three sects in this country: Orisa, Baptist and Shango. Trinidad also has a strong Moslem and Muslim representation. There even exists some subdivision of the Hindu religion, with the traditional Santana Dharma or Hinduism, the Hare Krishna sects and recently the Bramanite sects (which is a kind of mixture of both the Christian and Hindu beliefs); then what about Shinto the Japanese faith; or Buddhism and Taoism or even Shenism, which are all Chinese religions; or the Brotherhood of the Cross and Star; so much for all religions. To teach only three religions and leave out the rest is discriminatory and promotes division rather than inclusion, unity and harmony; so much for multi-ethnic inclusion. Sir, during my school days in the then Mount St Benedict College (an all-boys, Catholic school), we had religious studies which taught predominantly about the existence of a Supreme Being or God (whichever you prefer); and then we dealt with the existence of the many various religions and the ways in which different people worshiped Him in their different religions. I believe that method made all feel included as all religions were taught with equal merit and none were excluded. That was some 30 plus years ago. I dread to think that the education fraternity had a better understanding and more wisdom then, than now. Who comes up with these ideas anyhow Teaching of only three religions in exclusion; and teaching all is just foolishness. I believe the way in which I was taught is the better way to go, as it will remove disharmony and discontent and provide the much needed appreciation of God; which I am hoping was the original intent; unless I am totally misguided, and you had some hidden agenda.
